story:
“I'm beautiful in my way

'Cause God makes no mistakes

I'm on the right track, baby

I was born this way”



Lady Gaga couldn’t have said it any better. Yes, Rafflesia, the world’s largest flower is a freak of nature. It is a plant unlike any other—a non-photosynthetic parasite siphoning nutrients from a tropical vine. It has no roots, stems or leaves, just a massive red-orange flower, a spectacle so seldom in the midst of the rainforest, that tourists pay to see it, in spite of a permeating stench that lures in carrion flies to unwittingly carry its sticky pollen. Hence, the common name, corpse flower.


Click on this link to see flies pollinating the corpse flower


My name is Jeanmaire Molina, a college professor at Long Island University (LIU). I am a Filipino scientist with a dream, and that is to understand Rafflesia’s biology better so that we can grow it and save it from extinction due to rainforest destruction (Barcelona et al. 2009).  So that my son’s grandchildren and yours could also have the pleasure of being mesmerized by it, in the same way the pandas and the tigers are adored and admired. But unlike pandas and tigers, Rafflesia, despite many attempts, has not been grown out of the wild. And my life’s mission as a scientist is to make this happen.

Click here to learn more about me

Your trust in me is important. Click here for my qualifications as a scientist

How do the seeds get into its host plant? What makes the seeds germinate and thrive in its host? How can we replicate the process in artificial environment so that botanic gardens can grow it and conserve it ex situ?

To answer these questions, I will be traveling to the Philippines, the hub of Rafflesia diversity, home to more than 10 Rafflesia species. Your donations will be used to fund 2 weeks of fieldwork including travel costs, costs for field supplies, wages for field assistants, as well as cost of reagents for relevant lab experiments. If I reach my campaign goal by the deadline, I will conduct the field work this August, secure the necessary collecting and export permits to collect plant material, and continue with relevant lab work at LIU in September. If I don't reach my campaign goal, your contribution is NOT in vain. I plan to deposit collected funds in a bank account, and all donors will receive monthly statement updates of the balance, until I can find supplementary funding to pursue the field and lab work next field season (summer 2015).

I ask for NO money for my own personal efforts. The experience of learning about Rafflesia is a reward in itself. As a donor, you will receive regular updates of my results, cool Rafflesia photos from my field work, and you will be fully acknowledged  in research publications from this project. Plus, you get that priceless sense of fulfillment for helping a good cause.

You’d say it is a parasite, so why save it. It is an innocuous parasite, at least from an economic standpoint, unlike the destructive crop-killing witchweeds of Africa and Asia; it only grows on Tetrastigma, an ordinary impractical forest vine, which superficially does not seem to mind its flamboyant parasitic partner. Theirs is an ancient fragile partnership wrought by millions of years of careful evolution.

From a biological perspective, Rafflesia is simply an evolutionary marvel. There is no plant quite like it—a giant, fetid, parasitic, fly-pollinated flower—and this is all part of its charisma. On top of that, it has redefined what we know about plants. The chloroplast genome, the set of genes for making plants green and photosynthetic, is believed to be universal in all plants—until we couldn’t find it in Rafflesia (Molina et al. 2014) . So unusual was this that one scientific writer had to ask, “When is a plant no longer a plant?"(Pennisi 2014;Yong 2014) Of course, Rafflesia is still very much a plant. For one, it has a flower.

Indeed Rafflesia is a freak of nature. As Lady Gaga would say, “born this way”, yet beautiful in its own right.  Please help me in my scientific quest to study and save Rafflesia from extinction. Because once gone, ironically, we can no longer exhume the corpse flower.

story:
Short Summary

Short Summary

Since I can remember I've been intrigued by wildlife and the wilderness that they call home. Yet much about what I'm passionate about has been altered, changed, modified and sometimes even outright destroyed at the hand of humanity. Therefore much of my ambition and zest has been focused on restoring and recreating lost and forgotten wilderness areas - both locally and around the world. Eight years in the making, Rewilding The Lost Wilderness has been the result of my intense pursuit of restoration of the Cape of South Africa.

After much eager anticipation I can finally say that Rewilding The Lost Wilderness at 273 pages is ready to go to market with the inspirational tale of Rewilding the Cape. This story of a quintessential African wilderness that has been lost and regained is a story of hope and restoration! A tale of hope for all the wilderness areas that has been lost, and an example for all wilderness areas that is still to be regained! Rewilding The Lost Wilderness is much anticipated among the international rewilding community for whom the book will serve as a practical example for the recreation of lost wilderness areas, especially so in parts of Europe and North America.

What We Need & What You Get

We need $7,000 (seven thousand USD) to go to print and complete production. I would like to call on your help to bring Rewilding The Lost Wilderness to life with an early-bird purchase, sponsorship purchase or contribution.  See perks for Sponsorship Purchase and Contribution options!

The Impact

Help to get Rewilding The Lost Wilderness into school and national libraries and on shelves, in tourism offices to facilitate exposure to all the decision makers in conservation and rewilding circles throughout Southern Africa and among the international arena.

Time Frame

Production is expected to take place in November 2017 (given the fact that the full $7,000 is received.

Other Ways You Can Help

Please share this message as far and wide as you can among family, friends, and rewilding and conservation communities.

story:
On behalf of Ceci, Club Geoda and Federación Madrileña de Espeleología we would like to thank you all for the donations whi made possible Ceci's rescue. We have got the funds needed to cover the expenses for the rescue and we are closing down this crowfunding. Thanks again.

"Me gustaría agradecer a toda la gente que ha hecho posible que yo pudiera salir de la cueva y que ha participado de cualquier forma en el rescate. Creo que hemos dado un ejemplo de solidaridad y hemos demostrado que a un compañero nunca se le abandona.

Muchas gracias.

Ceci."

"I would like to thank to all people who made possible that I could go out of the cave and participated in any way in my rescue. I believe that we are an example of solidarity, showing that a mate is never left behind.

Thank you.

Ceci." Short Summary

THIS IS AN URGENT REQUEST FOR HELP TO RESCUE CECILIO LOPEZ-TERCERO, A SPANISH CAVER INJURED 400 METERS DEEP IN A CAVE IN PERU. 

Cecilio López-Tercero (40), belongs to the club GEODA of Madrid. He is a member of the Committee on cave-diving and was head of the Cave Rescue Group in the Madrid Federation of Caving (Federación Madrileña de Espeleología, FME). Degree in Biology from the University of Alcalá de Henares and Biochemistry from the Complutense University of Madrid, has extensive experience in campaigns caving in Spain, South America and Africa.

What We Need 

The FME, as the official association of cavers from Madrid, Spain, asks for your help to contribute with money to the rescue of Cecilio (Ceci, for his friends).

On September 18th, 2014, Ceci suffered an accident at 400 meters deep in the cave of Inti Machay, located in Huriaca (municipality Leimebamba, Department of Amazonas), a jungle area of difficult access located 1,200 kilometers from Lima (Peru). Ceci suffered a fifteen feet fall hitting badly on his back. He broke two lumbar vertebrae and he was unable to leave the cave by himself.   

More than 40 Spanish cavers have already traveled to Peru to assist Ceci in his rescue.

The FME asks for volunteers to participate in the rescue and funds to pay for it. 

    The Impact

    Ceci's life is in serious danger. He still remains in the cave ten days past the accident with his back broken. 

    The Spanish Ministry of Foreign Affairs and Cooperation has informed us that they "cannot financially support the rescue because they have no budget, and even if they had any, their protocols do not cover a case like this" (You can read this information at http://desnivel.com/expediciones/el-espeleologo-cecilio-lopez-no-podra-salir-de-la-cueva-hasta-que-no-lleguen-refuerzos) 

    ALL THESE EXPENSES HAVE TO BE FUNDED BY VOLUNTEER DONATIONS AS YOURS:

    - Transport (flights from Spain, helicopters, road transfers, etc.) 

    - Support staff (There are about 100 people involved in the rescue) 

    - Medical care (health personnel, hospital, medical transportation, etc.) 

    - Technical equipment (ropes, anchors, drills, pulleys, climbing equipment, etc.)

    Other Ways You Can Help

    You can also help us by spreading this URGENT request of funds to all of your contacts. 

    Asking the Spanish Government to assist in this rescue by signing our request here: https://www.change.org/p/gobierno-de-espa%C3%B1a-rescaten-a-cecilio-atrapado-en-una-cueva-en-per%C3%BA

    And stay informed about the rescue by the following means:

    - Official blog of the rescue (FME): http://rescateintimachay.blogspot.com.es/

    - Blog of his caving sport group (Geoda) informing about the rescue: http://rescateenperu.blogspot.com.es/

    - Facebook page of his caving sport group (Geoda) informing about the rescue: https://www.facebook.com/rescatecuevaperu

    - Facebook page of the ECA group from Peru involved in the rescue: https://www.facebook.com/EspeleoClubAndinoEcaPeru


    News about the accident

    These are some news about the rescue published so far:

    Sky news: 
    http://news.sky.com/story/1342643/race-to-free-caver-stuck-for-a-week-after-fall 

    National Post:
    http://news.nationalpost.com/2014/09/26/rescuers-work-to-save-injured-spanish-cave-explorer-whos-been-trapped-400-metres-underground-for-a-week/ 

    The Huffington Post:
    http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2014/09/26/injured-scientist-trapped-in-cave-peru_n_5890470.html 

    Fox News:
    http://latino.foxnews.com/latino/news/2014/09/26/injured-spanish-scientist-has-been-trapped-for-7-days-inside-peruvian-cave/
story_txt:
On behalf of Ceci, Club Geoda and
Federación Madrileña de Espeleología we would like to thank you
all for the donations whi made possible Ceci's rescue. We have got
the funds needed to cover the expenses for the rescue and we are
closing down this crowfunding. Thanks again. 

"Me gustaría agradecer a toda la
gente que ha hecho posible que yo pudiera salir de la cueva y que ha
participado de cualquier forma en el rescate. Creo que hemos dado un
ejemplo de solidaridad y hemos demostrado que a un compañero nunca
se le abandona. Muchas gracias.Ceci.""I
would like to thank to all people who made possible that I could go
out of the cave and participated in any way in my rescue. I believe
that we are an example of solidarity, showing that a mate is never
left behind. Thank you.Ceci."  

Short Summary THIS IS AN URGENT REQUEST FOR HELP TO RESCUE CECILIO LOPEZ-TERCERO, A SPANISH CAVER INJURED 400 METERS DEEP IN A CAVE IN PERU. 
Cecilio López-Tercero (40), belongs to the club GEODA of Madrid. He is a member of the Committee on cave-diving and was head of the Cave Rescue Group in the Madrid Federation of Caving (Federación Madrileña de Espeleología, FME). Degree in Biology from the University of Alcalá de Henares and Biochemistry from the Complutense University of Madrid, has extensive experience in campaigns caving in Spain, South America and Africa.
What We Need 
 The FME, as the official association of cavers from Madrid, Spain, asks for your help to contribute with money to the rescue of Cecilio (Ceci, for his friends).
On September 18th, 2014, Ceci suffered an accident at 400 meters deep in the cave of Inti Machay, located in Huriaca (municipality Leimebamba, Department of Amazonas), a jungle area of difficult access located 1,200 kilometers from Lima (Peru). Ceci suffered a fifteen feet fall hitting badly on his back. He broke two lumbar vertebrae and he was unable to leave the cave by himself.   
More than 40 Spanish cavers have already traveled to Peru to assist Ceci in his rescue.

The FME asks for volunteers to participate in the rescue and funds to pay for it. 

  The Impact Ceci's life is in serious danger. He still remains in the cave ten days past the accident with his back broken. 
The Spanish Ministry of Foreign Affairs and Cooperation has informed us that they "cannot financially support the rescue because they have no budget, and even if they had any, their protocols do not cover a case like this" (You can read this information at http://desnivel.com/expediciones/el-espeleologo-cecilio-lopez-no-podra-salir-de-la-cueva-hasta-que-no-lleguen-refuerzos) 

ALL THESE EXPENSES HAVE TO BE FUNDED BY VOLUNTEER DONATIONS AS YOURS:
- Transport (flights from Spain, helicopters, road transfers, etc.) 
- Support staff (There are about 100 people involved in the rescue) 
- Medical care (health personnel, hospital, medical transportation, etc.) 
- Technical equipment (ropes, anchors, drills, pulleys, climbing equipment, etc.)

Other Ways You Can Help
 You can also help us by spreading this URGENT request of funds to all of your contacts. 
Asking the Spanish Government to assist in this rescue by signing our request here: https://www.change.org/p/gobierno-de-espa%C3%B1a-rescaten-a-cecilio-atrapado-en-una-cueva-en-per%C3%BA
And stay informed about the rescue by the following means:
- Official blog of the rescue (FME): http://rescateintimachay.blogspot.com.es/
- Blog of his caving sport group (Geoda) informing about the rescue: http://rescateenperu.blogspot.com.es/
- Facebook page of his caving sport group (Geoda) informing about the rescue: https://www.facebook.com/rescatecuevaperu
- Facebook page of the ECA group from Peru involved in the rescue: https://www.facebook.com/EspeleoClubAndinoEcaPeru


News about the accidentThese are some news about the rescue published so far:Sky news: http://news.sky.com/story/1342643/race-to-free-caver-stuck-for-a-week-after-fall National Post:http://news.nationalpost.com/2014/09/26/rescuers-work-to-save-injured-spanish-cave-explorer-whos-been-trapped-400-metres-underground-for-a-week/ The Huffington Post:http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2014/09/26/injured-scientist-trapped-in-cave-peru_n_5890470.html Fox News:http://latino.foxnews.com/latino/news/2014/09/26/injured-spanish-scientist-has-been-trapped-for-7-days-inside-peruvian-cave/

story:
What we Do

We fabricate and distribute Sistema Biobolsa, a high quality modular biodigester that transforms agricultural and human waste into renewable energy and organic fertilizer to increase the productivity of small farms and reduce environmental and health challenges related to waste management.  We aim to reach hundreds of millions of small farmer worldwide through education and a directed microfinance programs.

We have brought our business to scale in central Mexico, and now we want to expand.  We will do over one million US in sales in 2012, with clients in 20 states in Mexico, Nicaragua, and Haiti.  We have over 4000 people using biogas technology in six countries, but there are over 4 million farms in Mexico alone that could utilize the technology, tens of millions of farms in Latin America and the Caribbean, and hundreds of millions in the world.   

What these Indiegogo Funds will Do

With the money raised from Indiegogo, we will install “seed” systems in new communities that will expand the reach of the technology and our market based program.  The key to creating demand and selling systems is demonstrating the technology in a local context.  That is what each $500 raised during this campaign will do: open up a new region with thousands of farmers to our technology.  Specifically, these seeds will be planted in Chiapas where they will serve as a pilot in a program that will have joint funding from the farmers, Kellogg, Heifer, and KIVA.  However, these pilots are the first step to making that program grow.  So this very small action of supporting us will have residual impacts on thousand of small farmers.     

How Else You Can Participate

As we open up new regions to Sistema Biobolsa, we need to expand our ability to provide loan funding.  This requires capital within our revolving loan fund.  We also need local partners, and we hope to develop a broad network of entrepreneurs and businesses that will offer our Sistema Biobolsa through their networks.  Grants, donations and sate funding are often very useful to plant the “seed” systems and begin the initial promotion and educational programs like the one we will run with Indiegogo funds.  We are always looking for talented people to join our team and help us grow and spread our message further.  In order to build human resources and capacity, we are interested in equity finance and standard financing options that will allow us access to capital as we increase our geographic coverage.   

More About Sistema Biobolsa

Sistema Biobolsa fills the need for an accessible yet reliable biodgester system on the market. By converting waste to resources, the benefits of biodigesters also address many pressing development challenges. Waste treatment removes organic loading and pathogen contamination of local watersheds, and drastically improves sanitary conditions, lowering enteric disease risks. Poor sanitation infrastructure has been shown to be a key limitation to development. Biogas produced by the treated waste can be used for cooking, heating, or electrical generation to lower energy costs, exposure to poor indoor air quality, and deforestation from biomass or fossil fuel sources. The resulting organic fertilizer can reduce agricultural inputs costs by 80%, making small farmers more productive and economically competitive. A transition to organic agriculture counteracts the broad degradation of agricultural lands through years of chemical fertilizer use. Local fertilizer production makes small producer less susceptible to volatile global prices of agricultural commodities.

The waste, energy, and agricultural benefits of Sistema Biobolsa also have greenhouse gas emissions impacts, and each system has been shown to reduce an average of 5 toCO2e per year, and there are 600 million small farms worldwide that could utilize this technology today.  These health, environmental, and productivity gains all have positive economic impacts. Strengthening rural economies through small farmers has residual impacts on the larger community, since declining rural productivity is a key driver of immigration and crime in the developing world. Supporting small farmers also improves food security, biodiversity, and social equity. Our comprehensive capacity building program trains large groups of installers and promoters to overcome challenges related to scaling across a wide geographic and socioeconomic space. Our financing program removes the first-cost barrier that limits the market development of many important technologies. Finally, our data management and monitoring system allows us to overcome challenges related to technological adoption, reporting and after-sales service.

The Sistema Biobolsa Team

A key strength of this project is its ability to attract talented interdisciplinary thinkers at the leadership level, as well as involve farmers, agricultural extension agents, and entrepreneurs on the ground.  Alexander Eaton is the CEO of Sistema Biobolsa, and is currently an Ashoka Fellow, an honor that acknowledges the ability of this project to create systemic change and have a global impact.  The Dutch Businesses in Development Network recognized Eaton as the Global Entrepreneur of the Year in 2010. His early work was funded as a Switzer Environmental Leadership Fellow, the Global Methane Initiative, and by working through international industrial biodigester firms. 

Our COO, Camilo Pages, has ten years of entrepreneurship, marketing, and business development in the sustainable development space, and was recognized in 2011 as one of Mexico's most innovative entrepreneurs for his role in Sistema Biobolsa.  Pages strives to integrate strong business practices and innovative marketing into his work, and pulls from a broad business network in Mexico.  Pages also comes from an industrial family, and his early business development was in fabrication and distribution in the automotive industry.   

Eleazar Ortiz worked in Mexican educational development for eight years before he completed a Masters Degree in Public Policy from the NYU Wagner school.   Ortiz now works on collaborative development strategies that allows for the integration of stakeholders into the Sistema Biobolsa program.

Our CFO Jorge Arellano has over 40 years of experience in finance, and manages our finance fund, and economic growth strategies. Arellano has worked for a long list of multi-national companies, and is experienced in international accounting standards and how to manage the finances of international distribution and sales.

Juan Gonzalez moved to our fabrication plant after 30 years of running industrial processes and fabrication in the automotive industry.  His specialty is process management and quality control, and he manages a strong team of engineers and fabrication workers at our production plant in Toluca, Mexico.  Humza Arshad is a talented young technological expert that has helped develop and implement a world-class data management system that serves as our scalable organizational platform.

On the ground in 18 Mexican states and three LAC countries we have thousands of trained technicians, farmers, and small business owners that now promote Sistema Biobolsa in their own region.  We have a strong network of research partners, NGOs, and international participants that add capacity, lessons, learned and oversight of our work. 

Finally, our board of directors in made up of successful businessmen that have a talent for scaling, and a network of professionals that provide constant consultation and education for the core team.  The combination of this wide variety of skills, contacts, and passion has created a top-notch team that is wired for innovation and set on scaling this big idea.  

 

This campaign was designed for the SOCAP conference community for it's annual gathering on October 1-4th.  A group of 100 entrepreneurs selected 5 entrepreneurs to showcase their work through a small crowdfunding campaign on Indiegogo. The entrepreneurs were given 2 hours to develop their campaign page. The campaign will run for 1 week to an audience of 1500 global social innovators at SOCAP.  SOCAP attendees were given a wooden token representative of $5 that they will choose to designate towards 1 of the 5 project, in total worth $10,000.  Additionally, attendees are encouraged to further contribute both financially and otherwise. Though the entrepreneurs have financial goals far exceeding the small amount they will raise through the campaign, this exercise is a symbol of how crowd and community support towards inspiring and innovative individuals can leverage great resources to change the world."

story:
"I was standing at the door, praying to God to keep our family safe as the winds were just starting to get really bad, worse than I had ever known before, when I saw our neighbour's roof was gone suddenly. It was ripped up into the air, and obliterated in seconds. Lavinia, and her six year old nephew Sosifa came running for their lives to the shelter of our home, as I watched their house literally being blown away behind them. It was terrifiying. I can't believe that a moment ago their home was there, and the next - just splinters of wood remained.

At that moment the storm became even stronger, and another hour later, it was unbearable. The wind, rain and sea spray were screaming through our home. Sione, my brother, shouted that our roof was damaged, and at that moment it was ripped from everywhere except the room we were sheltering in. I shouted to my Mum that we must do something to save Grandma, and my poor Mum said 'We must leave everything to God now Sia, we got no place to run to. It's too dangerous'. I thought at that moment. We are all going to die."

The storm lashed the island group relentlessly for over six hours, flattening over 80% of the homes in some villages. 

Right now, there are over 2000 people with no shelter. Food is limited as the crops were destroyed during the cyclone. There's no clean drinking water, no power, and no sanitation. 

It is total devastation.

Furthermore, there are serious concerns about the spread of water-borne illnesses as the water towers and guttering on homes has been destroyed, and existing drinking water sources are contaminated.

There are charities working in Tonga right now, with donations coming in from International aid - but their priority is to restore the power, provide clean water and re-establish sanitation. They're also offering temporary shelter to the people displaced from their homes, in evacuation centres or tented communities.  

But that's just it. The shelter is only temporary. 

In an already economically poor country, the people of Ha'apai simply don't have the resources to be able to rebuild their homes. It could be months and months before the charities are able to offer their help in rebuilding homes, if at all, so we are pleading for any help you may be able to offer.

Your donation of any amount, big or small, will not only be very gratefully received - we also pledge to keep you updated each and every step of the way, so that you can see what a huge difference your support has made in the difficult journey ahead.

Thank you for your kindness and generosity.

As they say in the Kingdom of Tonga... 

'Ofa lahi atu (Love to you)

story:
Sharing food sovereignty stories

I am hoping to participate in the UK food sovereignty gathering which will take place in October in England. I set up my agroecological and biodiverse farm more than 25 years ago. I want to go to England in October to:

  • Share my experience of defending seeds and ancestral foods. 
  • Get to know the UK food sovereignty movement and to share experiences and skills to help build the Colombian food sovereignty movement. 
  • Improve my English so that I can help strengthen existing movements in England and Colombia and to help with all of the international volunteers I host on my farm through woofing.

Who am I?

I’m a Colombian woman, daughter of farmers. I grew up in the countryside in a family where there was there was always food. Sadly because of the development of monocrop plantations and industrial agriculture, food has stopped being the priority. The excessive and irresponsible use of pesticides which affect health and the environment is one of the reasons I set up my project more than 25 years ago. I decided to live in the countryside and promote ecological agriculture and the recovery of forgotten foods and ancestral knowledge (medicinal, magical, foraged and decorative plants)

The main focus of my project is education and training through working with schools, farmers, groups of women, students, volunteers and visitors. The educational tours I organize through ecotourism, under the banner of ‘learning through recreation’, raise visitors’ awareness about the importance of protecting the environment.

The ‘Albergue Azul’ is an an agroecological and biodiverse farm which is a life project we are building as a family. 

The food sovereignty gathering I want to take part in in England will strengthen my knowledge and allow me to learn about what is happening in other countries about food sovereignty. I would like to then share this learning in Colombia.

You can find out more about my farm here: http://albergueazul.weebly.com/

If you think this project is interesting and important, I would be really grateful of your support.

Quiero participar en “food sovereignty gathering 2015” que tendrá lugar entre el 23 y 26 de octubre, esto con el objetivo de conocer los movimientos en otros países y compartir mis experiencias de trabajo en mi granja agroecológica y biodiversa realizado por más de 25 años.

Mis metas son las siguientes:

- Compartir mis experiencias de agroecología, resistencia por la defensa de las semillas y alimentos ancestrales.

- Fortalecer el movimiento por la soberanía alimentaria en Colombia y América Latina.

- Crear enlaces entre movimientos existentes en Inglaterra y en Colombia- aprender inglés para mejorar comunicación con voluntarios internacionales (wwofing) que recibo en mi granja.

¿Quién soy?

Soy una mujer, hija de campesinos. Crecí en el campo en una familia donde había abastecimiento de alimentos. Tristemente por el desarrollo de los monocultivos y la producción industrial, los alimentos han pasado a un segundo plano. El uso excesivo e irresponsable de agro-tóxicos que afectan la salud y el medio ambiente, son unas de las causas que me impulsaron a empezar este proyecto hace más de 25 años. Así, decidí vivir en el campo para promover la agricultura ecológica, la recuperación de alimentos olvidados y de saberes ancestrales (plantas medicinales, mágicas, forrajeras y artesanales). 

Los puntos principales de mi proyecto son la educación (trabajo con escuelas), la protección de especies y la formación (talleres con campesinos, grupos de mujeres, estudiantes, voluntarios y visitantes). Las guianzas educativas por medio del ecoturismo, bajo el lema "recrearse aprendiendo", permiten concientizar al visitante sobre la importancia de la protección y conservación del medio ambiente.

El Albergue Azul, una granja agroecológica y biodiversa, es un proyecto de vida que estamos construyendo en familia :


La conservación y protección de la biodiversidad es otro de nuestros objetivos al igual que el intercambio de saberes con campesinos, escuelas, colegios, universidades y visitantes en general. El encuentro que quiero participar “food sovereignty gathering 2015” fortalesería y permitiría conocer lo que se esta haciendo en otros paises relacionado con el tema de la soberanía alimentaria. A corto plazo, podria divulgar algunas de esas practicas en mi pais, Colombia.

Si desean conocer mas de mi proyecto, los invito a visitar la pagina Internet del Albergue Azul :

http://albergueazul.weebly.com/index.html

Si esta iniciativa les parece interesante y ademas importante, les agradecería inmensamente su apoyo.

You can find out more about my farm here: http://albergueazul.weebly.com/
If you think this project is interesting and important, I would be really grateful of your support. Quiero participar en  “food sovereignty gathering 2015” que tendrá 
lugar entre el 23 y 26 de octubre, esto con el objetivo de conocer los 
movimientos en otros países y compartir mis experiencias de trabajo en 
mi granja agroecológica y biodiversa realizado por más de 25 años.Mis metas son las siguientes:- Compartir mis experiencias de agroecología, resistencia por la defensa de las semillas y alimentos ancestrales. - Fortalecer el movimiento por la soberanía alimentaria en Colombia y América Latina. 
- Crear enlaces entre movimientos existentes en Inglaterra y
en Colombia-
aprender inglés para mejorar comunicación con voluntarios internacionales
(wwofing) que recibo en mi granja.¿Quién soy?Soy una mujer, hija de campesinos. Crecí en el campo en una familia donde había abastecimiento de alimentos. Tristemente por el desarrollo de los monocultivos y la producción industrial, los alimentos han pasado a un segundo plano. El uso excesivo e irresponsable de agro-tóxicos que afectan la salud y el medio ambiente, son unas de las causas que me impulsaron a empezar este proyecto hace más de 25 años. Así, decidí vivir en el campo para promover la agricultura ecológica, la recuperación de alimentos olvidados y de saberes ancestrales (plantas medicinales, mágicas, forrajeras y artesanales). Los puntos principales de mi proyecto son la educación (trabajo con escuelas), la protección de especies y la formación (talleres con campesinos, grupos de mujeres, estudiantes, voluntarios y visitantes). Las guianzas educativas por medio del ecoturismo, bajo el lema "recrearse aprendiendo", permiten concientizar al visitante sobre la importancia de la protección y conservación del medio ambiente.El Albergue Azul, una granja agroecológica y biodiversa, es un proyecto de vida que estamos construyendo en familia :La conservación y protección de la biodiversidad es otro de nuestros objetivos al igual que el intercambio de saberes con campesinos, escuelas, colegios, universidades y visitantes en general. El encuentro que quiero participar “food sovereignty gathering 2015” fortalesería y permitiría conocer lo que se esta haciendo en otros paises relacionado con el tema de la soberanía alimentaria. A corto plazo, podria divulgar algunas de esas practicas en mi pais, Colombia.Si desean conocer mas de mi proyecto, los invito a visitar la pagina Internet del Albergue Azul :http://albergueazul.weebly.com/index.htmlSi esta iniciativa les parece interesante y ademas importante, les agradecería inmensamente su apoyo.

story:
Our Volunteers Have Heart and Dedication 

Whale Scout volunteers help hundreds of people watch whales every year - many for the first time!  Each individual volunteer goes beyond their interest in whales by taking action, becoming leaders in their community promoting change. Much of this work is difficult and done in cold and wet weather. Whale Scouts are so passionate about whales that they plant trees in the rain, push heavy wheelbarrows full of mulch uphill, literally bleed as they remove invasive blackberries from native plants, and wear special gloves to keep their freezing fingers steady on their binoculars and ready to text their sightings. The rain is our liquid sunshine! 

Our efforts are expanding rapidly. In the next year we will:

  • Plant 500 trees
  • Assist 1,000 people to watch whales 
  • Engage 300 school kids in learning about whales 
  • Give 800 hours of service restoring salmon habitat
  • Much more! 

We Want To Do Even More 

We are raising funds to keep this team moving forward protecting Pacific Northwest whales at a time when the stakes are higher than ever. Our volunteers deserve to have better materials and tools to make the biggest impact for the whales as possible. We also want to invest in their education, provide well-coordinated volunteer opportunities to engage and inspire the public, and help offset some of their personal out-of-pocket expenses such as ferry tickets. Next year our grant support from Fish and Wildlife will run out. We can't do this without your support. Raising $5,000 in this campaign will help volunteers in many ways:

  • Give the approximately 20 new volunteers naturalist materials including our weather-proof diagrams, charts, and maps made specifically for Whale Scouts to share with the public
  • Print mini brochures with info about whales and our Helpin' Out events
  • Offer a dedicated volunteer leader on San Juan Island 
  • Start a book club to continue education for volunteers and engage the public 
  • Revitalize the Whale Scout Podcast 
  • Host scientists, communication experts, and other naturalists at volunteer trainings to educate volunteers on the latest research
  • Partner with organizations to develop coordinated orca stewardship materials
  • Host special events such as the Black Friday's #Optoutside or Earth Day, where volunteers can engage the public on non-whale days in a coordinated fashion
  • Continue to provide volunteers with the most recent version of the Center for Whale Research's Orca ID Guide 
  • Offer ferry ticket reimbursement for volunteer activities 

The Impact

Your contribution matters. Please help empower this group of volunteers to save whales by restoring their prey's habitat and inspire others to do the same. Ensuring our local endangered orcas have enough salmon to eat is the single most important thing we can do to save them. Many of them are suffering from starvation. Restoring salmon streams has great potential to feed orcas and can be done right in our own backyards.  

  • The Southern Resident killer whale community is unique in that they swim through waters in urban areas allowing researchers to track them individually throughout their lives, and offering many people the opportunity to view them in the wild. Whales such as Mike, Blackberry, and Granny are famous and known around the world. They are a treasure of the Pacific Northwest and are in peril. These whales are worth saving. Imagine the joy you might see on your child's face in the future as you watch whales thrive in the waters of Seattle or Victoria. 
  • Whale Scout has a proven track record. Our volunteer team was born three years ago and has grown steadily since then. We've been awarded grants in the past and have successfully worked with other groups to leverage our resources. We are firmly rooted in this effort and will not let up until Pacific Northwest whales are protected. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean you can't help:

  • Spread the word about this campaign on social media or with a fellow animal-lover. 
  • Consider a holiday gift for someone special. We even have certificates to honor a donation made in someone else's name. Check out our perks for donating!

Straight from Volunteer Experience

"I did not find the whales, they found me. A wonderful woman whom I admire and look up to lent me a book on the orca and said I really should read it.  I smiled and nodded, politely took the book she handed me and said "Thank you," but on the inside I was already grumbling to myself that now I HAD to read it because when I return it in a few weeks, she's going to ask how I enjoyed it. Begrudgingly one weekend I sat down to read it and was immediately immersed in the world of the Southern Resident killer whale population and their fantastically complicated social structure.  Families stay together all their lives? They babysit other calves? They have greeting ceremonies after they've been apart for some time? Wow, wow, and WOW!

Jump ahead in time a few years and now I love standing on a beach helping others spot the whales while hopefully providing them new information about the whales that they didn't already know. Yes, they are endangered. No, they are not getting enough food, but here's a list of some things you can do to help. Yes, you are only one person, but, there's a whole village full of you. 

There's a certain look that some people get in their eyes when I know they are feeling the same way I did reading that book. I'm just one person too, but there are so many whale advocates out there, I have to believe that this village of advocates we are building can make a difference for these icons of the Salish Sea."

story:
“Making the world work for 100% of humanity in the shortest possible time through spontaneous cooperation without ecological damage or disadvantage to anyone.” - Buckminster Fuller’s Mission

Marshall McLuhan said Buckminster Fuller was “the 20th Century Leonardo da Vinci.”  Because of his wisdom and years (if not lifetimes) of experience, he was also known as “Grandfather of the Future” and the “Grandfather of the Universe.”   Check out the Bio Video above (when in 1982 he said "if within five years we haven't learned to take care of everybody, it's all over for everybody")  for more details.

Fuller (who preferred that everyone call him “Bucky”) labeled himself a “comprehensive anticipatory design scientist,” focused on solving problems he believed would appear 50 to 100 years in the future.  Just prior to his death in 1983, he said that he felt humankind had about eight years to solve our major global problems including environmental degradation, hunger, homelessness, lack of available education and health care for all.  Clearly, we have not met his goal, but we’re still trying to create his vision of  “a world that works for everyone.”

“It is not for me to change you. The question is, how can I be of service to you without diminishing your degrees of freedom?” - Bucky Fuller

This is why his ideas, solutions and vision are more important than ever.  This campaign will help keep Bucky’s unique perspective alive, vibrant and public.  I have been studying Bucky’s vision and applying his ideas to my life since he died.  I have also been writing and speaking about his solutions, and I am the only person who has had two books about Bucky published by reputable publishers.  There are several more Bucky books in the pipeline, and this project will help move them along at a much faster pace.

In the past few years, I’ve applied the latest digital technology to share Bucky’s vision.  You can check out my

  • Huffington Post blog
  • A Fuller View Facebook Page
  • Buckminster Fuller Facebook Page
  • Buckminster Fuller Facebook Group
  • Global Citizens Facebook Group
  • Examiner.com articles
  • Twitter feed
  • Website

Although each of these venues is unique, the message is always consistent … we have the ability to survive and thrive as a species if we shift our focus and resources from weaponry to livingry.  We can also use Bucky’s life as a proven template for each of us making a difference as global citizens on board the planet he named Spaceship Earth.

Your financial support will allow me to expand the amount and diversity of writing and graphics I can produce and disperse.  It will also provide the impetus to complete and publish Volume 2 of the series that began with A Fuller View.  That book is entitled A Fuller Way, Buckminster Fuller’s Life Affirming Path To Success, and it is more than half completed.  Like A Fuller View, it will have many Guest Commentators, but the presentation will be identical to AFV.  There are many important people who have something to say about Bucky and his wisdom, and some of these potential Guest Commentators are getting on in years, so it’s critical to gather their wisdom as soon as possible.

Bucky often taught that if a person wants to make a difference with their lives they need only look around and see what needs to be done that is not being attended to and do that.  Thirty plus years ago, I saw that nobody was keeping the legacy of Bucky’s life and contribution alive. 

I’m not talking about his unique synergetic mathematics, geodesic domes, structures or other scientific and technical legacy.  I’m interested in a man who figured out how to ...

 

 

  • make a difference with his life and demonstrated what one person can achieve that cannot be accomplished by any government, corporation, religion or institution no matter how large or powerful.
  • solve all humankind’s physical problems with one simple change … from weaponry to livingry.
  • work on behalf of all life on Spaceship Earth and leave a legacy template of a life devoted to service.
  • alter the course of human evolution using Trimtab and other of Nature’s Generalized Principles.
  • do this and more while maintaining his vow not to work for a living.

 

In other words, I’m not interested in “your father’s Buckminster Fuller.”  This project is championing the vision and solutions of a philosopher, poet and revolutionary who figured out how to turn his discoveries and ideas into practical solutions that are needed more now than ever before.

And, I’m willing to provide you with some perks that will help you to more fully understand why I have devoted more than half of my life to bringing this vision before the public.

Thank you in advance for your generous support.  As Bucky often said,

“There is no use talking about bright ideas.  Everyone has bright ideas.  There is no use talking about an artifact until we reduce it to practice, until we see whether Nature permits it, whether society permits it.”

I’m putting this idea out to you as the artifact of this campaign to make a genuine difference with a very small effort.  Now, we get to see if Nature and society permits (supports) it.  Any support you can offer (including sharing this with your friends, family and networks) is greatly appreciated.

Feel free to contact me at ssieden@gmail.com if you have questions or are looking for an expert to speak about Bucky and his wisdom.

THE PLAN (for those who like details)

Here’s the priority Bucky items / artifacts on my plate.  They all focus around carrying Bucky’s message to the world in as comprehensive a manner as possible.

Live.  I am continually invited to speak and participate at events focused on consciousness, ecology and all the other topics that Bucky addresses.  Many of these events are for young people and / or have no budget.  Your support will provide the means for making more of these presentations, especially in schools. 

Digital.  My talks could easily be recorded and posted online.  I’m also looking at recording a series of Bucky Fuller interviews with various experts, especially the people in my book A Fuller View and the new book A Fuller Way.

I have some unique Bucky video that I have used in live presentations.  They give participants a vision of Bucky “live,” and then we can deconstruct and examine what he has said.  It’s a very eye opening process for many people, but it would be better if the recordings were edited and enhanced with music.

Social Media.  I am currently very active spreading Bucky’s message on Facebook, Huffington Post, Twitter, Linked In and other venues.  I could be more active if I had the time and resources.

A Fuller Way.  I would like to move this next book forward more rapidly.  I’d like to see it published in 2013, the 30 anniversary of his physical death.  Again, this requires time and resources.

Now is the time, and we are the people.  If you are so moved, please act NOW.

Chick here if you want to hear how John Denver felt about Bucky.  This is a video of John singing "What One Man Can Do" a song he wrote for and about Bucky Fuller.

story:
Hello and Chi Miigwech (Thankyou very Much!) for your interest and support!

We need to raise 8000 so that our government will match us with 50000 in funding for this project! We need your help!

The idea...

This project titled “Rural Economic Development Through Restorative Environmental Engagement  (RED TREE) starts by researching and planning the ability of using Analog Forestry on farmland to support the development of a self sustaining environmental economic system in rural areas of Southern Bruce County. This will help feed people, and sustainably grow many items that people can use to sustain their livelihoods. It will help to restore ecosystems and create areas for wildlife to thrive. Best of all, this work will help to connect people physically with the natural world, teaching people to understand how ecosystems work, and how we benefit from them by using things that come from them This research and planning is the first step in lay the groundwork making this idea a reality!

On the Ground:

What this technique looks like on the ground is farmland or open spaces converted into perennial agriculture plots containing  native plants that can be used as non-timber forest products (NTFP’s), such as medicines, crafts, foods, syrups, etc. “Analog Forestry” (AF), uses a variety of native plants that are grown specifically for their harvesting potentials as non-timber forest products. Because there are many plants grown, sustainable harvesting can take place within this strong and resilient ecosystem. This does take time, but it takes pressure off lands while still sustainably growing foods and other important resources.

The Impact?

Lots!! This idea has the ability to solve many problems with both food shortage issues, and lack of employment in the environmental field. This technique Analog forestry, will be investigated in its ability to compete with conventional agricultural practices through researching and planning for social, environmental, and economic resiliency of its product or services. This has worldwide impacts, and has been applied in many countries outside NA where growth patterns are faster, as well as in our backyards, where people can be growing food, medicinal, etc s for themselves. 

The non-timber forest products recommended through the research of this project will create a source of unique niche products to be sustainably grown on site, then processed, and sold. Thus, this research will allow the framework for a thriving self sustaining economic system to be planned for the next step of this project, planting, educating, growing and harvesting!.

This creates avenues for some Very exciting work that is beginning to be talked about, such as ways to offset carbon by 'sinking' dollars into community based projects that have a REAL environmental impact, such as this project. We want to forge the platform for having ecological services and functions recognized 

Our Future Site for this Program!

Saugeen First Nation is a first nation community next to Southampton Ontario. Members of this communty crossed my path 2 months ago when they began speaking of their interest in becoming a self sustaining community that is able to feed itself. Their cultural context makes for a wonderful chance to work with traditional techniques of listening and respecting the forest, and learning the stories that are behind products from nature. They would like to provide good work for people in their community and with the partners of this project, we will have the ability to bring much knowledge and experience together to create a lively and robust self sustaining community that is producing items made with respect and honor, courage and wisdom, love and truth. and an honest commitment to the world around us.  

Why we need your Support!

 We want to find some dollars to pay for the planning and research, a VERY important part!

Your dollars will help with a very unique form of research that will be engaging the entire community: 

-community gatherings, sampling wild edibles, to make community members aware of what is out there to be grown and harvested

-researching the needs of different types of plants so that we can plan some of the most beautiful and healthy planted plots possible

-visits to events that deal with non-timber forest products

-inviting specialists and educators to come into the community to help guide discussions and answer questions about how we can make this all happen

-using GIS (geographic information system) to plan for managing the resources from different areas, to help with planning by using maps, and to communicate to people the value of the services that plants provide 

-planning for the creation of a unique foundation under which we can run this program, grow these fields of young forests, manage, process, and harvest the products from these forests, and educate those involved.

For your Support, we will happily send to you unique examples of non timber forest products made by the participants of this program. these craft items, a card or a token, are small, however are the first versions of what we can make in the future of this program! You will then be holding a unique piece of history!

Other Ways you can help!

 

Get the word out that this work is going on, RIGHT HERE, in Ontario Canada, in a small rural community with a LOT of heart and interest in bringing nature back to life!

Any knowledge about the benefits of plants, GIS modelling, wildcrafting, ecological functions or services, socially responsible investing or environmental economics, first nation cultures, or anything related to what was described above, we'd LOVE to hear from you and involve you in any way!

Thankyou for your GENEROUS SUPPORT!!

This will help feed people, and sustainably grow many items that people can use to sustain their livelihoods. It will help to restore ecosystems and create areas for wildlife to thrive. Best of all, this work will help to connect people physically with the natural world, teaching people to understand how ecosystems work, and how we benefit from them by using things that come from them This research and planning is the first step in lay the groundwork making this idea a reality! On the Ground: What this technique looks like on the ground is farmland or open spaces converted into perennial agriculture plots containing  native plants that can be used as non-timber forest products (NTFP’s), such as medicines, crafts, foods, syrups, etc. “Analog Forestry” (AF), uses a variety of native plants that are grown specifically for their harvesting potentials as non-timber forest products. Because there are many plants grown, sustainable harvesting can take place within this strong and resilient ecosystem. This does take time, but it takes pressure off lands while still sustainably growing foods and other important resources. The Impact? Lots!! This idea has the ability to solve many problems with both food shortage issues, and lack of employment in the environmental field. This technique Analog forestry, will be investigated in its ability to compete with conventional agricultural practices through researching and planning for social, environmental, and economic resiliency of its product or services. This has worldwide impacts, and has been applied in many countries outside NA where growth patterns are faster, as well as in our backyards, where people can be growing food, medicinal, etc s for themselves. The non-timber forest products recommended through the research of this project will create a source of unique niche products to be sustainably grown on site, then processed, and sold. Thus, this research will allow the framework for a thriving self sustaining economic system to be planned for the next step of this project, planting, educating, growing and harvesting!.This creates avenues for some Very exciting work that is beginning to be talked about, such as ways to offset carbon by 'sinking' dollars into community based projects that have a REAL environmental impact, such as this project. We want to forge the platform for having ecological services and functions recognized Our Future Site for this Program!Saugeen First Nation is a first nation community next to Southampton Ontario. Members of this communty crossed my path 2 months ago when they began speaking of their interest in becoming a self sustaining community that is able to feed itself. Their cultural context makes for a wonderful chance to work with traditional techniques of listening and respecting the forest, and learning the stories that are behind products from nature. They would like to provide good work for people in their community and with the partners of this project, we will have the ability to bring much knowledge and experience together to create a lively and robust self sustaining community that is producing items made with respect and honor, courage and wisdom, love and truth. and an honest commitment to the world around us.  Why we need your Support! We want to find some dollars to pay for the planning and research, a VERY important part!Your dollars will help with a very unique form of research that will be engaging the entire community: -community gatherings, sampling wild edibles, to make community members aware of what is out there to be grown and harvested-researching the needs of different types of plants so that we can plan some of the most beautiful and healthy planted plots possible-visits to events that deal with non-timber forest products-inviting specialists and educators to come into the community to help guide discussions and answer questions about how we can make this all happen-using GIS (geographic information system) to plan for managing the resources from different areas, to help with planning by using maps, and to communicate to people the value of the services that plants provide -planning for the creation of a unique foundation under which we can run this program, grow these fields of young forests, manage, process, and harvest the products from these forests, and educate those involved.For your Support, we will happily send to you unique examples of non timber forest products made by the participants of this program. these craft items, a card or a token, are small, however are the first versions of what we can make in the future of this program! You will then be holding a unique piece of history!Other Ways you can help! Get the word out that this work is going on, RIGHT HERE, in Ontario Canada, in a small rural community with a LOT of heart and interest in bringing nature back to life!Any knowledge about the benefits of plants, GIS modelling, wildcrafting, ecological functions or services, socially responsible investing or environmental economics, first nation cultures, or anything related to what was described above, we'd LOVE to hear from you and involve you in any way! Thankyou for your GENEROUS SUPPORT!!

story:
It’s time to connect the dots about climate change. After being devastated by Tropical Storm Irene, we realize the terrible amount that is at stake.

World leaders will be meeting this June for the second UN Earth Summit taking place in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil, to reconvene on an international path towards sustainability. This is an incredible event as the previous and also initial summit was held back in 1992 and concluded with the recognition of the globe’s major areas of environmental concern. This was also during a time when climate change and global warming were still mere whispers.

A few Vermont citizens, with the support of 350VT, are organizing to send a peoples’ delegation to Rio. We urge Vermont to make itself visible at the people's assemblies. A warming world, furthered climate change, means more disastrous floods and storms here in Vermont, like we saw with Tropical Storm Irene. Now that our state has tasted the first bitter mouthful of global warming, we feel called to speak up and push the whole planet to take stronger action for a livable future. We believe our voices matter, and we’re willing to use them.

OUR MISSION

  • To give passage to Vermont stories and the "Vermont Strong" spirit to the Earth Summit in Rio De Janeiro, Brazil.
  • To stand shoulder-to-shoulder with Island Nations and other countries on the frontlines of the climate crisis.  
  • To ignite Vermont’s media attention and give visibility to the state’s distress.
  • To seize this opportunity as one to bond and embolden Vermont’s climate justice community.
  • To report back and work to make connections between global issues and local problems.

HOPES & NEEDS

We need your help to raise the money for airfare! Each ticket is about $1200. We hope to send 4 or 5 delegates from around the state. All Vermonters are welcomed to join! It is unfortunate that finances has to be a limiting factor.

If we don’t end up meeting our goal, the money will go towards supporting as many delegates as are able to supplement the travel costs.

We will also be hosting events in the Greater Burlington area to create awareness, gather stories, and encourage dialogue surrounding local solutions to global issues.

EMPTY POCKETS?

Some people just can’t contribute, that’s okay! You can help by sharing our cause.

  • Ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about our campaign.
  • Like us and post the campaign site to your Facebook wall!
  • Share your story! Fill us in on...
    • What’s an issue you feel should be addressed at the Earth Summit?
    • Why do you support the fight for climate justice?
    • How you may have been affected by climate change?
    • How do you engage in dialogues on systemic issues? What are your local solutions?

And that’s all there is to it.

story:
Help us provide education and outreach so that we can keep this vital freshwater source healthy for generations to come.

The California Delta is a primary freshwater source for California. Millions of humans, fish, wildlife, plants, and local economies could not flourish without it. Unfortunatley, according to a survey in 2012, 78% of Californians said they did not know what the Bay Delta was. In Southern California, 86% said they never even heard of the Delta.

But this is where the majority of water battles haven taken place for years. 

The SF-Bay Delta is under threat: Two large tunnels will divert water to benefit corporate agribusiness and the fracking industry, while destroying the largest and most magnificent estuary on the West Coast of the Americas and our vibrant economy. 

That is why we need to provide outreach and education to our Bay Area public now. The people need to know and voice their opposition against these massive tunnels. Living in a state where drought is experienced 1/3 of the time AND where climate change impacts are becoming more apparent, we cannot take our Delta water for granted. 

What tunnels?

The State of California is planning to build 2 giant tunnels, each 40 feet in diameter, 150 feet underneath the Sacramento-San Joaquin Delta. The tunnels would run about 30 miles, from just south of Sacramento to just north of Tracy. This is deceptively called  the "Bay Delta Conservation Plan" (BDCP).

What for?

The tunnels could carry up to 2/3 of the flow of the Sacramento River.  This is the main supply of fresh water in the Delta which flows into the SF Bay.  Right now, only about 30% of water exported from the Delta goes to cities in the Bay Area, the South Coast, and Southern California.  Corporate agribusinesses on the west side of the San Joaquin Valley, down to Bakersfield, get about 70% of the water, yet only contribute .3% to the state's economy.

What’s wrong with this plan?

Diverting all this fresh water will result in saltier, polluted water in the Delta and the Bay Area. This will affect farmers as well as commercial and recreational fishermen.  It will also affect cities in the Delta region by impacting their municipal water and discharge systems, and the environment of the whole Bay-Delta Estuary.

If you live in an area that relies on export water, your water rates will go up. As of now, the estimated cost is over $60 BILLION making it one of the largest and most expensive public work projects in U.S. history with no guarantee that it will provide more reliable water supply for Californians. If you are a California taxpayer, you will help pay for this project through water bonds.  

The sentiment against the peripheral tunnels when Californians voted against the canals 30 years ago echoes to this day. However, the battle against corporate takeover of a public trust resource is far from over. They have effectively circumvented the democratic process to keep us in the dark. To make matters worse, there is no vote on this issue. The state is allowing 120 days (as of Dec. 9, 2013) of public review of the Environmental Impact Report (40,000 pages long) for the tunnels project. 

What We Need & What You Get


(Watch above video of one of our projects in outreach and education with students from San Francisco and Stockton)

We are asking a minimum of $5000 for outreach in the Bay Area to educate and inform Californians why we must take action. Your contributions will go to:

  • Free screenings of our critically-acclaimed documentary, "Over Troubled Waters."
  • Presentations in different cities in California.
  • Statewide rallies.
  • Debates, events, and more!
  • Materials and information which are distributed free of cost.

Our perks include bumper stickers, window signs, yard signs, and more!

About Us

We've Stopped the Canals, Now We Will Stop the Tunnels.

Restore the Delta is a nonprofit organization that is in the final stages of being approved as a 501(c)(3) entity. YOUR DONATION IS TAX DEDUCTIBLE (we will send you the number after the campaign is over). We believe that Delta stakeholders deserve an equal say in decisions regarding the management of water exports, the protection of species and habitat, and the revitalization and sustainability of the Sacramento-San Joaquin Delta environment and economy for future generations. We are the leading organization fighting against the tunnels and are part of a large coalition fighting the BDCP. We have created a critically-acclaimed documentary and have received the Full Circle Fund grant in partnership with National Geographic to host a Photo Camp, a 4-day workshop for students in San Francisco and Stockton to document their connection to the Bay and Delta.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute, you can still help! We need as many people as possible to be informed and actively challenging the Tunnels Project. You may:

  • Follow this link to write to the governor and tell him it's a bad idea.
  • Sign up to our newsletter to stay in the loop!  
  • Follow us on Facebook, Twitter and/or Instagram.
  • Organize a screening of our documentary in your community or
  • Volunteer for us at events (email: javier@restorethedelta.org )
  • Visit the following websites: www.stopthetunnels.org & www.restorethedelta.org
  • Share this campaign!

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute, you can still help! We need as many people as possible to be informed and actively challenging the Tunnels Project. You may:

Follow this link to write to the governor and tell him it's a bad idea.

Visit the following websites: www.stopthetunnels.org & www.restorethedelta.org

Share this campaign!

story:
Short Summary

My name is Eva and I am an opera singer, actor, dancer, choreographer and environmental activist. I have grown up around very passionate people who want to make a difference in people's lives. This is our dream and we are making it a reality:

Our dream is to create an off-grid and heritage farming learning center based in the Shuswap. This facility's purpose is to demonstrate and put into practice multiple sustainable initiatives in order to strengthen and educate communities. By promoting lost heritage techniques in addition to newer,
emerging methods, we have a chance to lessen our impact on our planet while
reconnecting with the very roots of our humanity.

This is a very large and expensive project with many components, including
permaculture food forests, market gardens, alternative building projects,
traditional dairy production, heritage wool processes, and traditional
culinary classes as well as many others.But today we are trying to
fundraise for just one part of the dream: an underground greenhouse.

 After doing much research on reliable growing techniques, my dad discovered a plan for a partially underground greenhouse that uses geothermal heat to heat the plants within it. The greenhouse is 12 feet tall, 5 of which is
underground. Pipes that transport the natural heat from within the earth up to
the greenhouse are dug 8 feet into the ground. Fans are used to transfer this
air into the greenhouse, keeping the temperature in the greenhouse hot
enough to grow citrus and a variety of tropical fruit… all the time!

More info can be found at this link:

http://www.offgridchick.com/2014/03/30/going-underground/



What We Need

Approximate cost for materials:

Dome = $10,000

Piping/motors = $2,000

Fruit trees and other plants = Upwards of $1,000

Labour/machinery rental= Upwards of $3,000


Approximate
Total = $20,000

We are hoping to raise half of that total!


The Impact

- We can grow various tropical fruits and veggies all year round! We will be updating everyone on our progress throughout the building process.

-Educating our communities about alternative and sustainable food production
methods in a time when food security is a necessity. We would be
offering consultations and/or demonstrations after the completion of the
project to teach others how to benefit from this innovation.

-Decreasing footprint and reliance on fruit and vegetable products that
are not grown in our own climate.

Other Ways You Can Help

-Spread the word!

-Come visit us and help us
     complete these projects!

-Donate!

story:
Reducing Global Warming through Capturing Airborne Carbon Dioxide. Replenishing Soil for Life.

There are many contributing factors to the Global Warming crisis facing our planet and equally as many consequences. Some have gained more public awareness than others. Soil Sequestration is an important part of solving this and other issues facing future generations such as food security and food quality. Soil Sequestration is a method of capturing Co2 in the air and returning it back to the Soil for long term plant sustainability and the survival of all living things.

Carbon Dioxide Storage in Soil

The growing concern of too much Carbon Dioxide in our atmosphere is a world-wide problem. We know that Co2 stored in soil is released through felling of native forests and over farming and tilling of agricultural land.

It is estimated that soils contain between 700 gigatonnes (Gt, 109 tonnes) and 3000 Gt of carbon, or more than three times the amount of carbon stored in the atmosphere as carbon dioxide. However, most agricultural soils have lost 50–70 per cent of the original soil organic carbon pool that was present in the natural ecosystem prior to clearing and cultivation. When forests are converted to agricultural land, the soil carbon content decreases dramatically and needs to be managed well. This depletion happens because organic matter in the soil decomposes following ground disturbance while, at the same time, less carbon enters the soil because the clearance has reduced the biomass above ground as well. Practices such as stubble burning will also reduce it even more. Agricultural usages such as grazing, harvesting and tillage also tend to reduce soil carbon, as does increased erosion that is often a result of mass open space farming.

Given the enormous carbon storage capacity of soils, it has been suggested that with appropriate changes in agriculture management practices, could represent a significant reduction in atmospheric Co2. Managing agriculture to increase valuable organic carbon content can improve soil health and sustainable productivity by adding essential nutrients and increasing water-holding capacity, so essential for deep root development.


The Organic Solution

Hello, my name is Mel Holzworth and I am the CFO of an emerging, innovative, Organic Certified Liquid Plant and Soil Super Food company based in Brisbane, Australia. I have been an accountant for 30 years and a while back I embraced the vision of this forward thinking team of people. The creator of this technology is Danny Hood, a 5th generation farmer who has first-hand experience of the problems farmers face every day. With the development of a ground breaking technology, we are achieving the return of vitality back into our soil which is so necessary for the promotion and growth of healthy plants and nutritious tasting food, once again. A bit like Pop used to grow in his vegie garden when we were kids.

Recently, a well-known sugar cane farmer in Qld, Australia reported, after using the nutrient that not only did his soil health return quickly, but it was enriched with carbon and microbes. Scientific testing with the technology has been carried out which has resulted in confirming that carbon sequestration had returned to the soil with ease and at a very low cost to the farmer.

The vision of what can be achieved on a global level is truly astounding. Can you imagine the positive effect if not only commercial farmers were embracing Soil Sequestration, but also the humble home gardener. The mind boggles.


This video is a third party production which supports the principles of Dr Grow It All's ethos on planet health. The vital link to Globally Sustainable Biology.

Now, Where from here?

As is the case with any worthwhile project we need to fund lab work and also field testing on a larger scale and on different soil types and climate variations, not only in Australia, but globally. Yes, we have big plans.

We will run our 1st range of field testing on Sugar Cane Farms in Far North Qld, Australia, also potato crops in Gatton Qld. Wheat farms in the Narrogin area, in Western Australia. This program of clinical testing will run over a 2 year period and involve at least 4 crop harvest cycles.

Although the lab work will continue before, during and after each harvest cycle, it does come as a huge expense as the range of tests required on both soil and plants are extensive but vital to the production of a range of documents supporting what we know already to be true.

As we ask for funding for the 1st phase of the project we are confident of our success on a global level.  

Ways You Can Help

By donating you will become an advocate in the era of Globally Sustainable Biology through Dr Grow It All. You will be making a difference to the future of world food security and nutrition and thus the health of mankind.

Other ways you can help

  • Share our campaign on Facebook (the Indiegogo share tools make it easy)
  • Tell your friends and family. We need your help spreading the word about Dr Grow It All's mission to reduce carbon emissions.

Summary

Presently we are exporting small quantities of our plant and soil super nutrient to India, China and USA. Can you imagine what would happen if we could further develop a product that will help each country meet their carbon emissions targets. Imagine the benefits farming operations could offer the world through carbon sequestration and making the world a better place for generations to come. You could help us achieve this. Wow!!!!

and climate variations, not only in Australia, but globally. Yes, we have big
plans.
We will run our 1st range of field testing on Sugar Cane
Farms in Far North Qld, Australia, also potato crops in Gatton Qld. Wheat farms
in the Narrogin area, in Western Australia. This program of clinical testing
will run over a 2 year period and involve at least 4 crop harvest cycles.
Although the lab work will continue before, during and after
each harvest cycle, it does come as a huge expense as the range of tests
required on both soil and plants are extensive but vital to the production of a
range of documents supporting what we know already to be true.
As we ask for funding for the 1st phase of the project we
are confident of our success on a global level.  
Ways You Can Help
By donating you will become an advocate in the era of Globally Sustainable Biology
through Dr Grow It All. You will be making a difference to the future of world
food security and nutrition and thus the health of mankind.
Other ways you can help

Share our campaign on Facebook (the Indiegogo share tools make it easy)
Tell your friends and family. We need your help spreading the word about Dr Grow It All's mission to reduce carbon emissions.

Summary
Presently we are exporting small quantities of our plant and soil super nutrient
to India, China and USA. Can you imagine what would happen if we could further
develop a product that will help each country meet their carbon emissions
targets. Imagine the benefits farming operations could offer the world through
carbon sequestration and making the world a better place for generations to
come. You could help us achieve this. Wow!!!!

story:
Against all sane advice and their parents best wishes, Mark and Cody have entered the charity race from hell. In a vehicle poorly suited for cross city travel, they intend to cover a ridiculous amount of terrain with zero ground support. This grand tourismo of lawnmower taxis will take them from the southern tip of india 1500 miles north to the Pakistani border, all in the name of savin some trees. They need your help reaching their goal of $2000 for www.coolearth.org, a non profit group helping to save the rainforest by organizing and empowering local indigenous peoples. With your help we can support a great cause and make a real positive change. Check out the video below and visit their website to find out more about Coolearth.

Coolearth.org Rickshaw Run
