story:
Coral reefs, one of the world’s natural wonders and a hotbed of biodiversity, are under threat; populations of coral are declining throughout the world, and in the Caribbean in particular. Today there is a growing number of individuals that specialize in the growth and health of coral who can help turn the tide. We invite you to take part in an exciting project to help the threatened coral reefs of the Caribbean. With your help, we can regrow these coral reefs and educate the next generation of environmental stewards, educators, and scientists.

A unique opportunity to make a significant impact on the health and sustainability of Caribbean reefs is available to us in Grand Case, St. Martin. The local stakeholders in Grand Case look forward to our involvement in their community, and we have already laid the groundwork to develop this project during previous visits and meetings.

There are currently no major efforts in or around St. Martin, or the neighboring islands’ waters, to farm coral for transplantation back to adjacent reefs. The coral in this area represent a unique set of genetics that needs to be preserved, since, due to the distance, these coral cannot breed with coral in the areas where these helpful programs are taking place.


Coral reefs are complex biological communities, something like cities.  If one segment (or zone) is disrupted the whole reef ceases to operate normally and is endangered.  There are attempts all over the world to restock damaged, almost extinct coral reefs, but usually they consist of the introduction one or several species of farmed corals. 

Our project will be unique in that we recognize the interdependence of the parts of the reef.  We have a unique capability to replace the WHOLE reef structure, placing each of the interdependent species at the appropriate depth.  We will be the first program to recreate extinct or damaged reefs as a whole, not as an aggregation of a few species.

Our efforts will be enhanced by our capability to create relatively large coral colonies, thus speeding the recovery of the reef.  We will apply our newly discovered technologies to enhance coral growth and culture a multiplicity of coral species.


The funds raised will cover the legal costs associated with creating a non-profit organization to administer the reef restoration and education programs, and to ensure sustained support. We will develop three different artificial reef structures to provide a suitable substrate to grow coral, as well as a habitat for certain types of larval and juvenile fish. We will also have a more natural, and aesthetically pleasing design, to blend in with the surroundings.  We will test some of our designs in Long Island waters, where many species of tropical Caribbean fish settle out during the summer. Tropical larval fish expert Todd Gardner will analyze which fish settle on different reef construction configurations. We will determine which designs appeal to the most beneficial fish species, such as the grouper, surgeonfish, and parrotfish.

A portion of Joe Yaiullo's 20,000 gallon reef aquarium.                       Photo credit: Daniel Knop

We will take the best performing designs and deploy them in St. Martin later in the fall. Storm damaged coral will be tagged and propagated on the artificial reef and then transplanted back to the reef and surrounding areas, including the marine sanctuary run by the Reserve Naturelle St Martin.

 ( http://reservenaturelle-saint-martin.com/en )



We will track all colonies of the endangered Acropora species; several young colonies are currently growing in and around Grand Case Bay. We will educate the local population and tour operators about these important corals, including what special precautions to take and to educate their customers on.

The team will also work with the currently underserved Large Polyp Stony coral species. The environmentally friendly techniques that are used by the team members at the coral farm ReefGen, to propagated large quantities of these coral, will be used to grow mature colonies in as little as 2-4 years as opposed to 10-12 years on the wild reef. It takes older, sexually mature coral to spawn, and create the larvae that will reseed reefs on an even larger scale. The artificial reef will also be an ideal substrate for larvae to settle from spawning events on nearby reefs. These settled coral will also be tagged and cared for to maximize growth.


The education program will feature a college level study abroad component designed by Dr. Eugene Kaplan, using the coastal and marine environment of St. Martin and the artificial reef as teaching tools. Reef Generation will also offer the program to our college and high school partners in New York, Connecticut, New Jersey, and beyond as we extend our network.

Long term, we will construct land based classrooms for both “study abroad” and local St. Martin students, as well as an on land aquaculture component to further speed coral recovery. This center will serve to train coral restoration experts across the Caribbean, and educate tourists and locals on the importance of coral reefs.  

We will train the dive instructors at Octopus Diving on maintenance of the artificial reefs to aid in their upkeep in between team members visits. They will in turn use the reef as an education tool for their customers, and spread the impact and message of our project.

http://octopusdiving.com/http://octopusdiving.com/




The team will make 3 trips in groups of 3 or 4 team members, to install the artificial reef and plant coral, then plan follow up visits to study the species of fish attracted to each reef, and maintain and add on to the site. Long term, will we sustain funding for the program through grants, coordination with college partners, and other fundraising activities, to ensure sustained success in revitalizing the area reefs. The team will work to further enhance our relationship with local environmental groups, the St. Martin government, and community leaders and businesses.

Generous support for the project also comes from some reef aquarium industry heavyweights.

Two Little Fishies will be providing all the epoxy and glue that we need to secure the living coral to the reefs.  

(http://www.twolittlefishies.com)



Marco Rocks will be donating dry rock to be used for one of our reefs. (http://www.marcorocks.com).


We will thoroughly document the process at each step, release articles and videos, and give presentations on our efforts, successes, and failures. Our plan is to raise awareness, conduct original research, and move forward efforts to restore and safeguard coral reefs for generations to come.

With your help, we will rebuild some of the most crucial and damaged reefs in the Caribbean. We are eager to begin work on this exciting and important project, and we thank you for taking the journey with us. 





TEAM MEMBER BIOS



Dr. Eugene Kaplan:

Dr. Kaplan has had a long and productive career in education and aquaculture. Dr. Kaplan has written curriculum for grade school through graduate level courses. Dr. Kaplan founded several tlarge scale tilapia farms in Africa and Central America, as well as the Hofstra University Marine Lab in Jamaica . Author of several books, including Peterson’s Field Guides, including A Field Guide to Coral Reefs: Caribbean and Florida and A Field Guide to Southeastern and Caribbean Seahorses. Dr. Kaplan has seen first hand the rapid and extreme deterioration of Caribbean over the last 60 years. His work will be crucial in helping the team recreate the areas healthy reef ecosystems.



Joe Yaiullo

Joe is founder and curator of the Long Island Aquarium and Exhibition Center. Joe’s 20,000 gallon coral reef aquarium broke new ground in aquarium coral care, proving that large scale aquaria can be used to successfully house dense growth of living coral. He now consults on other monster reef tank builds. Joe is a long time coral farmer, many coral growing in his aquarium are over 25 years old. Joe has grown finger sized coral into man sized colonies. Joe is also President of the Long Island Reef Association (LIRA).




Justin Credabel

Justin is Co-founder of ReefGen, and a longtime coral aquaculturist. For the last 15 years Justin has been developing new methods to grow and reproduce coral, including never before propagated species and large scale aquaculture. Justin has developed Justin Credabel's Goniopower, distributed by Two Little Fishies, a food developed to feed Goniopora and other types of coral. Justin has developed curriculum for high school and college courses, and summer and afterschool marine biology education programs.





Laura Birenbaum

ReefGen Co-Founder, Laura Birenbaum is a coral and dwarf cuttlefish aquaculturist, and longtime aquarium professional. Many of her long term coral strains are growing in display and aquaculture systems throughout Long Island Aquarium. Laura has also been breeding several strains of dwarf Bandensis Cuttlefish for commercial distribution. Laura is also the Vice President of the Long Island Reef Association (LIRA), and a speaker at National and Regional conferences.



Project Consultant:

Todd Gardner



Todd Gardner is a professor of marine biology at Suffolk County Community College in Riverhead, NY. His life and his career have both been shaped by his passion for marine life and he has written numerous scientific and popular articles about his research and experiences collecting, keeping, and culturing marine organisms. Todd’s professional background includes work on a National Geographic documentary, commercial aquaculture at C-quest Hatchery in Puerto Rico, and an 11-year term at the Long Island Aquarium where he spent much of his time developing techniques for rearing marine fish larvae. To date he has raised more than 50 species. In 2013 Todd received the prestigious Aquarist of the Year Award from the Marine Aquarium Society of North America (MASNA). In his spare time, Todd dives, photographs marine life, runs marathons, and plays in a blues band.


Project Intern:

Karina Scavo


Karina is a graduate student in marine biology at Boston University focusing on coral recovery and restoration. She is studying under Dr. Les Kaufman, and is interested in environmental stressors and their effects on coral at the molecular level.

story:
Who are we?

We are the Paw-sitive Pals and we consist of four college students at the University of Tennessee. We are creating an Indiegogo campaign for a local animal shelter by the name of Young Williams Animal Center. We are raising money for YWAC to keep the animals happy and mostly importantly, healthy!

 

What We Need & What You Get

We are beyond excited to be working with this amazing non-profit however, we need your help! Our goal is to raise $1,000 to help with the cost of spay and neuters and medication. Your donation will help us reach that goal! The impact your donation will have on our community is great. You will help us raise the moral of animal lovers across the community, help lower the number of stray pets in Knoxville, and help the Young Williams Animal Center operate on a more efficient level with the amount of money that our campaign will generate from your help! Our campaign will also help YWAC spread their name across the community and at our school’s campus. This will help them reach out to potential adopters to adopt a furbaby from Young Williams. The more animals that are adopted the more room they have for  animals they need to take in! 


Every donation no matter the amount is very important to our community and YWAC. To thank you for your effort and generous donation we will be offering different perk packages for each different donation! 

Perk package #1 

For a $1 donation you will receive a Young-Williams Animal Center sticker.

Perk package #2

For a $5 donation you will receive a Tennessee Coozie in Grey or Orange!

Perk package #3

For a $10  donation you will receive a clear Tennessee tote bag. Purr-fect for football and basketball games!

Perk Package #4

For a $20 donation you will receive a sweet treat or suprise from Riverdog Bakery!

The Impact

Every year 2,000 stray, lost and abandoned animals are brought to Young-Williams Animal Center. In 2018 YWAC became a no kill shelter, yay! Giving these animals a second chance at life in a loving home is something Young Williams is successful in doing. However, spay and neutering, along with medication for certain animals can be expensive. Our group wants to fundraise for YWAC and help them care for every pet that enters their temporary home. Our campaign is where animal lovers can potentially donate and receive pictured perks for each donation value.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

It's okay if you cannot donate to our campaign. However, you can still help!

  • Help us get the word out about our campaign and let people know what we are fundraising for!
  • Use our sharing tools on Indiegogo! You can share on all social media platforms, this will help us reach our goal, so thank you!

story:
Friends! We really need your help, we can not cope without you!
This year the amount of the subsidy, which we were lucky to win, was one third less than usual, but in spite of this, we tried to help as much as possible the animals that were in trouble. We understood that we can not refuse the most important thing - in the treatment. We never refused to visit clinics at our expense to those who were in desperate need of it. And such animals, as always was very, very much. For all major operations, the group's activists collected money at once. But in addition to serious manipulations, there were a large number of examinations, droppers, injections, tests and treatments.
In addition, we helped to sterilize a few courtyard cats for pensioners who applied to us.

Despite the fact that the prices in the country grew every month, the staff of the clinic and the head physician did not raise the cost of servicing our animals and were always ready to work in debt !!! We would rather pay for the titanic work of the doctors of the clinic "9 lives".

We really need your help right now. If you have the opportunity to list at least 10, 50 or 100 dollars - this will be a contribution to our common good deed! There are a lot of people in our group. Please, after reading this post do not leave it unattended!
 Also, we constantly need the purchase of food for dogs! Thank you in advance! We believe in you, you never throw us in trouble!

Our friends, we learn from them:http://animals.kharkov.ua/node/374

story:
The EcoAdventure

Each year, River Watchers have an opportunity to spend their spring break participating in a one-week EcoAdventure. This EcoAdventure is a transformative, educational experience that cultivates the imagination, resourcefulness, environmental awareness, and collaborative skills of our young explorers, our future environmental stewards.

Last year, the young men of River Watch explored the geological diversity of West Texas. This year, the 18th Annual EcoAdventure, is for the young women of River Watch and will take place in East Texas. River Watchers will have the opportunity to camp in state parks, engage in one-of-a-kind environmental activities, and make lasting memories. They will learn about the wildlife and the ecology of the land as they hike trails, sleep under the stars, and form meaningful friendships with their peers. The EcoAdventure is a culminating experience for our River Watchers, where many of the lessons of environmental stewardship of the past year on the local level will coalesce into a deeper, global understanding and appreciation for nature.

For many of our students, this will be their first overnight camping trip - for some, their first road trip. It'll be their first time pitching a tent, building a fire, and roasting s'mores. Many have never ventured outside of Austin, and few have had the awe-inspiring experience of gazing up at a sky full of stars.

Austin Youth River Watch

Austin Youth River Watch is a multi-year, afterschool and summer program for high school students, combining youth development with intensive environmental education. Our "River Watchers" engage in hands-on science activities and environmental restoration projects. They are trained to collect and analyze water quality data, which is then reported to local and statewide agencies. Working in and around Austin's natural waterways, they learn about real-world issues such as biological diversity, erosion, and ecological sustainability.

The Impact

Every year, Austin Youth River Watch transforms the lives of 120 high-school students through holistic, youth-development activities that focus on academic success and environmental stewardship, making a positive impact on Austin’s environment and community.

The work of River Watchers on local water quality is critical, and goes towards preventing environmental tragedies such as the Flint water crisis. They have often been the first to detect spills and notify local authorities about conditions in neighborhood creeks and streams.

River Watchers do not necessarily have the best grades, nor do many of them come to us with initial interests in STEM. All are defined as "at-risk" by Texas Education Code, and yet nearly 100% of them have graduated high school since our founding in 1992. After just one year of participation, 89% report greater confidence with science, and 97% report greater knowledge of environmental issues. Nearly 40% of our students go on to work or study in STEM or environmental fields. Our alumni have become professional and personal environmental stewards working in government, academia, nonprofits, and industry. Some have even become environmental educators themselves.

Our students lead the way in understanding and positively impacting water quality in our local streams. And did you know that, since the time we started our work nearly 25 years ago, nearly 100% of our students have earned their high school diplomas? These are our planet's future stewards. Your contribution will not only invest in our important environmental work, but also the lives of underserved youth!

The Funding

The entire EcoAdventure will cost approximately $5,000. Your support will go towards:

  • Fuel for vans - $600
  • Groceries and supplies for the entire group - $3,600
  • Campsite reservations - $200
  • Camping and first aid supplies - $600

All funds raised beyond the initial $5,000 will go towards Austin Youth River Watch's overall programming, of which the EcoAdventure is a key part. All contributions are considered unrestricted and cannot be specified for any particular purpose. Your support is greatly appreciated, and will impact youth who would otherwise never have such an opportunity.

For all donations $50 and above, we are happy to provide an official Austin Youth River Watch vintage design Austin Creeks map t-shirt as a token of our thanks. Wear it proudly!

 

Risks & Challenges

As a small nonprofit, it is always challenging to fund local core programming along with peak experiences such as the EcoAdventure for our underserved youth. There are a couple of things that keep us going:

  • Austin Youth River Watch has been making a positive difference with underserved youth since 1992. Nearly 100% of all of our students graduate from high school.
  • We have built a supportive community around us that continues to grow. We'd like to share our story with you, and for you to join us.

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Share our campaign with your many followers!
  • Send us your email address to join our mailing list to learn about upcoming projects and events.
  • Volunteer your expertise (youth development, STEM, grant writing, marketing, etc…)
  • Volunteer with us to collect water quality data and perform hands-on projects that enhance the ecological and hydrological functioning of riparian zones.
  • Learn more about us here, http://riverwatchers.org/.
story_txt:
The EcoAdventure
Each year, River Watchers have an opportunity to spend their spring break participating in a one-week EcoAdventure. This EcoAdventure is a transformative, educational experience that cultivates the imagination, resourcefulness, environmental awareness, and collaborative skills of our young explorers, our future environmental stewards.
Last year, the young men of River Watch explored the geological diversity of West Texas. This year, the 18th Annual EcoAdventure, is for the young women of River Watch and will take place in East Texas. River Watchers will have the opportunity to camp in state parks, engage in one-of-a-kind environmental activities, and make lasting memories. They will learn about the wildlife and the ecology of the land as they hike trails, sleep under the stars, and form meaningful friendships with their peers. The EcoAdventure is a culminating experience for our River Watchers, where many of the lessons of environmental stewardship of the past year on the local level will coalesce into a deeper, global understanding and appreciation for nature.
For many of our students, this will be their first overnight camping trip - for some, their first road trip. It'll be their first time pitching a tent, building a fire, and roasting s'mores. Many have never ventured outside of Austin, and few have had the awe-inspiring experience of gazing up at a sky full of stars.
Austin Youth River Watch
Austin Youth River Watch is a multi-year, afterschool and summer program for high school students, combining youth development with intensive environmental education. Our "River Watchers" engage in hands-on science activities and environmental restoration projects. They are trained to collect and analyze water quality data, which is then reported to local and statewide agencies. Working in and around Austin's natural waterways, they learn about real-world issues such as biological diversity, erosion, and ecological sustainability.
The Impact
Every year, Austin Youth River Watch transforms the lives of 120 high-school students through holistic, youth-development activities that focus on academic success and environmental stewardship, making a positive impact on Austin’s environment and community.
The work of River Watchers on local water quality is critical, and goes towards preventing environmental tragedies such as the Flint water crisis. They have often been the first to detect spills and notify local authorities about conditions in neighborhood creeks and streams.
River Watchers do not necessarily have the best grades, nor do many of them come to us with initial interests in STEM. All are defined as "at-risk" by Texas Education Code, and yet nearly 100% of them have graduated high school since our founding in 1992. After just one year of participation, 89% report greater confidence with science, and 97% report greater knowledge of environmental issues. Nearly 40% of our students go on to work or study in STEM or environmental fields. Our alumni have become professional and personal environmental stewards working in government, academia, nonprofits, and industry. Some have even become environmental educators themselves.
Our students lead the way in understanding and positively impacting water quality in our local streams. And did you know that, since the time we started our work nearly 25 years ago, nearly 100% of our students have earned their high school diplomas? These are our planet's future stewards. Your contribution will not only invest in our important environmental work, but also the lives of underserved youth!
The Funding
The entire EcoAdventure will cost approximately $5,000. Your support will go towards:

Fuel for vans - $600
Groceries and supplies for the entire group - $3,600
Campsite reservations - $200
Camping and first aid supplies - $600

All funds raised beyond the initial $5,000 will go towards Austin Youth River Watch's overall programming, of which the EcoAdventure is a key part. All contributions are considered unrestricted and cannot be specified for any particular purpose. Your support is greatly appreciated, and will impact youth who would otherwise never have such an opportunity.
For all donations $50 and above, we are happy to provide an official Austin Youth River Watch vintage design Austin Creeks map t-shirt as a token of our thanks. Wear it proudly!

 
Risks & Challenges
As a small nonprofit, it is always challenging to fund local core programming along with peak experiences such as the EcoAdventure for our underserved youth. There are a couple of things that keep us going:

Austin Youth River Watch has been making a positive difference with underserved youth since 1992. Nearly 100% of all of our students graduate from high school.
We have built a supportive community around us that continues to grow. We'd like to share our story with you, and for you to join us.

Other Ways You Can Help

Share our campaign with your many followers!
Send us your email address to join our mailing list to learn about upcoming projects and events.
Volunteer your expertise (youth development, STEM, grant writing, marketing, etc…)
Volunteer with us to collect water quality data and perform hands-on projects that enhance the ecological and hydrological functioning of riparian zones.
Learn more about us here, http://riverwatchers.org/.

story:
Short Summary

The Highland eco educo center started as an idea in the heads of a group nature lovers, activists who are passionate about holistic wellness, permaculture, eco and healthy living.  Sava, Vlatko and Patricia have spend years as ecological activists in Montenegro, leading youth and other groups in various activities such as mountaineering tours, camps, ecological clean-up and planting actions, working with children and youth and numerous other healthy living activities, as well as citizen activism.  Thru a series of discussions and brainstorming sessions with other activists the idea was born to create a eco educo center with hostel/camping capabilities from a old rural house that Sava and Vlatko have in the hillside village of Martinici.  Named Highland eco educo center, it would be a focus for the development of social volunteering, eco school with education for all age groups, artistic commune retreat, environmental awareness workshops, healthy living and lifestyle classes (such as yoga, meditation, etc). 

The 1st of this kind in Montenegro, this center is surrounded by hills, stunning fruit tree groves, and tranquil fields and forests.  The old house was originally build more then 200 years ago, and is already partially ready for it's new purpose. It is in the historical region of Bjelopavlici, in the central part of Montenegro.

A great base for your trekking and volunteering endeavors through Montenegro. Only 16 km from the capital city of Podgorica.

A close-up satellite view of the building:  https://www.google.com/maps/@42.5481478,19.1753...

In the seemingly inaccessible areas of the rough hillside terrain there are villages of communities all connected and trails throughout the many valleys, ranging from grassy to forest terrain to breath-taking landscapes on the high plateau areas.

Having gathered together the funds to refurbish and renovate the property, we will transform it into a center of creativity, healthy living and environmental education.  The center will also provide hostel and camping accommodation for tours that are traveling thru, groups of all ages who are here on educo camping retreats, and for other reasons. 

How to express the magnitude of your contribution?  This is hard to explain. In this pure country of Montenegro education of this type: healthy and sustainable living practices, permaculture, ecological and environmental education, as well as social volunteering; are very scarce to non existent.  Being able to have a location that will provide education, broaden horizons, be a center for creativity, free thinking and self-development on a very low cost budget will for many (of all ages) be a fist time opportunity to be exposed to such education. 

What We Need & What You Get

Structurally this over 200 year old building is completely sound, and partially already refurbished.  We are in need of finishing work such as tiles, bath room and kitchen accessories and furniture to complete the interior.  The work so far has been done by Sava and Vlatko who are completely able to do most of the work needed themselves.

Needless to say, with most of the work being done by ourselves we are saving significant amount of money needed for contractors and other expertise.  We also have on hand the offered assistance of a number of friends, family and other activist who will provide needed manpower for the project.  

The primary concern and most important part of the project will be focusing on digging a well on the property.  Currently, the house is equipped with two cisterns for household use, technical water which will not be enough once the center gets running. For this important work an engineering and drilling company will be engaged.  

Additionally, Vlatko is well versed on making this property green by using solar thermal and PV panels, grey water recycling, low energy and water use.  This will make this center a self-contained, and with the organic gardening a self-sustainable center. 

The 20000 Euro requested will be the total needed to complete the work and get the center ready. All work and progress, and the impact of your investment will be transparently displayed thru pictures and descriptions on our webpage. 

Once fund raising is completed, the work will start immediately.  We are planning to start in May 2016 and complete the work by March 2017, to get the center ready for the spring/summer season of 2017.

Throughout the year there will be work to do on the gardens, around the 90000 m2 large property, terracing and cleaning the plots, preparing the camping terrain, outside classroom area, fire pits, planting, building of the greenhouse, etc.

The Team

VLATKO AND SAVA - Run their own taekwondo club, and mountaineering
club, and have been active in various ways in their local community and all over Montenegro.  Growing up in a rural setting, both have learned most they need to learn regarding farming and upkeep of land and home. 

SAVA - Is a construction engineer that has specialized in finishing construction work, and all accompanying construction technician knowledge. 

VLATKO - Is a mechanic for machine tools, welder, blacksmith and locksmith.  He is self-educated on solar panels, irrigation systems, other finishing construction work, and plumbing. 

i

PATRICIA - Has a degree in Mathematics and a master degree in Organizational leadership. She has lived in the United States for 19 years and has been a manager/project leader in one capacity or another for over 15 years. She currently is the director of an NGO called "Our action" (Nasa akcija) since 2012. The NGO focuses on environmental and heritage protection, leadership and other paradigm breaking education, humanitarian, sustainability and strengthening community work thru developing volunteerism and social activism.

Risks & Challenges

As all construction projects, this one runs the risk of falling behind schedule especially due to financial and/or weather constrains.  There is a possibility to also run over budget. To combat the risk of various delays we have put in a number of measures: 

1. We have given ourselves ample of time for schedule changes so we fall withing our planned opening date. 

2. We have enough workforce flexibility to get more work done and be ahead of schedule on days where weather is good.

3. We have applied for project funding in a number of places to make sure we do not fall short of what we need. Of course, the more funding we are able to secure, the better we can equip our center with all we need for it to function efficiently.

4. We have very carefully planned out needed funding for the project in order to minimalise the risk of going over budget.  

Our team (Sava, Vlatko and Patricia) have a number of large, successful projects under their belt.  The most important actually is our passion for the projects that we choose to get of the ground, because we invest ourselves to the fullest extend.  This is what we plan to do with project Highland eco eduko center which we plan to operate for years to come. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Other then a financial contribution which are of the out most importance to get the project of the ground, we wish to encourage all who are interested to contact us if they wish to volunteer and assist in the creation of the center, or to get more information and visit the center after opening.  Until we get our website running, we are available at the email nasaakcija@gmail.com ili visit.me@mail.ru, as well as on or facebook page. 

If you are unable to contribute, you can still help us.  PLEASE SHARE OUR WEBPAGE, MAKE SOME NOISE ABOUT OUR CAMPAIGN, USE THE INDIEGOGO SHARING TOOL OR JUST DO IT ON FACEBOOK OR TWITTER.  Your help is of big importance to us, in any way you wish to contribute. 

SUPPORT THE HIGHLAND ECO EDUCO CENTER!

story:
What is the Green Living Show?

The Green Living Show is an annual event in Toronto, Ontario held at the Direct Energy Centre.  It is a green tradeshow where the latest in sustainable technology, holistic practice and environmental campaigning is on display.  For 2014, the show will be held from April 25-April 27th.  The 3 day conference runs from 9 in the morning to 9 in the evening Friday the 25th and Saturday the 26th.  On Sunday the 27th the conference begins at 9:00AM and wraps up around 3:00PM.

Who Will We Reach?

  • Environmentally conscientious.
  • Socially aware.
  • 84% are between the ages of 20 and 49
  • 66% are female
  • 69% have university or post-graduate degrees
  • 59% hold professional or managerial positions

Costs:

Booth Space- 575.00

Carpeting- 72.00

Underpadding- 34.00

Electrical- 163.57

Liability Insurance- 127.60

What we get:

  • Exhibitor Space
  • Show Drape
  • Material Handling
  • 24-hour security
  • 10 free show passes
  • 6 exhibitor badges
  • Electrical power

Why Toronto 350.org is Attending:

In order for Toronto350.org to continue growing and developing a grassroots movement in accordance with our mission, it is important for us to reach a broader cross-section of the sympathetic public with our campaigns.

We are best served in doing this through raising awareness, specific to institutional divestment and pipeline campaigning.  By attending the Green Living Show, we stand to substantially develop contacts within the environmental movement, seek support from the public and build parnerships with green enterprises and other organizations. 

In terms of returns on investment, we have the opportunity to sell T-shirts, directly solicit donations and promote our campaigns.  Toronto350.org stands to at least earn a full return on its initial investment and preliminary assessment indicates an opportunity to build our campaigning resources through other positive externalities.

story:
Our Story

The concept for artist Anthony Burks to do the Endangered Florida Wildlife series stemmed from a recommendation from art historian in Palm Beach County. She asked Anthony why he was only producing African animals & not Florida animals since he is a Florida native. She mentioned that there were so many endangered wildlife & plant life that need a visual artist’s point of view.


After doing some research, on the local wildlife rehabilitation sanctuaries, and several different plant and wildlife that are in danger of being extinct, Anthony decided to execute several different artistic renderings of different endangered Florida animals. One of the discoveries in his research was that many of the sanctuaries are not doing well financially. There are many needs for these organizations to help the animal & plant kingdom to flourish.  


Anthony’s renderings accompanied by wildlife photography by Greg Matthews’, environmental photography by Durga Garcia and paintings by Ursula Fernandez will put together an exhibition in which 30% of proceeds of the sales of their works would go to three charities Busch Wildlife Sanctuary, Arthur R. Marshall Foundation & one TBA


The Endangered Florida Species Exhibition will be held at the Paul Fisher Gallery at 433 Flamingo Drive, West Palm Beach, FL in March 16, 2012. 

 

We feel that these images will make these endangered species real to the public. We want these animals off the endangered species list.  The money raised will help these organizations do more outreach & education to the public.

 

What We Need & What You Get

We need funding to host this event properly. We have the expenses of a videographer, a caterer, a bartender, the printing of the posters, signage & advertising. This is basically what the money raised is going to help finance. See the funding area for your perks.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

We are in need of a few sponsors.  Restaurants that may be able to sponsor a few platters a wine sponsor who would be able to sponsor a few cases of wine & a spirits sponsor who is interested in promoting one or two types of product from their line. This will help offset costs so we can put the money we earn here on paying the videographer in full, our bartender & our advertisers. 


Volunteers who can help manage selling of merchandise at the event .  Must be great with numbers keeping  track of inventor, handle the spreadsheet & tally up our totals at the end of the night.  I need at least 5 people for this.

 

Often when an exhibition is being established, art work gets stored away until the exhibition date arrives. Anthony’s idea is to put these creatures in foster care until the actual showcase. The foster care is basically renting the art. The clients will be temporary parents to Anthony’s wildlife & hang it on their wall for exhibition in their home or business until he is ready for the show.  Each piece sells for $3800.00.  The fee of the foster care is $1500.00.  The foster parents will naturally have first choice as to whether they want the art work.  If they do, the difference of $1500.00 will be subtracted from the $3800.00.  WE NEED  FOSTER PARENTS. This is a separate expense.


 We are also in need to a fiscal sponsor to help finance the printing of each set of the limited editions of Anthony Burks’ Endangered Series. (100 Ct) The sponsor who finances this will get 25 of the prints from the series to do what they wish (fundraisers, giveaways etc.) each one will be Numbered, signed & stamped by Anthony himself.  Each set is $6000 This is a separate expense.

story:
Heavens Field- a farm of cooperation in a sea of conflict.

"The land doesn't belong to us, we belong to the land."

Israel/Palestine often sparks images of violence and conflict but there are also Palestinians and Jews dreaming and realizing a different future. Whatever political  agreements may be reached- we know that our future on this land is together and its upon us to start working within our communities for a better future. Where we make space for each other- Heavens Field is exactly a space like that- a farm where we recognize and embody that this land is ultimately neither of ours;  our design and farming on the land reflects our understanding of each other as long-term neighbors: perma-culture.

We hope that by our working the land together and hosting inter-cultural work and dialogue sessions we will nurture a future of greater understanding- reducing the fear and violence between our peoples. The money we hope to raise here is literally the seed money to take our planning and investment the next step!

What we envision:

  • Co-run by local Jews and Palestinians, we have spent the past winter working out details, agreements and becoming better friends. We have just harvested the wheat crop on our land, and secured 6 dunam on long term rental for the project. Now it is just the seed money that we need to begin renting this land and dedicating it to our project.
  • Heavens Field will turn outward - selling our veggies in our local markets - branded for co-existence, supporting local families in need and welcoming volunteers and tourists to this especially holy piece of land.
  • The land is in a beautiful spring-fed valley between a Palestinian village and Jewish community near Bethlehem. All are welcome here: our community will include an expanding circle of volunteers, and visitors from the region and worldwide.
  • Heaven's Field Farm gives a physical space to the kind of grass-roots programming we believe in to change violence into understanding. This is one of a number of initiatives our larger communities are doing to increase understanding and cooperation between those perceived as the most natural of enemies. We are partnered with Arabic-Hebrew language learning circles, a joint Israeli Palestinian quarterly journal "Maktub", and other non-politically oriented co-existence work; all projects of our sponsoring network- Eretz Shalom (Land of Peace). 
  • Visit our English Facebook page: https://www.facebook.com/groups/177017932397979/ to see some of our activities and conversations, or come visit with us next time you are in the Holy Land.  

We are turning to you - people from around the world,  to make the first season a success. Our budget includes part-time salaries for 2 Palestinian and 2 Israeli staff, land rental, irrigation equipment, tools, and heirloom seeds from both Israeli and Palestinian seed banks. (see below and feel free to contact us for more details).

        Heavens Field Farm is run by everyday people here who are saying enough with the status quo and making an audacious stand within their home communities- to acknowledge and meet the "Other."  Help us get on our feet and carry the message to the many who are waiting for a place like this.

         This project is a unique chance to build an island of cooperation in the heart of the conflict. While the West Bank's notoriety is for the actions of hatred - there is a quiet majority on both sides that wishes to see the end of the violence, and is willing to address the reality that both our peoples belong to this land and it is upon us to find ways to live here now with each other. Our slogan is - Heart of the conflict, heart of the solution.

Other Ways You Can Help

Let people know about our project!

Come visit or tell somebody you know who's coming to Israel/ Palestine about our project- hosting tour groups and volunteers is part of our long-term plan.

And if you know someone who may be interested in supporting our work- foundations or friends, publicists or videographers- we are open to helping this vision become the most productive reality.

 

Budget Items:

4 part-time salaries, publicity materials, small meeting space structure (hoop house), irrigation equipment, land rental, event budget.

We hope to begin supporting ourselves through the sale of our vegetables after first season and by hosting various groups to the area to meet with local co-operation efforts.

For more information please feel free to contact our English language liason:

Shaul Judelman- organicjew@gmail.com

story:
A LITLE BIT ABOUT ME...

My name is Melissa Margetts and I am asking for your support & donations for the 100 Miles for Elephants trek I will be taking to raise funds and awareness about poaching and the plight of Kenyas rapidly declining elephant population. I moved from my home in Colorado to the slopes of Mount Kenya to volunteer on wildlife & humanitarian projects that I truly believe in. This is one project that is dear to my heart. I was the founder & director of one of Colorado's largest, most successful wildlife rehabilitation & education centers for 30 years. Helping wildlife has not only been a career for me but a lifetime passion.

A LITTLE BIT ABOUT WHAT WE'LL BE DOING...

I will be embarking on this 100 mile walk with a few other intrepid & impassioned wildlife advocates (fellow Elephants4life board members Annette Bulman, and Kaz Mikkelson) and we will be trekking along elephant travel corridors in north central Kenya for 9 days with a caravan of camels baring our tents and supplies. So we expect to be attacked by the fleas of 1000 camels while trekking with parched throats through the hot African sun while dodging 4 legged predators and anything else that crawls or slithers. Ahhhh but we will be accompanied by magnificent Samburu warriors as our guides & askari's (protectors). It looks like this old Colorado cowgirl is going to have to pull up her "Big Girl Panties" once again to do another 100 mile challenge & journey of a lifetime. (I completed the hardest 100 mile endurance horse ride in the world 3 times (the Tevis Cup). That will tell you I will not disappoint you should you contribute to my cause. I may be old but I'm determined and tough as nails. 100% of the money we raise will go our sponsor organization Space for Giants http://spaceforgiants.org 

THE MISSION:

To secure a future for the largest mammals on earth forever, to be enjoyed by humanity forever, by ensuring that they have the space and security to live and move freely in the wild forever.

A LITTLE BIT ABOUT WHY...

The appalling explosion of poaching of African elephants for their ivory trinkets on the east Asian market (particularly China) has left this species moving rapidly toward extinction.

 It is estimated that every day,100 African elephants are being killed for their ivory – if the slaughter continues at this rate Africa will have lost ALL of these magnificent animals in only TEN YEARS..... 

A LITTLE BIT ABOUT WHERE YOUR MONEY GOES....

The money I raise will go to the Space for Giants Foundation which will use the funds to: 

1. Provide wages, equipment and training for vitally needed poaching scouts & rangers in Laikipia.

2, Support the Kenya Wildlife Service to implement Monitoring the Illegal Killing of Elephants (MIKE) system in the Laikipia Ecosystem and wider area. This system was developed under the auspices of the Convention on the International Trade in Endangered Species (CITES) to help gauge the impact of the trade in ivory on elephant populations.

3. Improve collaboration and the quality of law enforcement work in order to ensure that those caught poaching giants or trading in their parts receive the highest penalties possible.

4.  lobby for both a change in the international laws that have allowed ivory to be traded legally and to mobilize leading public figures in China to champion elephants and other species with a view to stemming demand for wildlife parts.

YOU CAN HELP TO MAKE A DIFFERENCE TOO!.. Nothing is EVER too little to make a difference!

I will be covering my own expenses for this trek and my goal is to raise at least $2,500 for Space for Elephants through this campaign. Please help me reach my goal and we will BOTH be doing something to make a difference.

story:
I HAVE REACHED MY GOAL!! Thanks to all the generous personal donations from dear friends and family.

My story is certainly a changing thing. My initial intention was to make the trip to Seattle to attend the Generation Waking Up training and then tour back across Canada. That was until I discovered the Bus the Change peeps. Not only did they have an existing plan, structure, and RV for touring, but they had a TEAM. A small group of dedicated, passionate young people who want to do the same thing as me, inspire positive transformation! Not only that, but they were looking for an OPENING ACT, and when I saw that, I knew that I was the one for the job and had to go for it.

So here I am, in Oakland, California, writing, planning, organizing, and affirming that every thing has worked out and lead me to exactly where I want to be, and where I need to be.

Our plans are to raise money, adapt the Wake Up, book more dates, practice delivering the Wake Up, and hit the road in April tio go on our exciting tour, learning how we can speak to and draw out what it is our generation really wants to do. That is what happened in Egypt, Wael Ghonim and his prganizer friends just did what they felt was right, using facebook and twitter to organize and it TOOK OFF because that's what the people wanted and were feeling. I don't know if South Western American youth are ready in the same way, or even know what they are wanting, but we will find out, and we are ready to deliver the inspiring truth of our generation's story.

We are the ones we've been waiting for!






My Story

What really makes me come alive is giving myself and my passions to help the world come together and solve the greatest social, environmental, and spiritual challenges of our time. I get really excited when I think of a thriving, sustainable, just, peaceful global family, living in harmony with the natural world. One global citizenship that loves, shares and cares for each other and the Earth.  


On Feb 14th I am traveling from Guleph On, to Seattle WA, to train to be a facilitator of a workshop called Wake Up! The Wake Up! workshop inspires, empowers, and motivates youth, and I will be giving up everything I have to travel across Canada to make my contribution to the largest movement in human history, the movement towards a thriving, socially just, environmentally sustainable, spiritually fulfilling world. 


"Using music, inspiring multimedia, dynamic group interaction, and engaging dialogue, participants explore the critical questions facing young people and society today. It leverages the power of our generation’s narrative by empowering young people to wake up to a clear sense of identity and purpose, as members of a generation-wide movement for a thriving, just, sustainable world." - www.generationwakingup.org

 

My goal is to raise enough funds to get me to the training in Seattle. After the training I hope to partner with a group of facilitators who are taking the workshop on the road through California. Bus The Change is the name of this campaign and I hope to be the opening act as well as a skilled and engaging facilitator. This will teach me what I need to know and how we can work together to make as blueprint so myself and others can do the same thing and multiply the mobile global change squads that will eventually be in every city and every school in North America...and the World!


I will write blogs, songs, poetry, and make recordings of the workshops that will be made available on-line to everyone.

 

The Impact

I intend to work with other youth to creatively activate the hearts and minds of young people everywhere I go to take action and join the movement of all movements to transform our world. It is my hope that we not just document but collecting data, and connecting organizations and people in communities across the country that aim to create a sustainable, just, and thriving world. The worldwide movement is approaching a tipping point. There are millions of environmental and social organizations and hundreds of millions of caring, committed individuals working towards this noble collective goal to spread the word, spread the love, and come together for the good of all. 


Each additional active young human cell will speed up this healing movement and the process towards peace and sustainability exponentially. The end impact is becoming that much more closer to a thriving, just, peaceful, sustainable world. 


*In the off chance that I fall short on my goal, I will take a bus to Seattle and limit the scope of my project to BC and Southern Ontario for the time being.

Other Ways You Can Help

* Share my music, my spoken word, and my story. Send me love, believe in a better world, seek your passion and do what you love. Come ALIVE! The world needs you to come alive and remember who you really are. You are beautiful & I love you all!  


Thank you for taking time to read this!

 

http://www.youtube.com/user/TheoSimms

http://www.fouryearsgo.org

http://www.awakeningthedreamer.org

story:
Why Gardens?
Because gardens produce healthier food. Only 2% of American children eat enough fruits and vegetables, and 1 in 3 American children born after 2000 is at risk for Type II diabetes. A garden is an introduction to the real, healthy food students and families need access to.

Because gardens can help fix America's nature deficit. With more than 80% of Americans living in cities and suburbs, we need to work harder than ever to teach the values of natural processes.

Because gardens are a living laboratory for education. Not just healthy food—a lesson on what producing healthy food requires. Not just exposure to nature—a way for children to literally harvest the fruits of their labor.

A True Seed Investment 
For as little as $10, you can help a community reap all the benefits a garden has to offer. In just 39 days, we plan to raise $2500 per garden; to feed,  teach, and inspire people in each of these 100 communities. Here are a few things our garden plans to do with your donations:

"Forest Park Community Garden is located in Forest Park, Illinois, a small Village 8 miles from downtown Chicago. Before FPCG was established in 2008, there were no resources for Forest Park residents who wanted to garden but didn't have a place to do so. Forest Park Community Garden's mission is to educate the community on how to build organic sustainable food systems, to provide fresh organic produce to needy families and to beautify our community through gardening. The garden is located on approximately 1 acre of public land and consists of 51 raised garden plots, a charity garden area, and perennial native plant gardens. Currently there are approximately 25 individuals and families who use the garden to grow their own food. Also, other volunteers grow produce that is donated to the local food pantry. A variety of events are held throughout the year including garden picnics, educational classes, and our very popular annual seed swap. "

CHECK OUT THE GALLERY FOR IMAGES & VIDEOS

Look Good, Do Good
With every contribution to our garden, donors will receive organic, ethical perks from PACT. Our socks, undies, and t-shirts are produced to high standards of sustainability, with the comfiest organic materials we can find. You'll be giving out of the goodness of your heart, and in return you'll get PACT goodies. It's a win-win situation.

story:
The Chevra Lomdei Mishnayot synagogue is the last trace of the Jewish town of Auschwitz, Poland – a place where Jews thrived for almost 500 years before the community was destroyed during the Holocaust. It is the only Jewish remnant in the area of Auschwitz-Birkenau.

 

The Auschwitz Jewish Center is a registered not-for-profit 501(c)(3) organization.

The synagogue is part of the Auschwitz Jewish Center, which educates 25,000 Polish and international visitors each year about Jewish history before and during the Holocaust and the need to combat anti-Semitism, racism, and other forms of hatred in our world today.

 

What We Need

Break it down for folks in more detail:

  • Explain how much funding you need and where it’s going. Be transparent and specific—people need to trust you to want to fund you.
  • Tell people about your unique perks. Get them excited!
  • Describe where the funds go if you don’t reach your entire goal.

The Impact

The synagogue and the adjacent home of the last Jew of Oświęcim, Shimon Kluger, are held up by a retaining wall at dire risk of immediate collapse. When – not if – the retaining wall gives way, it will take the synagogue with it. The only remaining synagogue in Auschwitz will be lost forever.

 

To both ensure the Center’s structural integrity and its bright future, we must raise $300,000 for construction and renovation this year.

story:
Short Summary

Dive Against Debris Weekend is a 3-day scuba diving event planned with the intent to remove trash from natural reef sites in the upper Florida Keys.  

We are divers, divemasters and scuba instructors who dive daily in the Florida Keys and have witnessed marine debris (trash) piling up on the sites we dive. These sites are also home to over 260 species of tropical fish, dolphins, sea turtles, sharks and other marine life and is the only natural coral reef in North America.  With your support, we are going to clean it up!

By chartering a large commercial diving boat, our objective is to transport a total of 72 divers out to the reefs over a 3-day period for the sole purpose of removing marine trash from the reefs. Once the trash has been collected, sorted and logged, the data will be recorded into the largest online marine debris database in the world through Project Aware.  Not only will this cleanup effort have an immediate positive impact on the reef, but the survey information gathered will also help direct policy and advocacy efforts, aimed at addressing marine debris issues, in the future.

Your contribution will provide us with the necessary funds to pay for the charter boat, fuel and other expenses required to conduct these important clean up dives which will, in turn, profoundly benefit the reef on an immediate and long term basis. 

What's the Problem?

Plastic is the ocean's #1 killer!  

Every year, millions of pounds of trash finds its way to the oceans. Trash dumped into the ocean not only damages coral reefs, but it poses a serious threat to all kinds of  marine life. 

Thousands of fish, marine mammals, invertebrates, reptiles, birds and many coral species are killed every year by plastic bags, fishing line, enormous fishing nets, plastic bottles, car batteries, kitchen appliances, industrial waste and other trash in the ocean. Additionally, not only does ocean trash harm wildlife, but it compromises the health of humans, pressures the livelihoods that depend on a healthy ocean, and it threatens tourism and recreation which help the local economies. 

Florida is home to the largest natural barrier reef system in the Northern Hemisphere. A once pristine reef system teeming with aquatic life is sadly, today, like most other reef systems around the planet, facing turmoil due to trash as dive professionals in Florida, who have witnessed the degradation of these precious marine ecosystems year after year, we are asking for your help to make this mission possible. Together, we can create a positive impact in Florida's waters by cleaning up marine debris and, in turn, helping to preserve these amazing underwater worlds for future generations and ensuring that people can continue to enjoy recreational scuba diving adventures. 

 
Help us establish our Dive Against Debris campaign and together, we can help prevent trash accumulation from turning these beautiful reefs, ledges and seagrass meadows into rubbish dumps.

Who We Are

We are are group of dive professionals in Florida organizing this marine debris removal event under ProjectAware.org's "Dive Against Debris" program.  Each Dive Against Debris event is independently funded and organized by local grassroots efforts.  Think Globally, Act Locally! 

Mark Thrower is a scuba instructor and founder of the Dharma Dive Tribe. Mark, having lived and taught in the Florida Keys, donates much of his time to marine debris removal in both organized dives and by going out on his own every week either near coastal areas or accosting his friends for their boats to go out with other incredible people. The Dharma Dive Tribe enjoys the camaraderie of being out, removing marine debris and enjoying the phenomena (Dharma) that is diving. Marine debris removal is Mark's favorite type of diving and allows him to dive in places that most never go, something he calls his “Star Trek Dives” (to boldly go where no one has gone before).

Brian Barnes is a PADI Divemaster and environmental conservationist.  Brian has donated hundreds of hours as a volunteer and advisory member at Ric O'Barry's Dolphin Project, part of Earth Island Institute, to end dolphin hunting efforts in Japan. Locally, Brian has participated and helped organize dozens of marine and beach cleanup events that have removed more than a ton of debris from Florida's marine environments.  

Tam Barnes is co-founder and volunteer board member of Shark Fin Free Calgary, a non profit, grassroots organization whose campaign mission is to promote and assist in the creation of a municipal bylaw that bans the sale and trade of shark fin products in the city of Calgary, thereby positively contributing to the decrease in the global demand for shark fin products. Tam recently relocated to Florida where she and husband (Brian) are avid divers and work together for environmental causes that advocate for cleaner and healthier oceans.

What We Need & What You Get

Unfortunately, the trash that is seen dirtying beaches and floating on the ocean’s surface is just the tip of the iceberg. Much more lies unseen beneath the surface and far away on open waters — but that doesn’t make it any less important. 

Most Dive Against Debris events in Florida take place along shorelines and marine piers, which is crucial, but the only way to access the natural reefs, where massive amounts of marine trash is piling up, is by boat.

In order to mobilize our clean up efforts, we need to charter a commercial diving boat that can accommodate at least 12 individual divers plus crew during our Dive Against Debris event.  Your financial contribution will provide us with the necessary funds to acquire this vessel for 3-days. 

Without a boat, it will be impossible to get divers to the natural coral reef areas to clean up - we need your help! 

The Impact

Once the trash has been collected by the divers, it will be sorted and logged and the resulting data will be recorded into Project Aware Foundation's global marine debris database.  Not only will this cleanup endeavor have an immediate positive impact on the reef, but the survey data gathered will further help with policy and advocacy efforts in the future to help reduce marine debris, not just in Florida, but on a global scale.

Your contribution, along with the physical effort from our campaign divers, will help save millions of animals and remove some of the stress that is being forced on North America's natural coral reefs. With your help, we can contribute to the conservancy of coral species such as as the Elk Coral and Staghorn Coral, which were placed on the Endangered Species List in 2006 after 20 years of rapid decline.

Keeping these natural coral reefs free of marine debris is an immense step towards the preservation and conservation of the USA's delicate coral reef areas. Cleaning up debris from the reefs promotes their preservation, not just for future generations to enjoy, but for tourism, recreation, healthy fisheries and sustainable marine resources.

Over 75% of the annual revenue collected by all businesses in Monroe County, FL are due to these coral reefs, so it is everyone's job to do their part in protecting them.  As divers, we believe that we have an additional responsibility to the ocean's ecosystems as we are the only physical entity that can remove the debris from coral reefs without causing them further damage.

Other Ways You Can Help

Please, spread the word about our campaign through all of your social networks and help us make this happen!  Lead a movement of your own by signing up for a "My Ocean" account at ProjectAware.org and plan your own Dive Against Debris event.  Or, simply share this page on your Facebook, Twitter and Google+ social profiles and engage your friend network to do the same and get involved.

Lastly, stopping the trash flow at it's source, before it can reach the water, is everybody's responsibility. Waste, and how we choose to handle it, affects all ecosystems on the planet. Remembering to practice the three "R's" -  Reduce, Reuse and Recycle, and empowering your friends to do the same, is the start to a very effective way of eliminating the amount of trash that ends up in the oceans, and can minimize the need for future retrieval and removal efforts.

If you're interested in diving this event, please contact us!  The dives will be free for diver volunteers and divers must be open-water certified by a recognized agency (e.g., PADI, NAUI, SSI, etc.). In addition to that, divers must bring all of their own equipment, including tanks.  If you need to rent tanks, there are numerous dive shop locations in Key Largo that can provide them to you as long as you present a valid certification card. After the clean up dives are complete, our group has also planned some fun celebratory events that you are welcome to attend. 

Finally, if you or your business would like to donate a prize for our "after the dive" raffle, please contact us as well. Anything and everything is greatly appreciated.

Thank you for your support!
story_txt:
Short Summary

Dive Against Debris Weekend is a 3-day scuba diving event planned with the intent to remove trash from natural reef sites in the upper Florida Keys.  



We are divers, divemasters and scuba instructors who dive daily in the Florida Keys and have witnessed marine debris (trash) piling up on the sites we dive. These sites are also home to over 260 species of tropical fish, dolphins, sea turtles, sharks and other marine life and is the only natural coral reef in North America.  With your support, we are going to clean it up!
By chartering a large commercial diving boat, our objective is to transport a total of 72 divers out to the reefs over a 3-day period for the sole purpose of removing marine trash from the reefs. Once the trash has been collected, sorted and logged, the data will be recorded into the largest online marine debris database in the world through Project Aware.  Not only will this cleanup effort have an immediate positive impact on the reef, but the survey information gathered will also help direct policy and advocacy efforts, aimed at addressing marine debris issues, in the future.
Your contribution will provide us with the necessary funds to pay for the charter boat, fuel and other expenses required to conduct these important clean up dives which will, in turn, profoundly benefit the reef on an immediate and long term basis. 

What's the Problem?


Plastic is the ocean's #1 killer!

story:
We are a small group of people who have spent many years refining the process of extracting organic products from sustainably grown marine kelp

Our motto says it all...

“Clean Water Gives Life”

We are a small group of people who have spent many years refining the process of extracting organic products from sustainably grown marine kelp.

Our natural products are 100% safe for people and for the environment and are now being used to successfully clean domestic and industrial wastewater, removing unhealthy chemicals and odours and helping maintain clean natural waterways, offering clean water to many more people.


There is a limited amount of clean water in the world and more and more of it is being polluted as our population grows and our industries expand.

Some people have turned to unsafe solutions to their wastewater problems, using chemicals and enzymes - not only do these often cause other environmental issues, they can have far worse long term effects on our children.

One terrible side effect of enzyme use could cause children to be born with no arms or legs or eyesight - we have seen it before and we certainly don't
want to see it again.

The Daily Mail – 16 March 2014

Plague village where the WATER gives you cancer: Global twitter revolt over remote Chinese hamlet where wells are poisoned and disease rates are soaring,

  • Ordinary Chinese furious over high rates of disease in polluted areas
  • Outrage has spread throughout China thanks to social media
  • Communist Party has pledged to tackle the growing health crisis


The Water Project.org

  1. Did you know that half of the world's hospital beds are filled with people suffering from a water related disease?
  2. In developing countries, about 80% of illnesses are linked to poor water and sanitation conditions. 1 out of every 5 deaths under the age of 5 worldwide is due to a water-related disease.
  3. Clean and safe water is essential to healthy living.

We began in Australia and so far have achieved great success improving sewage networks and cleaning wastewater from food processing plants.

We now wish to expand our activities into other industries and in other countries. We have targeted many problem areas where our organic solutions will provide great benefit - some of these are in China, some in Africa and others in North America.

Our Product - Solutek

We developed our organic solutions by extracting certain components from sustainably harvested, naturally occurring marine flora – kelp to be exact.

These organic concentrates do NOT contain ‘live-cell’ bacteria (bio-culture) or enzyme concoctions and cannot introduce renegade bacteria into anybody’s water system.

They are:

  • 100% bio-degradable
  • Are user and environmentally safe
  • Non-hazardous
  • Non-flammable
  • Non-corrosive

Solutek does not just clean industrial and domestic wastewater…

Soil Enhancement:

It is becoming increasingly evident that beneficial bacteria play a key role in the fertility of soils and the subsequent performance of crops and plants that produce food.

Solutek, added to irrigation water at levels of 3-5 parts per million, can act as a stimulant to help beneficial bacteria reproduce and grow thus improving the fertility of those irrigated soils.

Quality of Life in small third-world communities:

Families in small communities in many developing countries face a lot of difficult challenges. Solutek can assist in helping those families.

Solutek helps increase beneficial aerobic bacteria in wastewater thus putting oxygen back into polluted water and limiting the amount of odour produced by hydrogen sulphide in anaerobic conditions.

This improvement in the performance of the local sewage treatment system through increased oxygen levels allows the community to process sewage more effectively, which in turn reduces the incidence of disease.

Unfortunately, we are still spending more money each month than we make as we try to improve our products further and expand our efforts internationally.

This is where you can help

Every time our product gets used somewhere in the world:

  • We know the outcome will be of benefit to our environment
  • We know that the water will be cleaner
  • We know it will be more healthy for people to drink; and
  • We know that we will be slowly cleaning our natural waterways and ground water.

We want to raise $500,000. I know, it sounds a lot - but wherever we tackle a water pollution problem:

  • We have to begin with expensive laboratory testing of the water and review its environment to determine just how bad the problems are
  • We need to know what particular pollutants we have to remove
  • Where the best place will be to apply our products
  • Then measure the improvements to the wastewater system as we make them so we can teach other people to dose their own system
  • And all this takes several months

Our products are not expensive but the establishment of the projects to clean different wastewater problems is.

Apart from helping us clean up the world, we want to thank you in a more recognisable way.

Every dollar we receive will help us improve some community's environment somewhere: It may be the sanitation and drinking water in a remote African village; or cleaning the effluent from factories that ends up being poured into streams and rivers.

We will always have a positive impact on the health of people and where they live.

If you would like to help us but don't have the money, please share our goal with your friends and encourage them to join with us in cleaning the world's water.

Indiegogo has tools you can employ to share our story – please use them.

story:
Over the last week a state of emergency has been declared in parts of Bosnia after the heaviest rain and worst floods since records began more than 120 years ago.

Overflowing rivers have burst into towns and villages, cutting off whole communities, while landslides have buried houses. Many have been left with little or no food, electricity or clean water, communities have been evacuated and homes have been devastated. Individuals have been left with only the possessions they were able to carry, and the clothes which they were dressed in. 

For those who know anything in regards to Bosnia will know that this is a country left devastated by war, the majority of the population are unemployed and rely largely on the agricultural industry to survive. The floods have not only ripped communities and homes apart they have almost totally wiped out the countries agricultural resources for the year. 

The situation is sadly still becoming progressively worse and the forecasts suggest more rainfall is yet to be expected. I would urge anyone who is able to donate to donate generously. All the money raised is going to be sent directly to the victims, the plan is to send all the money raised to the Red Cross who will then disrepute packages across the country.

story:
Update

We would like to thank you all that supported our campaign in any way. 

We didn’t quite raise enough money to buy the plastic moulding machinery we hoped to buy, however, we have made the most of the amount we raised; we decided to try 3d printing, so far we have 3 printers which enables us to make up to 6 items a day, the good thing about 3d printing is that the printers themselves are relatively cheap, therefore it will be possible to expand our capacity by buying new 3d printers.

We also bought a filament makers which helped to cut the cost of filament by 50%.

The advantage of this change is that the new product is slimmer, lighter, better looking and most importantly requires less handwork than the old design.

The disadvantage is that the plastic we use, PLA, is much more expensive than the old plastic which has increased the cost of production. 

Once again, many thanks to you all!!!

_____________________________________________________________________

Original Campaign

We are Masa Energy, a start up company based in Uganda, East Africa, and our goal to make affordable solar products for the millions of people in Africa without access to electricity.

Our first product is a portable solar lantern that is easy to use and costs just $12, a price that is affordable for most people.

_______________________________________________________________________

The problem

Whatever their reasons, African governments have failed in their duty to provide basic infrastructure such as electricity to the majority of their population. The situation is such that in many countries less than 1/4 of the population has access to electricity.

Source: World Bank

As a result, many people, especially in rural areas, still rely on solutions that their grandparents relied upon, like kerosene lamps.

There are many disadvantages to kerosene lamps and here are some of them:

1. Poor quality of light

As you can see from the pictures above, with kerosene light it’s difficult to see from just one meter away. School children who use them to do homework would have to seat really close to the lamp, which increases their exposure to the hazardous smoke.  


2. Pollution 

Much of the fuel from Kerosene lamps turns into pollutant smoke. Research has shown that kerosene lamps add up to 3% to global black carbon emissions.

Source: niehs.nih.gov


3. Health risks

The World Bank estimates that breathing kerosene fumes is the equivalent of smoking two packets of cigarettes a day.

Also from the World bank; two-thirds of adult females with lung cancer in developing nations are non-smokers.

Source: BBC


4. Cost

In Uganda the average kerosene user spends $0.20 on fuel, that will power the lamp for 4 hours.

For low income families $0.20 can mean 10% or 20% of their daily income. And on days when there’s no money to buy the fuel, the whole family has to go to bed as soon as it gets dark. 

_______________________________________________________________________

Our Solution?

We have created a solar lantern that is much, much brighter than a kerosene lamp.


No pollution:

It charges under sunlight, stores the energy in its rechargeable batteries and uses an energy efficient LED bulb. The batteries can last over 2 years.

Battery life is 12 hours when fully charged; this ensures that even if the user misses a day of charging, a rainy day for example, there will still be enough energy for them to use (the average user needs light for 4 hours).


And most importantly for the target customer, it’s cheaper than kerosene use:  

The solar lantern costs $12, this is a one off cost and it comes with a 1 year warranty.

If you compare that to the cost of kerosene fuel, which is $0.20 per day, you can see that the lantern will pay for itself in just 60 days. 

______________________________________________________________________

Why we need your Help

We currently make these lanterns using the home-made tools pictured above (You can see the making process in our video). 

We had a limited budget from the beginning but felt it was important to prove the product was feasible before trying to raise capital. We have proven that the product is feasible but have been unable to raise the capital we need to buy machinery.

In Uganda there are no venture capitalists or angel investors and every bank we’ve spoken to wants collateral. 

With this IndieGoGo campaign, we are hoping to raise money to;

  1. Buy plastic moulding machinery
  2. Rent factory space

If we raise enough money, we would also;

  1. Work on a solar mobile phone charger (many customers inquire about this).
  2. Work on a brighter version of our solar lantern.
  3. Hire more people to help us with the work.
______________________________________________________________________

Some pictures of how people are using our lanterns:


A business that sells fruits and vegetables uses the lantern to light up the kiosk at night.

A poultry breeder uses the lantern to light up the pen over night.
