products for the millions of people in Africa without
access to electricity.Our first product is a portable solar lantern that is easy
to use and costs just $12, a price that is affordable for most people._______________________________________________________________________The problemWhatever their reasons, African governments have failed in
their duty to provide basic infrastructure such as electricity to the majority
of their population. The situation is such that in many countries less than 1/4
of the population has access to electricity.Source: World BankAs a result, many people, especially in rural areas, still
rely on solutions that their grandparents relied upon, like kerosene lamps.There are many disadvantages to kerosene lamps and here are
some of them:
1. Poor quality of light
As you can see from the pictures above, with kerosene light it’s difficult to see from just one meter away. School children who use them to do homework would have to seat really close to the lamp, which increases their exposure to the hazardous smoke.  2. Pollution Much of the fuel from Kerosene lamps turns into pollutant
smoke. Research has shown that kerosene lamps add up to 3% to global black
carbon emissions.
Source: niehs.nih.gov3. Health risksThe World Bank estimates that breathing kerosene fumes is
the equivalent of smoking two packets of cigarettes a day.
Also from the World bank; two-thirds of adult females with
lung cancer in developing nations are non-smokers. 
Source: BBC4. CostIn Uganda
the average kerosene user spends $0.20 on fuel, that will power the lamp for 4
hours. 
For low income families $0.20 can mean 10% or 20% of their
daily income. And on days when there’s no money to buy the fuel, the whole
family has to go to bed as soon as it gets dark. _______________________________________________________________________Our Solution?We have created a solar lantern that is much, much brighter
than a kerosene lamp.No pollution:It charges under sunlight, stores the energy in its
rechargeable batteries and uses an energy efficient LED bulb. The batteries can
last over 2 years.
Battery life is 12 hours when fully charged; this ensures
that even if the user misses a day of charging, a rainy day for example, there
will still be enough energy for them to use (the average user needs light for 4
hours).And most importantly for the target customer, it’s
cheaper than kerosene use:  The solar lantern costs $12, this is a one off cost and it
comes with a 1 year warranty.
If you compare that to the cost of kerosene fuel,
which is $0.20 per day, you can see that the lantern will pay for itself in
just 60 days. ______________________________________________________________________Why we need your HelpWe currently make these lanterns using the home-made tools
pictured above (You can see the making process
in our video). We had a limited budget from the beginning but felt it was
important to prove the product was feasible before trying to raise capital. We
have proven that the product is feasible but have been unable to raise the
capital we need to buy machinery. 
In Uganda
there are no venture capitalists or angel investors and every bank we’ve spoken
to wants collateral. With this IndieGoGo campaign, we are hoping to raise money to;
Buy plastic moulding machinery
Rent factory space
If we raise enough money, we would also;
Work on a solar mobile phone charger (many customers inquire about this).
Work on a brighter version of our solar lantern.
Hire more people to help us with the work.
______________________________________________________________________Some pictures of how people are using our lanterns:A business that sells fruits and vegetables uses the lantern to light up the kiosk at night.A poultry breeder uses the lantern to light up the pen over night.

story:
"Never doubt that a small group of committed people can change the world. Indeed, it is the only thing that ever has." - Margaret Mead

LET'S MAKE VANCOUVER FIN FREE

The movement to protect sharks is growing across Canada and we want to build on the momentum of the shark fin ban in Toronto and launch Fin Free Campaigns in BC. Starting with Vancouver, we will sweep across the lower mainland and then, across Canada.

There are over 100 restaurants that serve shark fin in Metro Vancouver, making it the second largest Chinese restaurant industry in the continent. Through our Happy Hearts Love Sharks wedding contest, many Chinese wedding couples and consumers have already joined the movement and pledged to not consume shark fin.

Now it's time to take this movement to the next level and ban the sale, possession and trade of shark fin in Vancouver, Burnaby, and Richmond.


We've been garnering support from Vancouver City Councillors and we'll be pushing for a motion to ban shark fin in Vancouver right after the elections and we can do it with your support.

OUR PLANS FOR A FIN FREE MOVEMENT IN BC

Vancouver ? Burnaby ? Richmond ? Canada
Vancouver is planning to be the Greenest City in the World by 2020 and starting here, we can launch a movement that would build a foundation for shark fin bans across neighbouring cities, like Burnaby and Richmond.

We are also working with a Member of Parliament who is introducing a bill for a national ban on shark fin imports. Having successful municipal bans will build the momentum we need for passing a national ban on imports.

Referral Contest

IndieGoGo automatically tracks the referrals of contributors, so we are offering a BONUS award to the person(s) with the most referral contributions! Once you contribute any amount - even the minimum of $10 - you could still win the contest by referring the most contributors.

1st place referral prize is everything included in the $1,000 Fin Free Warrior pledge package.

2nd place referral prize is everything included in the $500 Shark Knight pledge package.


It's not hard to win - make the minimum contribution then refer your friends!

Where Your Money is Going



Our goal is to fundraise $45,000-$80,000 in total for the 6-12 month campaign. With $18,000 pledged through IndieGoGo, it will contribute a huge portion to jumpstart this campaign.

  • Campaign materials (design and production), website design & maintenance, web action tools
  • Campaigner (Claudia) to lobby politicians, organizations, liaise with media to keep the issue on high profile
  • Volunteer Coordinator to educate and engage constituents, mobilize supporters to take online and in person actions (like petitioning and showing up at committee hearings)
  • Office and room rentals for volunteer meetings and make the magic happen!
  • Travel costs to get to presentations and meetings

The rest of the campaign funds will be raised through grants and events fundraisers.

An Effective Campaign Takes Dedicated People

Lobbying City Councillors, educating organizations, convincing businesses, mobilizing citizens, organizing volunteers and interviewing with media in English, Cantonese and Mandarin â€“ it takes dedicated people to run an effective and comprehensive campaign to ban the controversial sale of shark fin. Shark Truth is a lean and mean organization and with your support, we can make it happen!

Real Results: 10,000.
Shark Truth is the only group in Canada that directly engages the Chinese community on shark fin issues through our collaborative and effective campaigns. In just two years, we have convinced 65 couples to pledge to protect sharks and not serve shark fin at their wedding, diverting 10,000 bowls of shark fin from consumption (saving approximately 1,000 sharks). This shows politicians that there are Chinese consumers across the nation that support a Fin Free world. In Toronto, we collected & delivered 10,000 signatures for the shark fin ban motion that passed 38-4 and we've been featured on CBC The National, Globe & Mail and Fairchild Cantonese Radio speaking out for sharks. Let's repeat this success in Vancouver.

Other Ways You Can Help
Refer a Friend to make Fin Free Vancouver reality! 
Come join us to launch the campaign in Vancouver Thursday December 1st: http://finfreevan.eventbrite.com/
Sign the Petition for Fin Free Vancouver: http://chn.ge/finfreevancouver
Get Involved & Join the Team: http://bit.ly/joinsharktruth

Questions or Comments? Contact us!


BACKGROUNDER

Sharks & Oceans at Risk  | Every year, up to 73 million sharks are killed primarily for their fins, a practice that is not only ecologically destructive, but wasteful. Sharks are top predators and maintain the balance of our ocean ecosystem, something we all depend on. On average, fins make up less than 5% of a sharks total body weight. Due to the high value of their fins and low value for their meat, their fins are often the only thing taken and the rest of their body wasted and dumped overboard. Most popularly served at Chinese wedding banquets, shark fin consumption is threatening the stability and health of our ocean ecosystem.

Our Partners | We are working with United Conservationists in a strategic alliance to maximize our efforts. We'll be using their Fin Free branding and tools and we will be carrying out the grassroots organizing and lobbying to get municipal motions passed.

Shark Truth is a grassroots nonprofit dedicated to promoting awareness, education and action for sharks around the wasteful and ecologically destructive consumption of shark fin soup. Learn more  at http://sharktruth.org or join us at http://facebook.com/sharktruth

Note: Contributions made with a non-US accounts will be subject to your bank's exchange rate into US dollars.

story:
Project AviPulse : Objectives

Project AviPulse is an initiative to promote bird conservation across the world through:

  • Creation of knowledge
  • Generation of awareness
  • Appropriate use of technology

What exactly do we develop?

  • Sound processing tool for bird identification from calls / recordings

A smartphone app which can record and identify bird species from their calls!

  • Image processing tool for bird identification from images
  • Comprehensive database creation for bird features to aid in bird identification via a feature-based probabilistic search (currently live at http://www.avicentral.com/latestsite/tools5.php)
  • Bird visualization tool to interactively identify a bird based on observations made in the field

Build your own bird, or try to build a bird you saw and find out which species it was!

  • Field trips and on-field conservation activities
Apart from these, we also develop databases for research and education purposes and are currently developing a curriculum for wildlife conservation as a course to be taught to school students.
Here is a basic overview of our motivation and our tools:

What we will use the funds for

Funding raised will be directly used to develop bird identification tools and generate databases. Details of the use of funds:

  • $500 for the development of database of noise-free bird calls that can aid in the sound processing tool
  • $1000 for the development of database of images that can aid in the image processing tool
  • $1000 for development of the sound processing tool
  • $2500 for development of a feature-based database of birds of the world
  • $500 for development of a data visualization tool for bird identification built using the feature-based database
  • $500 for development of a map-based interface to locate different birds and birding spots in the world
  • $1500 for on-field conservation activities, specifically in rural India where birds are threatened by pollution and incorrect waste disposal

What you get!

We are offering several perks for funds raised by you towards Project AviPulse:

  • $10 : Try out our Bird visualization tool for free and be a part of the developing team! Your feedback as a beta user will be extremely valuable!
  • $20 : Try out our sound processing tool for bird identification free before its official release, and be a beta user!
  • $40 : Get our entire set of AviPulse Tools. You can try out our sound processor, image processor, feature-based Bird ID Tool, Bird visualization tool and bird locator for free! Also be a part of the developing team with your feedback as a beta user!
  • $60 : Get a T-shirt shipped to your doorstep which respects your contribution towards Project AviPulse


  • $150 : Get access to our huge Bird ID Tool database, which has over 12000 species with 50+ anatomical and physiological features for each species! We have taken, and are taking, enormous efforts to create this database which will serve as the ultimate bird ID database!

The Impact

Once established, tools developed by Project AviPulse  can be used by scientists, naturalists, bird-watchers and nature enthusiasts around the world. The critical impact areas are:

  • Census : The sound processing tool is being developed specifically to be able to identify species from their calls. This could improve census studies and numbering endangered species
  • Education and generation of awareness : The Bird identification tools using image and sound processing and the probabilistic search tool can help in easily identifying species. This will generate interest and the need for bird conservation can be developed.
  • Exploration : The data visualization tool can be used for exploration purposes, in order to visualize the biodiversity in avifauna in the world backed by a database of distribution ranges for each species. Youth can get introduced to the amazing avifaunal biodiversity by exploring the bird world through our tools. This generates interest, awareness, enthusiasm, and, most importantly, promotes bird conservation!
The tools designed will impact all levels of individuals - scientists, naturalists, professional bird-watchers, amateur bird-watchers and students who just want to explore the amazing diversity in the avifauna of their home country! We will be one step closer in  promoting bird conservation through knowledge creation and generation of awareness.

Who we are

Like several initiatives, this project was conceived and fostered at the Indian Institute of Technology, Madras. The project has now evolved from a mere passion for bird conservation to a structured technologically-challenging research start-up. The team has the perfect blend of avian love and technology for a sustainable and promising future. 


Raunak Bhinge, a student of IIT Madras and now a PhD student at UC Berkeley, is a passionate birdwatcher and technology freak. His bird-watching experiences and personal interactions with the avian world sowed the seeds of AviPulse.


Bhavin Chandarana, a student of IIT Madras, is an expert in software development and electronics. As a leader of the Entrepreneurship Cell in IITM, he packs with him several invaluable skills along with his zest and passion for technology. He now works full-time on Project AviPulse with the firm belief that together we can make the world a better place for birds.


Pallavi Hujband, a full-time software engineer and bird-watcher, devotes time and effort from her busy schedule towards the project. She provides invaluable support in terms of knowledge about birds, on-field conservation activities, educational bird-watching trips and user interface strategies in order to take the tools we develop to the users who will be actually using them!

Together, we believe we can make a difference!

We do not work alone!

We implement cutting edge technology, through collaborations with esteemed research institutes like University of California Berkeley, IIT Madras, IIT Mandi and IIT Bombay, that aid in census, bird identification and bird conservation as a whole. We believe in developing tools along with partner universities in order to apply the latest technologies and bridging the gap between research and application!

Risks & Challenges

Since Project AviPulse is a collection of research projects implemented as tools for a social cause, we receive support from several organizations like WWF and BirdLife International for our activities. There are minimal risks in terms of competition due to the technologies being implemented, and all the tools would be free for use as web applications, thus further promoting dispersion of knowledge. The main challenges foreseen are:

  • Access to data for development of databases : Since this is a niche field, the data required to develop the databases are not available and need to be generated. We are currently generating an exhaustive feature-based database for the birds of India. In order to expand to all the birds of the world, immense effort will have to be put into database generation.
  • Collaborative work : In order to promote this form of knowledge and data-driven bird conservation, efforts will have to be put into making this available and known to people in developing countries of Africa, South-East Asia and Central America. For this to work out, collaborations with organizations (particularly Audubon societies or equivalent conservation societies) would be necessary to be able to distribute this knowledge

Other Ways You Can Help

If you cannot donate to our cause, you can still help us achieve our goals by spreading the word. Project AviPulse is taking one major step ahead in technology towards the cause of bird conservation.

story:
Our Story

On December 2nd we will be going to Burma. We are fortunate enough to have been asked to document (via videography and photography) a group that is going to Burma to provide aid to 15 orphanages. These orphanages have been regularly overlooked because of their location and they in desperate need of help. The 'lack' Burma is currently suffering is overwhelming and this project is an effort to provide the necessary supplies needed for these orphanages to continue operating and ultimately continue saving the lives of children. 


The Impact

This campaign will have an unbelievable impact on these orphanages by providing basic necessities that are needed to survive.


We are asking for $15,000. A small amount will go to renting equipment for documenting this project. However, the majority of the money will be divided up and then given to the orphanage to help with the essentials and their individual need.

We are asking for you to donate money and take this opportunity to partner with us. Your donations will purchase water wells, food, bedding, toys and provide a way for each orphanage to support themselves financially once we've left. These are necessities that no child should go without.


Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't donate right now, we thank you for considering our campaign and ask that you share it with others on Facebook, twitter, or any other social media site so that someone else may have the opportunity to give.  


We would also like to thank all of our sponsors involved in donating their time, money and products. Want to thank Fortune Cookie Soap for donating perks too.

story:
"First it was necessary to civilize man in relation to man. Now it is necessary to civilize man in relation to nature and the animals". ~ Victor Hugo

Ever since I was a small child I dreamed of a world where modern man could live in harmony with nature. As an adult, my volunteer work in India has brought me back to some of those core values.  I have a passion for spreading the word about alternative energy, water catchment purification, and other off-grid and affordable living practices. We CAN Thrive Naturally!!

This campaign is aimed to raise money for chronicling my current project of a water purification system, a solar oven, and a small aquaponics system.

I have been studying sustainable design for some time and am preparing for my certificate. My life goals include continuing on to achieve the diploma and teaching credentials and eventually open up my own school, offering courses online at a much more affordable rate than is available now.

Your donation goes directly into research, supplies, and the documentation of the projects. Upon successful completion, the designs will be made publicly available and the work will shift to creating a "kit" for the whole system. The main focus is to create an efficient small-scale system that provides a source of nutrition and clean water with little effort. A beautiful and functional addition to any home. If you are interested in preparedness and sustainability, this campaign is for you.

This project incurs costs ranging from small supplies to access of prestigious medical and scientific journals. The equipment needed to test the water is one of the more costly aspects of the project. There are many other associated costs with construction and documentation of the project. On my own, my start-up company cannot take on the full investment at once and the need for fresh water and wholesome nutrition is growing rapidly. I can complete this research/design project much faster and cheaper if I do this while I am volunteering in India.  That is why it is important to obtain supportive funding in order to complete it by this time next year.

The stand alone solar oven(s) will be donated to charity and the design will also be documented into a lesson format and would make a wonderful project for schools, camps, boyscouts etc. and will be FREE OF CHARGE.

I am thrilled to be in a position in my life where I can help others and believe we can all truly thrive naturally in this precious world. I hope you will join me in this journey with a donation, large or small.

R. Wright

LinkedIn Profile

Please note that if the goal is not met, the project will take longer to complete, as I will be funding it myself. Thus the design plans and/or kits will not be available as quickly. However, anyone who donates can opt for periodic updates on the progress my company is making with this project.
story_txt: "First it was necessary to civilize man in relation to man. Now it is necessary to civilize man in relation to nature and the animals". ~ Victor HugoEver since I was a small child I dreamed of a world where modern man could live in harmony with nature. As an adult, my volunteer work in India has brought me back to some of those core values.  I have a passion for spreading the word about alternative energy, water catchment purification, and other off-grid and affordable living practices. We CAN Thrive Naturally!!This campaign is aimed to raise money for chronicling my current project of a water purification system, a solar oven, and a small aquaponics system.I have been studying sustainable design for some time and am preparing for my certificate. My life goals include continuing on to achieve the diploma and teaching credentials and eventually open up my own school, offering courses online at a much more affordable rate than is available now.Your donation goes directly into research, supplies, and the documentation of the projects. Upon successful completion, the designs will be made publicly available and the work will shift to creating a "kit" for the whole system. The main focus is to create an efficient small-scale system that provides a source of nutrition and clean water with little effort. A beautiful and functional addition to any home. If you are interested in preparedness and sustainability, this campaign is for you.This project incurs costs ranging from small supplies to access of prestigious medical and scientific journals. The equipment needed to test the water is one of the more costly aspects of the project. There are many other associated costs with construction and documentation of the project. On my own, my start-up company cannot take on the full investment at once and the need for fresh water and wholesome nutrition is growing rapidly. I can complete this research/design project much faster and cheaper if I do this while I am volunteering in India.  That is why it is important to obtain supportive funding in order to complete it by this time next year.The stand alone solar oven(s) will be donated to charity and the design will also be documented into a lesson format and would make a wonderful project for schools, camps, boyscouts etc. and will be FREE OF CHARGE.I am thrilled to be in a position in my life where I can help others and believe we can all truly thrive naturally in this precious world. I hope you will join me in this journey with a donation, large or small.R. WrightLinkedIn ProfilePlease note that if the goal is not met, the project will take longer to complete, as I will be funding it myself. Thus the design plans and/or kits will not be available as quickly. However, anyone who donates can opt for periodic updates on the progress my company is making with this project.

story:
Community Rights is “…the beginning of a social movement that is greater than just the oil and gas industry, it is a potential game changer for all of corporate America”.

– New Mexico Independent Petroleum Association

Who We Are 

The Colorado Community Rights Network is a grassroots organization that was established in 2013 to fight corporate power and push legal changes to protect Colorado communities.

We are working at the local level by assisting communities to write laws that defend them from inherently dangerous industrial projects. These local "Bills of Rights" challenge the corporate laws that jeopardize our communities’ safety and democratic decision-making.

Building local power upward, we are working at the state level to drive state constitutional change. If we succeed in this campaign, we will rewrite the Colorado state constitution to include our Colorado Community Rights Amendment, which would be a first of its kind victory to build local democracy and civil rights protections against state and corporate power.

How will the funding be used?

Funds will go towards our commitment to getting the Colorado Community Rights Amendment onto the state ballot in 2016.

We need:

* Paid organizers

* Paid petition circulators

* Promotional materials

* Legal defense funds

* Allowances for travel expenses

* Mainstream advertising

In campaigning for its adoption into the Colorado Constitution, we will have to overcome tens of millions of dollars in corporate spending. It is not impossible to do, but the scale of this effort and its national implications mean we need your help!

Our Network

Nationally, we are connected to the greater Community Rights Movement that is now operating in over eight states and growing rapidly. With the help of the Community Environmental Legal Defense Fund, this movement has written and enacted over 160 local “Bills of Rights” across the country. These Bills of Rights serve to protect individuals and communities from corporate activities such as fracking, mega-mining, factory farming, sewage sludge dumping, GMO farming, pesticides, and many more.

The Colorado Community Rights Network has volunteers in over 20 Colorado cities and has gained national media attention for our efforts. Thanks to our work in drafting the first proposed state level Community Rights Amendment, we are on the leading edge of the national Community Rights Movement.


What is the Colorado Community Rights Amendment?

The Colorado Community Rights Amendment will give local communities...

“(a) the power to enact local laws protecting health, safety, and welfare by establishing the fundamental rights of individuals, their communities, and nature, and by securing those rights using prohibitions and other means; and

(b) the power to enact local laws establishing, defining, altering, or eliminating the rights, powers, and duties of corporations and other business entities operating or seeking to operate in the community, to prevent such rights and powers from interfering with such locally-enacted fundamental rights of individuals, their communities, and nature.”

Where are we now?

In May of 2014, the Colorado Community Rights Amendment was found to meet all legal requirements of a state ballot initiative by the Colorado Supreme Court. It will be submitted to the state of Colorado in January of 2015, and in Spring of 2015 we will begin the legal process of signature gathering to make it onto the 2016 ballot.

This will not be easy. We are given a six month period to collect the 125,000 necessary signatures. (About 86,000 validated signatures from registered Colorado voters are actually required by the state, but 125,000 allows for the requisite buffer of rejected signatures.) It is critical to note that no state level ballot initiative in Colorado has ever made it to the polls on the backs of volunteers alone. That’s why we need your donations.


What are the ramifications of the Colorado Community Rights Amendment?

The Colorado Community Rights Amendment is the first of its kind, and will be a historic effort in creating profound and fundamental legal challenge to corporate rule in Colorado. It is attached to both local and national grassroots organizing efforts, and is a hallmark campaign to push changes to a system of law that is written to serve the interests of multinational corporations. The state Amendment and the local Community Bills of Rights that are being enacted are legally binding, and serve to define and enforce local democratic decision making to protect our civil and basic human rights.

Why is the Colorado Community Rights Amendment relevant to people and communities outside of Colorado?

The Colorado Community Rights Amendment directly challenges the long-standing legal power of corporations that are using state level laws to supercede and override community voices. All of the laws being used to sue Colorado communities that have banned fracking, for example, have similar or identical versions in other states. The Colorado Community Rights Amendment will set a nationwide precedent for fighting these corporate laws. We are creating a model that can be used by all other states to protect the health, welfare and safety of their people.

What successes has the Colorado Community Rights Network had toward the establishment of community rights over corporate power?

In November of 2013, Lafayette, Colorado became the first Colorado community to pass a Community Bill of Rights. In doing so, the people of Lafayette enacted a local law that illegalized oil and gas activity within their community, but also defined a set of rights that included the right to clean air and water and the right to local self determination. The Lafayette Community Rights Amendment goes even further, and illegalizes corporate personhood for oil and gas industries,  as well as prohibits the disposal of associated industrial waste in that town.

The law passed by over 60% of the vote, and through this campaign Lafayette citizens elected two city councilors that currently stand for community rights and are defending the community vote. Councilor Merrily Mazza is one of these candidates and is featured in our video.

Since that time, the Colorado Community Rights Network has enlisted volunteers in over 20 Colorado cities to build the community rights effort both locally and statewide. In May of 2014, we defeated legal challenges by the Colorado Mining Association against the language of the Colorado Community Rights Amendment, and became the first grassroots group in the state to establish the language of a binding constitutional amendment to concretely challenge and alter corporate power in Colorado.

What are the challenges involved in this organizing?

Building a movement that creates concrete, democratic challenges to the laws written on behalf of major industries invariably finds powerful opposition. We are certain to be met with major funding from corporate entities, combative advertising campaigns, and periods where the odds seem stacked against us. However, the same was true during movements for the abolition of slavery, women’s suffrage and civil rights.


How are we going to overcome these hurdles?

These major challenges have already started to be overcome by the grassroots efforts of Colorado citizens and in local elections. Even the money spent by the oil and gas industry has been unreliable in confusing the topic and influencing the common people of Colorado. This has corporations and politicians very worried.

Building on these local victories, the Colorado Community Rights Network with help from the Community Environmental Legal Defense Fund, has now created the foundation of a genuine movement. We have a legal team that is amongst the best in the nation, and through our connections with other community rights networks across the country, have the basis for driving the conversation and pushing fundamental legal challenges upward from Colorado to the US Constitution. What happens in Colorado will not stay in Colorado, and we aim to take our victories to your community and state.

Ways you can help:

* Donate to the Colorado Community Rights Network and our campaign to place community rights over corporate power.

* Get the word out!!! Share this page on social media using the IndieGoGo share tools.

* Get involved here:

https://www.thedatabank.com/dpg/568/personal2.a...

* Frequent our website to be kept up to date with announcements and organizing efforts: www.cocrn.org

* Email us to have a speaker come to present on community rights in your town: CoCommRIghts@gmail.com

* Volunteer to be a petition circulator in the campaign for Colorado Community Rights, set to launch officially in the spring of 2015!!!



Colorado Community Rights Network

Colorado Community Rights Network

story:
Summary
Starting on July 2nd 2014 we will be embarking on a 2,500km, two month long bike expedition from Victoria, British Columbia to San Diego, California. The purpose of our trip is to contribute to the protection of wildlife on the Pacific Coast through raising awareness and funds. 100% of the proceeds go directly to Pacific Wild, a non-profit organization devoted to protecting British Columbia’s Great Bear Rainforest, the largest intact temperate rainforest on earth. We will also be sharing the natural beauty of the Pacific Coast through our photographs which will be posted on our Ride for the Wild blog throughout the trip. High resolution photographs and printed photographs will also be offered at the end of our trip as perks to those who donate. Our other perks include the Jamming the Pipeline Compilation CD and 4 acclaimed films from the Great Bear Rainforest on DVD.

Our Inspiration + Cause
 Our expedition is largely inspired by the proposition of the Enbridge Northern Gateway pipeline (OFFICIALLY APPROVED JUNE 17th) which poses as a great threat to the pristine wildlife of British Columbia. The proposition includes a twin pipeline, one carrying diluted bitumen west from the Alberta tar sands to the port of Kitimat and the other carrying toxic gas condensate eastward to Alberta. The combined distance of the proposed twin pipelines equals approximately 2,400km so we have decided to make it our goal to surpass this distance and bike along the Pacific Coast to San Diego. The pipeline would cut through the Rocky Mountains and into the Great Bear Rainforest, crossing more than 800 rivers and threatening the habitats of keystone species on land and in water. The pipeline would also bring heavy amounts of supertanker traffic to one of the trickiest marine routes on earth to ship 450 million barrels of oil to Asia every year. The Great Bear Rainforest is one of the largest remaining tracts of unspoiled temperate rainforest in the world and could be completely destroyed by a pipeline or tanker oil spill.

About Pacific Wild
Pacific Wild is a registered non-profit organization located on the Central Coast of British Columbia that supports innovative scientific research, public education, community outreach and awareness to achieve the goal of lasting environmental protection in the lands and waters of the Great Bear Rainforest. Donations will help support Pacific Wild's innovative projects including the Great Bear LIVE field cameras and the Great Bear Sea Hydrophone Network which transmit live wildlife video and audio streams from the heart of the Great Bear Rainforest to the internet for public viewing. This year Pacific Wild's underwater and above water cameras captured wolves fishing for salmon, resident killer whales, black bears, hatching seagull chicks, Steller sea lions, seals fishing and spawning herring. To watch or listen to these live streams or to learn more about Pacific Wild’s efforts to protect the Great Bear rainforest visit pacificwild.org.

About Us

We are Geoff and Mikhayla, two students studying photography and design at Emily Carr University in Vancouver, British Columbia. We have both spent most of our lives in British Columbia where we have developed a strong passion for the environment and a growing desire to protect it. We are also bike enthusiasts and avid riders in in the Greater Vancouver area and on Vancouver Island. However this trip will be our first big cycle tour and we are so excited to tackle this challenge. Through our online blog we will be sharing the progress of our trip and showcasing our photographic exploration of the Pacific Coast.

See some of Mikhayla's photos here.
See some of Geoff's photos here.

story:
Due to a historic drought, California's fire season started this year in December- 9 months earlier than normal

TRAILS IS ...a ballet and aerial dance performance by Luminario Ballet about climate change effects on the California environment.
TRAILS is a website by Luminario Ballet and other artists with an interactive forum bulletin board where people can ask questions, offer solutions, and arrange meet ups for their environmental activities-- from school beach clean ups, to neighborhood planning meetings, to companies wanting help to green their buildings or surroundings.

TRAILS is also a short film which will be easily delivered to schools interested in how the arts and sciences work together to communicate important ideas via dance and images about climate change in our world, and how we can preserve it.

TRAILS will diagram Fire, Flood, Earthquake, and Traffic, through dance, aerial dance; and project on stage images of our planet's gorgeous landscape and environment from the International Space Station, from the NASA website, allowing all of us to see the big picture of what we want to save and cherish.

We will connect TRAILS with environmental information sites at Princeton and Yale (climate change websites), and other sites where concerned people are coming together.

California's climate is a desert, similar to the Middle East

Help us raise $25,000 for production costs of TRAILS

What the money goes to:

  • funds raised will pay production costs of this performance including: performance and rehearsal pay for dancers and aerialists; rehearsal studio, venue, and marketing costs; website creation and maintenance; choreographers; visuals;  the TRAILS film, and the TRAILS curriculum.
  • TRAILS supporters will receive posters, DVDs, show tickets, Gala Tickets, and invitations to attend Luminario Ballet in rehearsal.
  • Luminario Ballet is dedicated to presenting TRAILS this year and will present  Works In Progress portions of TRAILS in our repertory shows, festivals, and guest appearances as funds are found to produce the entire project.

The polar vortex gave us our coldest winter in recorded history

TRAILS brings performers, science, and the public together to do something about climate change

TRAILS will demonstrate the impact of climate change on California.

TRAILS the website will allow us to get together to make a difference.

  • As performing artists, we are dedicated to making the world a place where we can exchange ideas. As dancers, we communicate about important things without words, across cultures. TRAILS is for us to share our urgent desire to implement real, positive change in our environmental stewardship.
  • Luminario Ballet has performed for over 30,000 audience members in less than 5 years- and we intend to share TRAILS with all, young, old, black, white, rich, or poor, to get everyone involved to make a difference.
  • TRAILS can be your own personal environmental project, or your school's project, or your company's project, and you can use TRAILS to bring up the subject of good environmental stewardship and positive action.

Fresh water- our most precious resource- yet we have no infrastructure to catch and store it when it rains, so, it floods.


Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute funds to TRAILS we still need your help!

  • SHARE the TRAILS indiegogo campaign with your friends, office, school, and family, via email, social media, and good ol' fashioned conversation.
  • provide us with what you can do: provide your theater for performance!
  • donate costumes or other services or goods to our production!
  • help us make our videos and website!
  • VOLUNTEER to help Luminario Ballet present TRAILS! We welcome volunteers in the office, rehearsal studio, theater, and around town. It always takes a village to run a dance company and we always need your help! Email us at: luminarioballet@yahoo.com if you want to volunteer, and put "volunteer for TRAILS" in your subject line.

story:
(Se encuentra la traducción en Español mas hacia abajo)

What does Cántaro Azul do?

Cántaro: Cantaro Azul’s is an organization in Chiapas, Mexico mission is to improve the health and well-being of people that live in marginalized communities.

Vision: to develop sustainable solutions that will benefit more than one million people in Mexico and contribute to strengthening the international water sector.

Anything else? Yes! Cántaro Azul integrates a communication strategy to involve the communities to participate in the sustainable management of water resources.

The organization is doing amazing work in the communities of Chiapas, Mexico through the implemented programs and local staff. if you want to learn more about the organization, check out http://www.cantaroazul.org/.

What will I be doing?

 

I will be working on a few projects in San Cristobal de Las Casas and rural communities in the surrounding area.

 1. I will create a strategy for Cántaro Azul to have a greater impact at local water distribution centers.

2. I will be working to develop the activities that Cántaro Azul uses to educate people from all ages on the provision and management of a water system and the sanitation and health benefits of treated water.

3. I will collaborate with a research partner on developing and implementing activities for women to learn about safe water sanitation practices.

I am looking forward to learning about the local culture in San Cristobal de Las Casas and contributing to Cántaro Azul’s impact on the community.

 

Want to partner with me?

First and foremost, thanks for taking the time to read this!

Secondly, a way for you to help support me would be through a monetary contribution.  In order to research and serve for six weeks, I will need to raise $1870.00 each. The expenses include transportation, housing and living, and prepaid cell phone costs. Please consider giving – any amount will be extremely helpful for my fundraising efforts.  

Last but not least, help me spread the word! Not just about my project, but also about Cántaro Azul's amazing work in Chiapas! 

 

¿Qué hace Cántaro Azul?

La misión: Cántaro Azul es una organización establecida en Chiapas, México que tiene la misión de mejorar la salud y la calidad de vida de personas que viven en comunidades marginadas.

La visión: La visión de la organización para cinco años es generar soluciones que beneficien de manera significativa y sostenible a más de un millón de personas en México y que contribuyan al enriquecimiento del sector del agua a nivel internacional.

 ¿Algo mas? Si! Cántaro Azul integra una estrategia de comunicación que involucra las comunidades a participar en el manejo sostenible de recursos de agua.

La organización esta haciendo trabajos increíbles en las comunidades de Chiapas, México a través de la implementación de programas y empleados en el alrededor.

Si quiere saber mas acerca de la organización, visite la pagina http://www.cantaroazul.org/.

 

¿Que haré yo?

 Yo trabajaré en algunos proyectos en San Cristóbal de Las Casas y en comunidades rurales en el alrededor.

 1.Yo crearé una estrategia para que Cántaro Azul tenga un impacto profundo en el quisco central de distribución de agua.

 2. Yo trabajaré en desarrollar las actividades que Cántaro Azul hace para educar gente de todas edades en la provisión y manejo del sistema de agua y las ventajas de agua purificada en higiénicas y de la salud.

 3. Yo colaboraré con una compañera en desarrollar e implementar actividades para mujeres en la educación de hábitos de la sanidad.

 

¿Quiere ser compañero conmigo?

¡En primer lugar, gracias por leer acerca de mi plan!

En segundo lugar, una manera en que me podrá ayudar es en el apoyo monetario. Para hacer investigaciones y servir por seis semanas, necesito recaudar $1870.00. Los gastos son para transportación, la vivienda, y los costos del celular. Porf avor considere donar – cualquier cantidad será increíblemente útil para mis esfuerzos de recaudar fondos.

 En fin, ayúdenme promover esta información! No solo acerca de mi proyecto, pero también acerca del trabajo increíble de Cántaro Azul en Chiapas!
story_txt:
(Se encuentra la traducción en Español mas hacia abajo)
What does Cántaro Azul do?
Cántaro: Cantaro Azul’s is an organization in Chiapas, Mexico mission is to improve the health and well-being of people that live in marginalized communities.
Vision: to develop sustainable solutions that will benefit more than one million people in Mexico and contribute to strengthening the international water sector.
Anything else? Yes! Cántaro Azul integrates a communication strategy to involve the communities to participate in the sustainable management of water resources.
The organization is doing amazing work in the communities of Chiapas, Mexico through the implemented programs and local staff. if you want to learn more about the organization, check out http://www.cantaroazul.org/.
What will I be doing?
 
I will be working on a few projects in San Cristobal de Las Casas and rural communities in the surrounding area. 
 1. I will create a strategy for Cántaro Azul to have a greater impact at local water distribution centers.
2. I will be working to develop the activities that Cántaro Azul uses to educate people from all ages on the provision and management of a water system and the sanitation and health benefits of treated water. 
3. I will collaborate with a research partner on developing and implementing activities for women to learn about safe water sanitation practices.
I am looking forward to learning about the local culture in San Cristobal de Las Casas and contributing to Cántaro Azul’s impact on the community.
 
Want to partner with me?
First and foremost, thanks for taking the time to read this!
Secondly, a way for you to help support me would be through a monetary contribution.  In order to research and serve for six weeks, I will need to raise $1870.00 each. The expenses include transportation, housing and living, and prepaid cell phone costs. Please consider giving – any amount will be extremely helpful for my fundraising efforts.  

Last but not least, help me spread the word! Not just about my project, but also about Cántaro Azul's amazing work in Chiapas!

story:
Our Story

The 91 foot, tall ship Quinnipiack has been a fixture in New Haven Harbor and Long Island Sound since 1990. Her goal is to increase environmental literacy. This is accomplished by providing educational programs for schools and public sails for the community.


Running a traditional wooden boat takes a lot of work and maintenance. This campaign will help provide the funds need for her biennial haul out and US Coast Guard inspection. This will include replacing planks, covering boards and top timbers. We will finish off with a new coat of protective marine paint.


The Impact

Reaching our goal and being able to complete our haul-out would mean that Quinnipiack can continue providing a great learning experience for the communities on Long Island Sound. If we are not able to complete our goal the future of the ship will be uncertain.


What We Need & What You Get

Below is a breakdown of where the money goes to and a brief explanation of each item for those who might not be familiar with the terminology.


$4000 Hauling and Launching- Taking the boat out of the water and putting it back in.

$3000 Lumber and Fasteners- The wood needed for repairs and the hardware to attach it

$1000 marine coating- Special primer and paint for boats

$6000 Shipwright fees- These are the skilled professionals that specialize in traditional boat repairs

$2000 Tool Rentals

$2000 Crew Housing- While the boat is under repairs the crew cannot live on-board

$1000 Crew Provisions- Food, gloves, dust masks, paper coverall suits,etc....

$1000 Waste disposal- Everything scraped and taken off the bottom of the boat must be properly disposed of in an environmentally friendly manner



Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you can't make a donation you can help by spreading the word. Pass this along to all of your friends and coworkers. Use the share buttons. We are also accepting volunteers to help with the haul-out process.

story:
The story

So once there was this mountain in Africa. 

And highly endangered black rhinos (2,500 left in the whole world endangered)

And a bunch of interesting women decided to climb the one to save the other. 

There was a climate scientist, and a 12-year-old mountain rescuer, and a Hemingway.

And for each of the 19,341 steps up the mountain each of them would be thinking: 

 

“Eye of the tiger, eye of the tiger.”

 

And also, wow! We’re doing something good.

And we’re so glad our friends are here with us…witnessing…joining in...cheering us on.

Those friends: you.

 

We’re paying for 100% of the trip. The request: Help us move the mountain. Sponsor one segment of the climb and kick in for the rhinos.

 

Read more details about (the trek) and exactly how the money helps here (this really is worth a read...it's amazingly well articulated.)

 

 

How this works and what you'll see on the trek up the mountain (from photos and SocialCam feed):

During the 12 day climb, we'll pass through 5 different climate zones, plus the volcanic crater/summit.

 

Sponsor one segment of the climb...one climate zone...

1. Bushland - Villages. Banana plantations. Local tribes

2. Rainforest  - 90 degrees. Sweat-tastic. Monkeys!

3. Moorland - Heathers and shrubs. Starting to get cold.

4. Alpine desert - Lunar landscape. Giant cacti. Other, uh, things.

5. Arctic Zone - Disappearing glaciers. Things that scientists geek out over.  

6. Volcanic crater & the peak - Then 15 minutes of fame at the top. 

 

What is needed & what you get

 

What is needed:

- Your generosity

- Sponsor one segment of the climb...one climate zone

 

In exchange for:

- Fabulous-ish prizes!

- Commentary from a climate scientist

- My brand of comedy - it may involve pee

- A great sense of self-worth and my undying gratitude

 

NOTE:  100% will go to Mkomazi Rhino Sanctuary and Climb for Conservation 501(c)(3)

 

"When one tugs at a single thing in nature, he finds it attached to the rest of the world." - John Muir

story:
WE ARE PULLING DOWN THIS SITE, BUT WILL     RETURN IN OCTOBER SO PLEASE DO NOT CONTRIBUTE!

                        PLEASE CHECK BACK LATER!!!

 

THE BOTTLED WATER INDUSTRY HAS VERY SUCCESSFULLY TURNEDA PUBLIC RESOURCE INTO A PRIVATE COMMODITY! 

Each WaterStop cart's tank carries 50 gallons = 400 -16oz of bottles of water. Refilling it is easy, a common hose and any local public water system can be used to refill the tank....it takes around 8-10 minutes. 

       THE BEGINNING OF THE REFILL REVOLUTION!

Bottled water is a world wide problem and we fully expect to adapt our carts for the international market. Our first program however is in the U.S. with a leasing and sponsorship program for our under funded schools and universities to address the pollution of our school's water. A big issues in all 50 states.... More on this program below

The Pacific Institute estimates that production of bottled water for U.S. consumption in 2006 required the equivalent of more than 17 million barrels of oil, not including the energy used for transportation. This released over 2.5 million tons of carbon dioxide, a major global warming gas. (These numbers have grown by 8.5% in 2012) It took three liters of water to produce one liter of bottled water. The total amount of energy embedded in the use of bottled water is the equivalent of filling a plastic bottle one quarter full of oil, according to the Pacific Institute.

In the U.S. more than 50 billion plastic water bottles are discarded each year. Only 15% are recycled; the rest end up in landfills, or as litter - 60 million every day. They can take 1,000 years to decompose and meanwhile they contribute to the vortex of plastic waste in the Pacific Garbage Patch, which may be twice the size of Texas.

             Bottled water can cost you 500 to 4,000 times more than tap water.

Hi, my name is Nan Harris; I am the founder and Acting CEO of WaterStop Carts LLC. The development of the company has been my passion for over two years now. How could we all not share the concerns of the health of our planet and our children? This is easy to say, but its really hard changing wasteful habits. I know, I’ve tried, but feeling guilty about it and making others feel guilty doesn’t change anything. I realized that I can only be responsible for my actions, but I could create a way to change one habit that we all share by providing a way to refill water bottles. I have put my money and passion into it and hope you will feel the same about it.

My background, 30 years in the entertainment industry, has little bearing on the water distribution industry. However, after years of working as an independent contractor, I realized that I had the skills and experience to create something new that could have a much more positive effect on the planet and all its inhabitants. This desire, to do something meaningful, lead me to sustainability and sustainability lead me to the idea of mobile water stations for refilling water bottles.... and that lead me to the creation of WaterStop Carts. 

As you can see from the video, we have completed the 1st prototype of our mobile water carts. We have created the basic unit with the digital banners for advertising. But there is still much more that needs to be done: Making the overall size smaller, as well as the electronics for wifi, video screen, and app. We need to add a new structure so we can add wheels that will allow the cart to be transported on roads. Making the unit look great will require a very expensive tooling process for the skin, but it is a one time cost. And finally getting the website up to date.

Our interested investors would like to see the final prototype. So completing the next unit is essential to the growth of the company. Without these investors onboard we have a great idea that has been realized, but no company to get it to the public. 

  • The greater portion of the funds raised (total $250,000) will go to the engineering and construction of the second prototype (estimated at $150,000). We have engaged Sigma Design for this stage (sigmadesign.net).
  • After the 2nd prototype is complete we will need to have written a user’s manual which will include all parts guarantees and warranties ($50,000ish).
  • After this is done we will apply for certification from the NSF (nsf.org) and other organizations like UL, this includes legal fees ($20,000)
  • And finally complete the website and update the video($20,000).

If we do not reach our funding goal, every penny will go to the steps needed to complete the 2nd prototype. The funds will allow us to get certain steps in engineering completed, most importantly, to get the drafting of electronics for the video screen and wifi. If we have to, we will dismantle the 1st prototype and reuse its parts, this allows us to skip certain costs.

Did you notice the collapsible, reusable bottle in the video with our name printed on it? We will be also selling these bottles along with the carts (venders can replace the money lost on selling bottled water by selling these bottles and offering free water refills, generating good will and return customers.) The bottles are feather weight and small; they can easily fit into a pocket, purse, or backpack and don’t add the extra bulk and weight of a typical reusable bottle. They are BPA free and dishwasher safe and are good for 1,000 opening and closings or about 3 years. They are great for kids (or anyone) to color on or write thier name on… They’re really cool! Unfortunately because of the cost involved in buying them, shipping and hiring someone to do this, the minimum donation to receive 2 bottles is a $500 contribution…sorry, I wish we could afford to get one to every contributor!!

The other perk we can offer will be your name listed under the producer credits on the final video, a position on our permanent founders list, and our heartfelt thanks!

HERE IS MORE INFORMATION ON THE COMPANY:

Changing the Way We Consume Water by Creating a New Delivery System:

WaterStop Carts is a socially responsible, for-profit company based on the simple proposition that people around the world need safe, accessible and affordable water sources. We seek to address the discrepancy between demand and access by filtering municipal tap water for taste as well as removing impurities. Making it available to the public through our mobile water-carts is our goal.

“Accessibility through Mobility”

This is the foundation of our thinking. Refilling bottles will save consumers, businesses and governments the extraordinary amount of money spent daily on purchasing and recycling plastic water bottles (The US spent $21.7 billion in 2011). Equally as important our water-carts will help eliminate the daily 60 million plastic bottles (50 billion a year!) that go into our landfills and oceans from the U.S. alone.

Our mobile carts will go where people go, venues of all kinds:

Entertainment venues like Disneyland, Concerts and Sports Stadiums,

National and Local Parks

Golf Courses, Street Fairs etc.

Educational Institutions

Hotels and Conference Spaces

City, County and Federal Office Complexes

Military Complexes

At Airports, carts will be placed beyond the security check points so people can refill their bottles or any drinking container

Crisis Management organizations like FEMA and the Red Cross. For these emergency services, carts can be used to replace bottled water and if needed distribute antibiotics in the water.  In third world countries food nutrients can be added to the cleansed water (carts manufactured outside the western world will be made using local materials and resources.)

The Beginning of a Refill Revolution:

Bottled water is a world wide problem and we fully expect to adapt our carts for the international market. Our first program however is in the U.S. with a leasing and sponsorship program for our under funded schools and universities. In 2010 the US congress mandated that schools provide free water sources to students, but they didn’t address either cost or access, did you know that kids have to buy bottled water in 95% of our schools? Forget about the water fountains that so many of us grew up with!

It is at these educational institutions that the movement toward sustainability is the strongest and the need for clean water is the greatest. In total, there are 112,000 public and private schools. In addition, there are almost 5,000 colleges with a combined total of 77 million students (2012). They comprise 27% of the entire population age 3 and older.

Over the last decade, the drinking water at thousands of schools across the country has been found to contain unsafe levels of lead, pesticides and dozens of other toxins. An Associated Press investigation found that contaminants have surfaced at public and private schools in all 50 states - in small towns and inner cities alike.

Children are especially susceptible to lead and copper exposure because their bodies absorb these metals at higher rates than the average adult. Exposure to high levels of lead can cause damage to the brain, red blood cells, and the kidneys. Exposure to even low levels of lead can cause low IQ, hearing impairment, reduced attention span and poor classroom performance.

States have indicated that they want to increase their efforts in ensuring that school drinking water is safe. However, almost all indicated that such an effort would not be possible for them to carry out in the absence of additional federal funding. WaterStop Carts is the answer, they provide students a supply of clean, tasty water through our sponsored mobile water carts and collapsible reusable water bottles. Mobility allows the carts to be stationed anywhere on campus. Water that has lead or other impurities can be easily decontaminated by changing the standard filter in the back of the unit.

Our Once and Future Customers will be the catalyst of the Refill Revolution:

At WaterStop we believe it is the Millennials who will build consumer loyalty, demand and brand for us. Sustainability and Environmental concern is already a major part of this generation’s thinking and way of life. Millennials are referred to as the sustainable generation.

These 77 million students, now in schools across the nation, will take into the future a demand for water refill stations. WaterStop is building a future customer base, insuring the growth of the company, as well as making enormous environmental strides.

There are many ways you can help besides financial donations! Please pass our request for funding onto all your friends, family and associates. But, equally important, if you have contacts at organizations, that are appropriate for educational institutions, and think they would be interested in sponsoring carts at schools, please let them know about us!  You can do this through this site. 

One more thing...please keep this a secret from the bottled water industy...there not going to like us :)

Thank You for your Support!!!

In 2010 the US congress mandated that schools provide free water sources to students, but they didn’t address either cost or access, did you know that kids have to buy bottled water in 95% of our schools? Forget about the water fountains that so many of us grew up with!
It is at these educational institutions that the movement toward sustainability is the strongest and the need for clean water is the greatest. In total, there are 112,000 public and private schools. In addition, there are almost 5,000 colleges with a combined total of 77 million students (2012). They comprise 27% of the entire population age 3 and older.
Over the last decade, the drinking water at thousands of schools across the country has been found to contain unsafe levels of lead, pesticides and dozens of other toxins. An Associated Press investigation found that contaminants have surfaced at public and private schools in all 50 states - in small towns and inner cities alike.
Children are especially susceptible to lead and copper exposure because their bodies absorb these metals at higher rates than the average adult. Exposure to high levels of lead can cause damage to the brain, red blood cells, and the kidneys. Exposure to even low levels of lead can cause low IQ, hearing impairment, reduced attention span and poor classroom performance.
States have indicated that they want to increase their efforts in ensuring that school drinking water is safe. However, almost all indicated that such an effort would not be possible for them to carry out in the absence of additional federal funding. WaterStop Carts is the answer, they provide students a supply of clean, tasty water through our sponsored mobile water carts and collapsible reusable water bottles. Mobility allows the carts to be stationed anywhere on campus. Water that has lead or other impurities can be easily decontaminated by changing the standard filter in the back of the unit.
Our Once and Future Customers will be the catalyst of the Refill Revolution:
At WaterStop we believe it is the Millennials who will build consumer loyalty, demand and brand for us. Sustainability and Environmental concern is already a major part of this generation’s thinking and way of life. Millennials are referred to as the sustainable generation.
These 77 million students, now in schools across the nation, will take into the future a demand for water refill stations. WaterStop is building a future customer base, insuring the growth of the company, as well as making enormous environmental strides.
There are many ways you can help besides financial donations! Please pass our request for funding onto all your friends, family and associates. But, equally important, if you have contacts at organizations, that are appropriate for educational institutions, and think they would be interested in sponsoring carts at schools, please let them know about us!  You can do this through this site. 
One more thing...please keep this a secret from the bottled water industy...there not going to like us :)
Thank You for your Support!!!

story:
* English below

Présentation du projet

La première habitation Earthship adaptée au climat québécois, homologuée par Michael Reynolds et assistée par Earthship Biotecture sera en construction au Rond Coin à Saint-Élie-de-Caxton du 8 au 26 septembre 2014.


Le Rond Coin à Sainte-Élie-de-Caxton


Lors de la construction, le Rond Coin s’est joint à Solution ERA afin d’accueillir une Académie sur les Earthships et les technologies du futur. Le but poursuivi par cette initiative est de permettre aux habitants de la région d’expérimenter un chantier de solidarité Earthship tout en se familiarisant avec ce type de construction écologique et humanitaire.

En plus d’offrir aux clients du Rond Coin un nouveau type d’habitation d’expérience, nous démontrerons la pertinence d’adapter les Earthships au climat froid et humide du Québec et leur efficacité.


Les 6 principes des Earthships

1.Chauffage & Climatisation passive

2.Électricité solaire et éolienne

3.Traitement des eaux usées sur place

4.Construire avec des matériaux naturels & recyclés

5.Récolte de l’eau de pluie

6.Production alimentaire


La campagne

Notre campagne de financement Indiegogo vise à amasser 30 000$ de dons afin de:

-  Finaliser les plans que nous avons commencé à dessiner avec Michael Reynolds, l’inventeur des Earthships ;

-  Recevoir le soutien de Earthship Biotecture sur le terrain lors de la construction ;

-  Faire l’achat des matériaux et des outils manquants pour le chantier.

Si nous amassons des surplus lors de la campagne nous utiliserons ces fonds supplémentaires pour agrémenter l’aménagement intérieur et l’aménagement paysager autour du Earthship.


Simple Survival 1&2 NM photo de Jocoah Sorensen


Ce que ça signifie nous aider

Non seulement votre contribution financière au projet nous aidera grandement, mais avec celle-ci et en partageant cette page, vous participerez au mouvement visant à promouvoir la propagation des Earthships tant au Québec qu’à travers le monde!


***********************************


Presentation of the project

The first Earthship adapted to Québec’s climate, approved by Michael Reynolds and with the assistance of Earthship Biotecture will be built at Le Rond Coin in Saint-Élie-de-Caxton from 8 to 26 September 2014.



Le Rond Coin at Sainte-Élie-de-Caxton

During the construction, Le Rond Coin will be working in association with Solution ERA to offer an Academy on Earthships and future technologies. The aim of this initiative is to enable people to experience an Earthship solidarity jobsite while familiarizing themselves with this type of humanitarian and ecological construction.


Here are the six design principles of an Earthship

1.  Thermal/Solar Heating & Cooling

2.  Solar & Wind Electricity

3.  Contained Sewage Treatment

4.  Building with Natural & Recycled Materials

5.  Water Harvesting

6.  Food Production

 

The Campaign

Our Indiegogo fundraising campaign aims to raise $ 30,000 donation to:

- Finalize plans we started drawing with Michael Reynolds, inventor of Earthships;

- Receive support from Earthship Biotecture on the jobsite during the construction;

- To purchase materials and tools for the jobsite.

If we raise more then our campaigns objective we will use these additional funds to improvements the interior design and landscaping around the Earthship.


What it means to help

Not only your contribution to the project will help us greatly, but also with it and by sharing this page, you will participate in the movement to promote the propagation of Earthships in Quebec and around the world! 


Simple Survival 1&2 NM photo by Jocoah Sorensen

story:
On October 10th, C.H Ruby and her fisherfolk family were evicted from their home in Ganjam district of Odisha, India. They were removed by Government forces and shifted to an ill-equipped relief shelter in order to save their lives from the advancing cyclone that was to hit them very soon. Two nights after the cyclone passed, she made her way back to the village only to discover that her house and her belongings were swept away by the merciless gusts of the cyclone, lost forever. Ruby had survived the cyclone, now the challenge was to survive the aftermath.

One can only imagine the mental anguish of experiencing your life's savings disappear in a momentary fury of climate change. To not have a roof over your head, to lose your only source of income, and to be driven to scrounge for survival, it's doesn't feel fair what's happening to them. Rebuilding the lives of Ruby, her family, and thousands of survivors like her is an uphill yet urgent task.

Phailin relief is a campaign that is being run by 350.org and Council of Social Action (CoSA, www.cosaindia.org) 350.org is a global climate campaigns organisation that is building a grassroots movement to tackle the climate crisis. 350.org's local partner Council of Social Action works on various livelihood and empowerment programs in the villages of Odisha.

What We Need & What You Get

Our initial target is 10,000 USD or approx. 6 Lakh Indian Rupees. Your contribution in the following denominations can provide -

Rs 600 or 10 USD - Food for a family of 4 for 10 days

Rs 1000 or ~20 USD - Will provide fishing nets for a family or a temporary shelter material

Rs 1200 or 20 USD - Solar lanterns for lighting

Rs 2500 or 40 USD - Land development and agricultural assistance for 1 family

Rs 6000 or 100 USD - Basic child nutrition, clothing and a school students kit for 10 kids

Rs 10000 or ~200 USD - More of the above for more families and survivors

We aim to support 1000 families across 25 villages affected by cyclone Phailin. 

Perks

a. Every donor will be mentioned on our 350.org website as a valuable contributor to this campaign

b. Those who donate 200 USD or more will receive 350 merchandise

c. Those who donate 1000 USD or more will receive merchandise and have an option to visit the impacted communities and witness the impact of their donation *conditions apply.

The Impact

CoSA has extensively toured the communities impacted by cyclone Phailin and has a good track record of engaging with the people on various socio-economic programs. Phailin relief is aimed at achieving three broad objectives

a. Raising money and resources for restoring peoples livelihoods in Odisha 

b. Helping connect the dots between Phailin and Climate Change

c. Demanding climate adaptation in affected areas of Odisha

The second and third objectives will be worked on by 350.org and CoSA respectively. 350.org has been working on public mobilisation around climate change and helping people connect the dots between extreme weather disasters like Phailin, Haiyan, Uttarakhand floods etc and climate change. Making these connections is important to move our leaders to realise the urgency of global warming and drastically reduce our carbon emissions.

CoSA and its convenor Santosh Pattnaik will be working with the local administration of the district and impress upon them the need for enhanced climate adaptation for such disasters in the future.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are unable to contribute, please share the message with your friends and family. Use the various tools available on this page to share it across different social platforms. Please urge them to contribute, whatever they can to help achieve the objectives or our Phailin Relief campaign.  

You can promote the campaign by sharing the following graphics on your social networks
