story:
We are Environomica NGO and for the past 3 years we've been working to protect forests while supporting rural communities around the world. This year, with the help of local partners, we have selected two areas in Colombia of critical ecological importance to pilot innovative land management models: by bringing together the people and their environment, we foster a sustainable local economy that will lift villagers out of poverty while protecting their ecosystems.

Tree seedlings ready to be planted – Local farmer with indigenous rice harvest

In order to do so we need your help! Project 1 is an alliance with the Global Heritage Fund to restore ecological corridors in the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta by subtracting portions of forest to unrestrained clearing and by reorganizing agriculture in conjunction with the locals. Project 2 is a green business model based on reforestation, bioremediation and responsible ecotourism to support household income in the Sierra Nevada del Cocuy. 


Where does your donation go?

We need € 7.800 (50% of total budget) to equip two tree nurseries and two project headquarters, which will pave the way to the success of our projects. We'll keep you up to date with our progress via email and our Facebook page, providing photos of the finished nursery and headquarters.


The impact

The inception of our two projects will generate an appreciable impact. Nursery and headquarters will become the foundations of our forestry projects in Colombia. These preliminary actions will strengthen network ties among project stakeholders and lay down the base for both projects to be majorly funded as to achieve each individual overarching goal.


What is Environomica?

We are a group of experts in various fields committed to integrate solutions for the conservation of our planet with local, sustainable development. We started Environomica because we witnessed that neither traditional NGOs nor international agencies or governments had been able to provide solutions that could satisfy the needs of both people and the planet.

Information about us and our on-going projects is available at www.environomica.org

Information about the Global Heritage Fund is available at http://globalheritagefund.org/



...MOREOVER…




The Environomica Non-profit Concept


As a way of thanking you for your kind support we will reward you with one picture of your choice out of our photography gallery. Prints will be sent out to you as postcards, posters, bags or canvas depending on the level of support.

Check out the perks on the right sidebar for more details.


The projects in a nutshell


S.F.E.C. Project – Sustainable Livelihoods and Forest Ecosystem Conservation, Colombia

The Buritaca river basin, located in the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta (SNSM), Department of Magdalena, contains only one of 36 rivers flowing through the local Sierra. Roughly 1.2 million people are dependent upon the freshwater supplied by the SNSM rivers. In 2013, the Sierra was identified as the most irreplaceable bio-region in the world for threatened species. In the aftermath of the Colombian armed conflicts, farmers in the Buritaca basin are thriving at the expense of nature through uncontrolled cattle-ranching, land clearing, poaching, and irresponsible eco-tourism. Environomica sets out to restore ecological corridors by subtracting portions of forest to unrestrained clearing and by reorganizing agriculture in conjunction with the locals.

The S.F.E.C. Project has three additional partners to Environomica. ASOTEYUNA (Association of Community Sustainable Tourism) operates for the progress and welfare of the farmer and indigenous families living in the Ciudad Perdida region and will provide coordination with the tour guides in the Sierra. Global Heritage Fund Colombia, who manages the Ciudad Perdida Archaeological Park in partnership with the Colombian Institute for Anthropology and History, will engage the local indigenous and farmer communities as major stakeholders in the project. Fundación Pez León, a Colombian non-governmental and non-profit organization focused on the conservation of marine, coastal and forest ecosystems, will assist the project with logistics, cultural adaptation, and guidance.


S.M.E.C. Project – Sustainable Montane Paramo Ecotourism, Colombia

The Sierra Nevada del Cocuy, Department of Boyacá, is home to the country’s largest glacier and precious fresh water sources. The area has experienced a progressive upslope shift of subsistence farming which, in turn, has resulted in land degradation, soil impoverishment, water contamination and habitat transformation. Environomica has set up a green business model based on reforestation, bioremediation and responsible ecotourism to support household income in the area.

The S.M.E.C. Project has two additional partners to Environomica. Cabaña Guaicany is a family-run ecotourism business based in El Cocuy, Department of Boyacá, operating in the National Natural Park of the Sierra Nevada del Cocuy and owning a farm named ‘El Junco’, which will be the project pilot area. Fundación Pez León, a Colombian non-governmental and non-profit organization focused on the conservation of marine, coastal and forest ecosystems, will assist the project with logistics, cultural adaptation, and guidance. 


Projects Rationale


Our upcoming projects are based on the result of preliminary need assessments, which have been run in March 2015 by our team.

Both projects will tackle the following issues with respective strategic actions:


Problem 1: Unstable income sources for the inhabitants of remote natural areas

Problem 2: Land degradation, forest depletion, and water course contamination

Problem 3: Lack of vision for the sustainable management of land, water, and natural  resources


Action 1: FARMING will be organized to both to feed the community, reduce and OPTIMIZE farmland use, and generate INCOME via ORGANIC CROPS that can be locally processed and sold to financially SUPPORT the community and initiative alike.

Action 2: Purchased forestland will be registered as a “RESERVA NATURAL DE LA SOCIEDAD CIVIL” in order to protect the mega-diverse forest ecosystems, restore ECOLOGICAL CORRIDORS, and create the conditions for SCIENTIFIC TEAMS to study and assess biodiversity in the Sierra.

Action 3: On EACH project LOCATION we will secure FOUR HECTARES of forest as an initial conservation step and equip the projects with a TREE NURSERY. Nursery and headquarters will become the foundations of our forestry projects in Colombia. A straightforward nursery setup powered by our tropical agronomist and engineer, in conjunction with the locals, will enable secure short-term results.


The modular approach


Each successive project phase, as per Environomica’s modular approach to project implementation, will produce clear, distinctive impacts.


Phase 1 – Fundraising

This is where YOUR HELP is needed! Raising funds will enable us to start working on the field and lay down the base for OUR INITIATIVES

Phase 2 – Conservation

On EACH project LOCATION we will secure FOUR HECTARES of forest as an initial conservation step and equip the projects with a TREE NURSERY

Phase 3 – Agriculture

FARMING will be organized to both feed the community and generate ORGANIC CROPS that can be locally processed and sold to SUPPORT the initiative financially

Phase 4 – Handover

GOALS have been achieved, activities pay for themselves and the community is ready to take over: time to HANDOVER the initiative and REPLICATE it elsewhere


Why Environomica?


We have already established projects in Mozambique, Italy and Morocco where we could offer sustainable low cost solutions. Our expertise encompasses land and natural resource management, especially focusing on forest and water conservation, small-scale agriculture and social entrepreneurship.


Information about us and our on-going projects is available at www.environomica.org

Project mosaic. Pictures taken by our team on the project fields in Mozambique and Colombia.

story:
‘Raise the green Wall project’

The defined scope of Raise the Green wall is to Bring down the scope of the fight against climate change to the doorstep of every youth and passionate citizens across the federation whereby a platform for development and engagement is established through the scope of acting locally, thinking nationally, and subsequently globally. One major tool of adoption in the raise the green wall project is tree planting. And the aim is to ensure trees planting is integrated into the common sense of our society and a situation that would warrant the Government enforcing various regulations to ensuring the sustainability of tree planting and greening of the our environment. Thus the mitigation benefit of trees is enabled while the essential co-benefits help out with the adaptation side.

Raise the green wall however takes the form of climate change awareness creation, sensitization and actual practical volunteering engagement which is often in the form of tree planting campaign. All of these are complimentary in increasing the level of climate change education and awareness among the youths while building a chain of volunteers alongside and raising abundant stands of trees to serve as a landmark in the fight against climate change.

Primarily the reach-outs are streamlined to target youths in educational institutions, community youth association, youth wing of faith based organization.


How Donations will be used

The fund would be subjected to a judicious use in the regards of it appropriation in the procurement of materials and aids for the modification of the reach of the project. There are certain needs of the project which often limit the level of reach, the constant availability of facilitation aids such as a projector, public addressing system, mobile power generator, prints and teaching materials and lastly constant supply of tree seedlings and planting materials.

Breakdown:

Projector purchase: $1000

laptop purchase: $500

Mobile public address system: $300

Power generator: $ 200

Tree seedlings/ seed purchase : $500


Volunteer kits: $ 1000

Prints/flyers/stickers: $1000

Peck fulfillment: $500

Total: $5000



A wake up call

“We stand on the fringe of a catastrophic collapse of the eco-system and still we have to fight hard to be heard; pay with the last of our strength to make them work out a policy to secure a homely earth for us when they cease to exist.

To be more honest, I have not much to do with lamenting, but I would rather save my energy to incite more youths to take action in the wise of saving this planet from the ravages of our unfriendly and unsustainable actions. Yes, I know we have not been found wanting in a committed stand, yet again, I believe we can still do more and work harder leaving every stone turned and sending a wake-up call to every one we know who loves to have a future at least on Earth.

Often we do not have much to work or fight with, but in our strength lies our pride, we can do much more than we think we can, only if we can look deeply and make use of the little we have.

If you can speak, please let your voice be heard over the hills, if you can run, sprint all the way to make a change, if you can write, make your pen your sword and fight harder and if you think you don’t have much to give, help the ones who can and with that we can all fight for our lives and our common future.

Every hand is needed on the deck in helping to stand for the survival of our ecosystem, our only home, the Earth and no other time is more appropriate to join the move for change. It doesn’t take much but the possible little in your capacity.

Green Impact International needs your support in whichever regards you deem possible in your capacity. Please extend the hand help so we can all be part of the story of saving the Earth.

story:
The Need
How can we address the threats of climate change? How can we help the people who are most vulnerable to changing weather patterns, an increase in disastrous storms, and threatened food/water security?

By helping people help themselves. Many of us have rallied to help people in need after disaster strikes. Remember Haiti? What about being preemptive, so that when disaster happens the results won’t be so destructive? Let’s help  now, before so many lives are lost and people are left helpless.

What We Can Do
I am looking for support to assist OceansWatch (a charitable organization) to develop and pilot a Climate Change Adaptation Program that will be implemented in communities in the Solomon Islands and Vanuatu in the South Pacific. In the immediate future, the program will benefit more than 3200 people in approximately 16 marginalized and highly vulnerable communities. In the future this program can be used to assist at-risk coastal communities around the world.

These island communities are already suffering from the results of climate change with more intense storms, changes in drought and rain cycles, rising sea-levels, and more. The only solution is to adapt to and navigate these challenges. Since 2008, OceansWatch has worked with communities that have requested their assistance in these countries. Previous projects in these communities  have supported the people to sustainably manage the  marine resources they depend on and have helped local women  send their children to school through producing and selling organic coconut oil.

I was invited to work with OceansWatch to develop climate change adaptation protocols for these communities. The next step is to pilot this program so it can then be implemented throughout the region that OceansWatch works.

What We Need
To pilot the Climate Change Adaptation Program, we need to raise $4750. Well-spent aid money will help people be able to help themselves, not create a long-term dependency on outside support. As the adage goes, "Give a man a fish, you feed him for a day. But give him a fishing rod, you feed him for a lifetime."  It's not about funneling money in, it's about giving people tools. Your contribution will do exactly that. You can make it possible for me to implement this new program, giving the people of the Temotu Province of the Solomon Islands the tools they need to survive and thrive in the face of climate change. I will be in the field for 10-12 weeks this fall. I will be doing an additional 2-3 months of work for preparation and follow-up. I am prepared to give my time and energy to this cause because I see the incredible positive impact it will have. I also know that it's a building block for future work that will empower  marginalized communities around the planet to help themselves and prosper. Donations will contribute to my airfare, expenses, and a small stipend for me. I'm prepared to put my boots to the ground. Contributions of any size will help make this possible!

Thank you for your interest and your support!

About Britt Basel
With a MS in Human Dimensions of Natural Resources, a MS in Conservation Leadership, and a BA in Anthropology,  Britt's work and experience span over 35 countries and across scales, from consulting for the United Nations’ Disaster Risk Reduction Program in Chiapas, Mexico to working directly with rural and marginalized communities. As a photographer associated with National Geographic,  Britt uses photography to tell the story of the people and ways that we can drive positive change.

story:
Scoria brings you biodegradable high quality cork yoga mats, ethically made recycled leggings and fun expressive t-shirts inspired by children's imaginations. As an art teacher, designer, and passionate yogi, I interpret different children's stories into designs of high quality yoga gear that tap into the imagination!

 

SOCIAL, ENVIRONMENTAL & A CREATIVE IMPACT!

Ending world hunger one yoga mat at a time... Scroll to the bottom to see how each purchase gives back! ~ 

 

"How can Scoria products help my creativity?"

Scoria's designs are a tool to trigger the imagination... Interpreted from children's stories, illustrations of landscapes, doorways, or patterns can help initiate the start of a story. We encourage imagining different stories with every practice on the mat

 

 

SIGNATURE DESIGNS

QUALITY ASSURANCE

Made of natural cork and natural rubber, the most sustainable materials in the market, we use a high quality process of production so that the cork is un-breakable, does not harm any trees and is top performance.

1. THE MAT

DESIGN CHOICES: EARTHY, SUSTAINABLE & DREAMY

 1. A friend to our planet

2. Better grip every time you sweat! (perfect for hot yoga)

3. Durable and will last years

4. Self-cleaning cork top! Yes, the top is anti-microbial and prevents mildew. Only needs an occasional wipe with water to prevent oil build up

5. One mat gives 6 meals to a hungry child 

6. Triggers the imagination allowing one to feel more creative during yoga or meditation

AND, they come with a strap!

The sizes of the yoga mats are a standard size of 68 inches x 24 inches.  This first production provides cushioning of 4mm; the best balance of comfortable cushioning and easy travel.

PERFECT FOR HOT YOGA!

Do you sweat a lot? These mats grip better as you sweat.

Yoga mat features and materials:

 

SUSTAINABILITY

"Eco-friendly" is not enough for us! These yoga mats are 100% natural and biodegradable. Cork and rubber = best materials for sustainability.

Yoga mats that use PVC, TPE, and or Micro-fibres, are still not the best for the environment as much as they claim to be eco-friendly. The materials do not all biodegrade and are usually a mix of synthetics and natural materials.

 

 

2. THE LEGGINGS

For this first production we designed only one pair of leggings! We wish to design more scribbly leggings and start instilling creativity within children in communities once we grow or if we reach an over-funding of the goal (See "Goals" all the way below for our plans)

 

Leggings materials and features:

Our leggings are made using 86% recycled yarns derived from post consumer plastic bottles and 14% spandex. Be kind to the planet while you sweat! They are also functional and can be worn for lounging or for casual wear.

EXCITING UPDATE

Flat lock seams and a gusset are not shown in the pictures, however, we have recently adjusted the design with flat lock seams for an excellent fit and added a gusset for better comfort.

SIZE CHART

We currently have standard sizes of M, L, or XL. 

XS (First production: SOLD OUT), S (First production: SOLD OUT),

At the end of a successful campaign, backers will receive a survey that will allow choosing the preferred size and design!

3. GRAPHIC TEES

Meet our fun Uni-sex t-shirts that are perfect for fun casual everyday wear!

TEES: Pledge of $25CAD+ | $19USD

LEFT: WHO I WANT TO BE TEE

RIGHT: FLEXI THE UNICORN TEE

NEW: I DIDN'T EAT THE COOKIE TEE

 

 

GIVING BACK

Our children are the future! With every unique pledge of $25CAD or more, you help feed children in the most needed communities around the world. We commit to 6 nutritious plant-based meals with every unique pledge of $25 CAD in partnership with FCE. The meals include lentils, rice, dehydrated vegetables, pink Himalayan salt, are versatile and could be easily cooked into different recipes.

Courtesy of Feeding Children Everywhere

 

WHERE ARE THE FUNDS GOING?

 

THE GOALS

With this funding we will be able to get our first production ready for you! With the start of Scoria, you will be bringing more story-telling and imagination to the world. 

$15,000 - INVENTORY - UNLOCKED

With a little more funding we will be able to 100% guarantee that the first collection will be going in a new Scoria e-commerce store for anyone to be able to purchase

$25,000 - NEW COLLECTION INVOLVING CHILDREN & COMMUNITIES

With around $12,000 more we will be able to fund a new collection that is community involved. 

We are aiming to work with children in impoverished communities to inspire them to be artists and give them the ability to become the designers and provide their inspiring stories and scribbles to the world as we give back royalties, financial help, and hands-on help to the children's families and organizations involved directly.

The money will be needed for more research, being able to directly communicate and visit the communities, better communication of ideas to the world, and giving back financially to the children who provided their art and stories to the world. Also, of course a minimum order of inventory for each design to provide the world with the option of having a piece of this collection

$35,000 - NEW LEGGING DESIGNS + WORK ON NEW RECYCLED TEXTILES

If we really over-reach the goal, we will add brand new leggings that you will love, and in darker colours for many who requested that. As we are in a process of even more improvements for the leggings. A lot of the money will go into making the recycled fabrics even better! 

We would love to make the fabric better through keeping it soft and have it feel as if it's second-skin as it is right now, however with a thickness that will be harder to recognize that they are made from recycled fabrics. Compared to other brands, our fabric is one of the thickest recycled polyester and has one of the best functionalities, however we aim to work on developing the textile itself to make it even better in its thickness, coverage, comfort and durability! (Aiming high to use/ develop the best recycled fabrics to find in the market)

$42,000 - ADDITION OF SPORT BRA

Ah, don't you just want to spark your imagination from head to toe? We worked a lot in the past year to find a way to add a sports bra that is also made from recycled plastic bottles, however we wanted to keep our commitment to manufacture clothing ethically and in Canada and discovered that it will need to be tackled from scratch with a brand new pattern, more testing and research. An investment will be needed to create a brand new pattern, prototypes and with an aim for optimal quality and functionality.

Future Goal: SCORIA MEN'S 

If we reach an even higher funding of $80,000 or more, it's good to dream! We will be adding a first collection for men in terms of clothing/ unisex sweater, tee, and men's active wear/ yoga pants. 


LET'S GET SOCIAL

Visit our website: www.scoriaworld.com

Instagram: @scoriaworld

Twitter: @scoriaworld

Facebook: Scoria

Risks and challenges

There is always a possibility for unforeseen circumstances for production, however, there has been a buffer time added to make sure this project follows the timeline. I also worked closely with manufacturers to put together production estimates and secure the materials. At this point all of the products you see are ready to roll with this goal being reached.

And, I will always put in my very best to work through any challenge to deliver what is promised and deliver it on time. Any challenges and risks coming our way will be tackled directly

Duty/VAT charges: If you are an international backer, you will be responsible for any applicable duty/VAT charges.

Customs: Some countries may be very slow with customs. We're sorry that it is out of our control to help them get through faster.

Because our backers' support is so important to us and we will make sure to keep our promises and frequently about our progress, and if there are any blips along the way, we'll let you know! All is needed now is your support. So, let's bring this creativity notion to life!

story:
Help us build a spectacular (and safe) hiking trail in the Caucasus

We are raising money to build a trail between the regions of Svaneti and Racha in the Greater Caucasus mountains of western Georgia. This trail will become a part of the Transcaucasian Trail (TCT), a proposed trail network that will eventually stretch across the Caucasus. The long-distance trail will connect more than two dozen national parks and protected areas in the region, an idea that Der Spiegel has already recommended as one of the best new hikes in world.

Last summer, our team traveled around Georgia scouting routes, collecting data, and building support for the Transcaucasian Trail. This summer, two other members of our team are continuing that scouting effort in Georgia and Armenia. You can follow their adventures here: www.transcaucasian.com

Now that we’ve done the research and gathered support for our idea, we want to demonstrate what actually building the TCT will look like and how we will do it. The Svaneti-Racha section will serve as our first TCT trail building pilot project.

The Svaneti-Racha trail is a perfect pilot project in many ways. The route will connect two proposed national parks and pass through some of the most stunning landscapes in the Caucasus. It will bring hikers who have discovered Svaneti across the mountains to Racha, which has very little tourism despite its incredible beauty. It will create sustainable economic opportunities for the remote mountain communities in both regions. And this year the Georgian government is working to formalize the creation of Racha National Park, so the trail will provide access to this brand new, and very significant protected area, and help to highlight the importance of its conservation.

The route we are building this summer between Zeskho, Svaneti and Ghebi, Racha was an established hiking route between these two regions in the past, but the trail is in serious need of rehabilitation and reconstruction. The current route is dangerous and easy to lose, and in places totally non-existent. Fixing it means building tread for the trail, creating safe river crossings, and clearing and marking the path where it has become overgrown. You can read more about the route here: http://www.caucasus-trekking.com/blog/svaneti-racha-1

This summer our goal is to construct and rehabilitate roughly 40 km of trail, utilizing rotating teams of volunteers working for eight weeks in July and August. The volunteers will be a combination of Georgian and international volunteers. Some are experienced trail builders, but many will be learning the skills it will take to build and maintain the trail in the future. This group will form the core of a growing base of trail experts in the region who will help design, build, and maintain the trail rest of the TCT in the coming years.


We will be able to cover some of the administrative costs of the program through a generous donation to the TCTA, and contributions of time and effort by our awesome team. But we still need to raise money for some really critical parts of our budget.

Here’s what we need:

-$3,100 for equipment: This includes trail building equipment like shovels, picks, loppers, axes, a clinometer for measuring the slope of the trail, GPS devices, kitchen equipment for cooking meals, and first-aid kits for the work crews.

-$800 for communications: In order to ensure the safety of the volunteer team, we need a satellite messenger and subscription for emergency communications when we are out of cell phone range, as well as two-way radios.

-$3,000 for food: We will be feeding 7-8 crew members for 8 weeks.

-$2,400 for gas and transportation: We will need at least one support vehicle that can bring the volunteers, supplies, and equipment to the trailhead as well and help the team in case of emergency. We will also cover volunteer travel to and from Tbilisi, and we’ll need to rent horses to support the teams when moving camp locations.

-$3,000 for rent and administrative costs. This includes the cost of setting up a summer office in Mestia (which will also serve to house volunteers on weekends) and other administrative costs that we haven’t been able to cover so far.

Based on the success of our work this summer, we will start planning for the scale-up phase of our project next year, steadily increasing the number of kilometers of trail we are building each summer. Any extra funds we raise beyond our goal will support the work of the Transcaucasian Trail Association, including trail crews in summer 2017.

The Impact

Over the next five years, the Transcaucasian Trail (TCT) project aims to develop a world-class, long-distance trail network across the Caucasus, linking roughly two dozen existing and proposed national parks in the region. The network will consist of two intersecting trail corridors, each roughly 1500 km long. One corridor, oriented east to west, will connect the Black Sea and the Caspian Sea, and the other, oriented north to south, will connect the Greater Caucasus and the Lesser Caucasus.

These well-marked and well-maintained trails will provide a world-class experience for hikers and other trail users, while increasing economic opportunities for local communities. The TCT system will improve access to historic sites and protected areas in the region and raise their profile, helping to ensure that the natural and cultural heritage of the Caucasus can be enjoyed by future generations.

The TCT will serve as a recognizable international brand for hiking and ecotourism in the Caucasus, making it a safer, more accessible and more enjoyable experience. More visitors who stay longer will increase income and employment for the local population. Greater international recognition of the region’s rich cultural and natural diversity will support its preservation. More empowered local communities will be able to effectively respond to and benefit from the growth in tourism without negatively impacting the environment. And by promoting the region as a whole, rather than individual countries, the TCT concept also helps build connections between communities, ecosystems, and people in a place where there is too much focus on the things that divide.

The Transcaucasian Trail Association (TCTA) is a non-profit organization based in Washington, DC, dedicated to the development, promotion, and maintenance of the TCT. Our team members in London, Yerevan, and Tbilisi have many years of experience in the region and deep, grassroots connections with our affiliate organizations, local communities along the trail, and relevant national and local authorities in the region. The TCTA will serve as the central coordinating body for trail development and promotion, building the necessary partnerships with individuals, communities, NGOs, academics, businesses, and governments, and laying the groundwork for successful trail development.

We have partnered with the National Hiking Federation of Georgia to help develop the trail in Georgia.

Risks and Challenges

We are being ambitious in our plans for the summer. By September, we plan to have designed and built a safe and sustainable trail from Svaneti to Racha, but the uncertainties of nature and the weather, as well as other unforeseen circumstances, could prevent us from completing all of the trail that we would like to. As important as completing the trail will be creating a safe and fun working environment for our volunteer crews and teaching them new skills, which we will certainly be able to do with your support.

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you can’t contribute, you can still help out by spreading the work about the TCT. You can also check out current volunteer opportunities and sign up for our newsletter here: http://transcaucasiantrail.org/en/get-involved/
story_txt: Help us build a spectacular (and safe) hiking trail in the CaucasusWe are raising money to build a trail between the regions of Svaneti and Racha in the Greater Caucasus mountains of western Georgia. This trail will become a part of the Transcaucasian Trail (TCT), a proposed trail network that will eventually stretch across the Caucasus. The long-distance trail will connect more than two dozen national parks and protected areas in the region, an idea that Der Spiegel has already recommended as one of the best new hikes in world.Last summer, our team traveled around Georgia scouting routes, collecting data, and building support for the Transcaucasian Trail. This summer, two other members of our team are continuing that scouting effort in Georgia and Armenia. You can follow their adventures here: www.transcaucasian.comNow that we’ve done the research and gathered support for our idea, we want to demonstrate what actually building the TCT will look like and how we will do it. The Svaneti-Racha section will serve as our first TCT trail building pilot project.The Svaneti-Racha trail is a perfect pilot project in many ways. The route will connect two proposed national parks and pass through some of the most stunning landscapes in the Caucasus. It will bring hikers who have discovered Svaneti across the mountains to Racha, which has very little tourism despite its incredible beauty. It will create sustainable economic opportunities for the remote mountain communities in both regions. And this year the Georgian government is working to formalize the creation of Racha National Park, so the trail will provide access to this brand new, and very significant protected area, and help to highlight the importance of its conservation.The route we are building this summer between Zeskho, Svaneti and Ghebi, Racha was an established hiking route between these two regions in the past, but the trail is in serious need of rehabilitation and reconstruction. The current route is dangerous and easy to lose, and in places totally non-existent. Fixing it means building tread for the trail, creating safe river crossings, and clearing and marking the path where it has become overgrown. You can read more about the route here: http://www.caucasus-trekking.com/blog/svaneti-racha-1This summer our goal is to construct and rehabilitate roughly 40 km of trail, utilizing rotating teams of volunteers working for eight weeks in July and August. The volunteers will be a combination of Georgian and international volunteers. Some are experienced trail builders, but many will be learning the skills it will take to build and maintain the trail in the future. This group will form the core of a growing base of trail experts in the region who will help design, build, and maintain the trail rest of the TCT in the coming years.We will be able to cover some of the administrative costs of the program through a generous donation to the TCTA, and contributions of time and effort by our awesome team. But we still need to raise money for some really critical parts of our budget.Here’s what we need:-$3,100 for equipment: This includes trail building equipment like shovels, picks, loppers, axes, a clinometer for measuring the slope of the trail, GPS devices, kitchen equipment for cooking meals, and first-aid kits for the work crews. -$800 for communications: In order to ensure the safety of the volunteer team, we need a satellite messenger and subscription for emergency communications when we are out of cell phone range, as well as two-way radios.-$3,000 for food: We will be feeding 7-8 crew members for 8 weeks. -$2,400 for gas and transportation: We will need at least one support vehicle that can bring the volunteers, supplies, and equipment to the trailhead as well and help the team in case of emergency. We will also cover volunteer travel to and from Tbilisi, and we’ll need to rent horses to support the teams when moving camp locations. -$3,000 for rent and administrative costs. This includes the cost of setting up a summer office in Mestia (which will also serve to house volunteers on weekends) and other administrative costs that we haven’t been able to cover so far.Based on the success of our work this summer, we will start planning for the scale-up phase of our project next year, steadily increasing the number of kilometers of trail we are building each summer. Any extra funds we raise beyond our goal will support the work of the Transcaucasian Trail Association, including trail crews in summer 2017.The ImpactOver the next five years, the Transcaucasian Trail (TCT) project aims to develop a world-class, long-distance trail network across the Caucasus, linking roughly two dozen existing and proposed national parks in the region. More visitors who stay longer will increase income and employment for the local population. Greater international recognition of the region’s rich cultural and natural diversity will support its preservation. More empowered local communities will be able to effectively respond to and benefit from the growth in tourism without negatively impacting the environment. And by promoting the region as a whole, rather than individual countries, the TCT concept also helps build connections between communities, ecosystems, and people in a place where there is too much focus on the things that divide.The Transcaucasian Trail Association (TCTA) is a non-profit organization based in Washington, DC, dedicated to the development, promotion, and maintenance of the TCT. Our team members in London, Yerevan, and Tbilisi have many years of experience in the region and deep, grassroots connections with our affiliate organizations, local communities along the trail, and relevant national and local authorities in the region. The TCTA will serve as the central coordinating body for trail development and promotion, building the necessary partnerships with individuals, communities, NGOs, academics, businesses, and governments, and laying the groundwork for successful trail development.We have partnered with the National Hiking Federation of Georgia to help develop the trail in Georgia.Risks and ChallengesWe are being ambitious in our plans for the summer. By September, we plan to have designed and built a safe and sustainable trail from Svaneti to Racha, but the uncertainties of nature and the weather, as well as other unforeseen circumstances, could prevent us from completing all of the trail that we would like to. story:
Update 5: What a Weekend!

We did it! Our ShellNo BreakFree Kayaktion has officially wrapped, and we accomplished some incredible things.

First and foremost, Shell Oil and Tesoro were so nervous about being confronted on water and land that they cancelled every single oil train and oil tanker in and out of their refineries for 3 days in Anacortes WA. One of our biggest goals was to impact their operations, and we did that in a huge way! Please give yourselves a big round of applause for helping to make that happen.

Secondly, the Mosquito Fleet couldn’t be more proud of the action we helped pull together this weekend. With tanker traffic already defeated, kayaktivists decided to push the envelope further by landing on the refinery property itself, confronting Shell’s private security forces to send a message to the refinery workers themselves: we are with you, and we want you to be with us. It’s time for workers on both sides of the refinery walls to come together and demand a fair and fast transition to safe energy.

Kayaktivists raised banners on the beach, then held a moment of silence for the victims of Big Oil greed worldwide.

After returning to our launch point (a 6 mile paddle), a few Fleet members launched a second, smaller action to have a little fun with Shell. We took our safety boat back to Shell’s refinery to make something crystal clear: because of us and this incredible collection of badass climate justice groups, this normally bustling hub was completely empty of oil tankers.

We’re so grateful to you all for supporting the Fleet as we went hard in Anacortes. From here, we’re going to continue to ratchet up the pressure, stopping Shell’s proposed oil train terminal and escalating the call to keep fossil fuels in the ground. We’re also going to dive headfirst into planning an awesome Kayaktion Camp in September to keep building power and spreading kayaktivism far and wide.

Thanks again for everything you’ve done. See you on the high seas!

P.S. If you’re receiving a t-shirt or hoodie, please keep watching your email! We’ll be continuing to message folks in the coming couple weeks to get their sizes and design preferences, and we cannot send you your perk without that info. As noted on our page, we expect all our perks to be delivered by the end of June. Thanks again!!

--

Update 4: Onward and Upward to $25K!

Greetings from Anacortes, WA! 

The Mosquito Fleet is on the ground at Break Free PNW along with a whole bunch of incredible climate justice groups, and we're stoked to get out on the water to give Shell a little hell. The kayaks, life jackets, and other safety gear you've so generously helped us to get are getting a ton of use already; one of them is about to be used in a training we're leading with Presidential candidate Dr. Jill Stein! Huge, huge thanks to all of you for helping to make this thing happen.
    

And thank you to all of our recent donors who helped us shoot past our second stretch goal! We're so honored by your support and continue to be blown away by the momentum and energy of this moment. We're now moving on to our next stretch goal of $25,000! This will help us keep growing the Mosquito Fleet after this weekend is over: we want to seed Fleets in coastal communities all over this bio-region, in the small towns and neighborhoods where the climate movement hasn't reached, and it takes resources to do the kind of person-to-person outreach we need to make this movement truly robust and representative. We've also started a small repair and maintenance fund so we can keep all the gear you helped provide in shipshape and ready to roll into action. Please keep sharing this fundraiser with your family and friends to help us get there!

On a serious note, if you haven't heard already, Shell created yet another environmental disaster this week: a 90,000+ gallon oil spill was discovered in the Gulf of Mexico yesterday. Our thoughts and hearts are with everyone in that community, who have withstood disaster after disaster created by oil companies, political apathy, and corporate greed. The time for a just transition is right now, and you are all helping to bring it to life. Thank you, as always, for everything you're doing.

--

Update 3: Let's Make it $20,000

We're gonna run out of ways to say "Thank you" at this rate! (Not that we're complaining). Less than 24 hours after announcing our new stretch goal, we shot right past it! We're so, so thankful for and in awe of the response to this campaign. 

The incredible energy on display is just another sign that the tide is turning, and we are winning. Mosquito Fleet is going to throw everything we've got into this action and, after it's over, in growing new Fleets in coastal communities all over the PNW. We're moving to our next stretch goal of $20,000; this will go toward final expenses the action, scholarships for our Kayaktion Camp, and starting a repair and maintenance fund to ensure the longevity of the Fleet and the materials you've so generously given us. 

We're packing up our lifejackets and making final adjustments to the kayaks in preparation for this weekend. See you on the high seas!

--

Update 2: We beat our goal! Now we’re going for $15,000!!

Thanks to y’all, we’ve officially broken through our $12K goal! We’re super stoked to kick Shell’s butt and show you an awesome action this weekend!

We’ve been buying up used, “arrestable” kayaks, and we got an amazing deal on a used 23-foot sailboat, to be our Kayaktivist Mothership. Thanks to you, this action is gonna rock. 

Some incredibly generous folks have also been hooking us up with half-price life-jackets, discounted rain gear, and VHF radios! We’re blown away by the momentum behind this action and the generosity on display from folks all over the world.

Now that we’ve met our initial goal, it’s time to really crank up this Indiegogo and see what this puppy can do. We’re hereby setting a stretch goal of $15K! This will help us put more courageous kayaktivists out on the water to block Shell’s tankers and speed the transition to clean energy. It will also help us to pull off Kayaktion Camp in September where we’ll train a hundred new Mosquito Fleet paddlers in our creative tactics of swarming against global warming.

So throw down, keep sharing with friends, and get yourself some awesome fleet flair!!

--

Update 1: HOLY COW! We’re more than 95% funded in just five days! 

Thank you to everyone who’s donated, and to everyone who’s written in to offer kayaks, lifejackets, cameras, and more. You all are pure awesomeness! 
We’re now less than two weeks away from our big action and there’s a LOT to do. If we surpass our $12K goal, we’ll be able to get even more people on the water to take a stand against Shell. And every piece of gear we get will stay with the Mosquito Fleet, so if we can really rock this campaign, we'll be set up for future actions too!
So please keep this campaign going! If you can't give, you can help by sharing it with your friends and families. Our team is reaching out to everyone we know, but the Internet is a big place - that means every share is a potential new donation. So share, share, and share some more! 
 Finally, for those who are receiving t-shirts or hoodies, we’ll be reaching out to you starting this week to get your size and design preference, so please keep an eye on your email! Thanks again to everyone who’s chipped in; you're living proof of how big and real this movement is. Let’s DO this thing!
--------

Your tax-deductible gift will help us launch the Mosquito Fleet!

The Mosquito Fleet peacefully confronts Big Oil on the coastal waters of the Pacific Northwest to interrupt business as usual; our goal is to keep fossil fuels safely in the ground by stopping the dangerous flow of oil, gas, and coal through our communities. 


What We Need

The Mosquito Fleet is made up of folks from coastal communities who care about our climate and oceans; we want to ensure that anyone can join us in standing up to Shell. We're asking for your help in obtaining:


Any funds raised beyond our goal will go toward seeding new Fleets: providing gear, training new kayaktivists, and supporting existing efforts to shut down fossil fuel infrastructure. 
And remember, your donation is tax-deductible, so please give generously!

Perks!

$5: Jr. Deckhand
Every dollar helps! You’ll get a personal shoutout on mosquitofleet.us.

$15: Deckhand
Welcome to the Fleet! You’ll get a shoutout on mosquitofleet.us, plus you’ll get to show your Fleet pride with a high-quality vinyl sticker!

$25: Paddler
You’ll get the shoutout, the Mosquito Fleet sticker, plus a sweet Mosquito Fleet koozie to keep your drinks cold on the water!

$50: Boatswain
You’ll get the shoutout, the sticker, plus our new Mosquito Fleet trucker hat! Keep the sun out of your eyes on land or sea.

$50: Safety Kayaker
You’ll get the shoutout, the sticker, plus your very own Mosquito Fleet t-shirt. Choose from our classic Anchor design or the new Jolly Roger design. Arrrgh!

$100: Third Mate’s Pack
Movin’ on up! You’ll get the shoutout, the sticker, the trucker hat, plus your choice of a t-shirt!

$150: Second Mate's Pack
Now we’re talkin’. You’ll get the shoutout, the sticker, plus your choice of a super soft hoodie: rock the classic Mosquito Fleet anchor or our new Jolly Roger.

$250: First Mate's Pack
Bargain! Keep extra warm on deck with a shout-out, a sticker, and both Mosquito Fleet hoodies!

$500: Captain’s Pack
Aye, aye, Captain! You’ll get it all: shoutout, sticker, trucker hat, koozie, your choice of tee, and your choice of hoodie. Show off your Fleet pride wherever you go!

$1,000: Kayaktivist
You’ll get the Captain’s Pack, plus the chance to give Shell hell: we’ll use our 12,000 lumen digital projector to “tag” the hull of an Oil Tanker with your personal message (no potty words - keep it family-friendly, please!).

All our tees and hoodies are manufactured and screen-printed in the U.S.


Press and Other Details

  • Varied Pressures Force Shell Out of Arctic, The Seattle Times, Sept. 28, 2015
  • Grabbing Paddles in Seattle to Ward Off an Oil Giant, The New York Times, May 11, 2015. 
  • 'Cold welcome' for Arctic drilling rig's arrival, The Seattle Times, Apr. 17, 2015, Front Page.
  • Can a Flotilla of Kayaks Block Shell's Arctic Drilling Rigs in Seattle?, The Stranger, Apr. 8, 2015, Front Page.
  • 'Kayaktivist' teachers train for Shell protest, KING 5 News, Apr. 23, 2015
Learn more about the Mosquito Fleet on our website at mosquitofleet.us.
Join us on the water! Sign up at breakfreepnw.org.

story:
If you know me then it shouldn't surprise you that I started a tree farm in a foreign country.  My first arrival in Leyte was four years ago.  The island was a mess.   I was eager to help in any way that I could.  I joined with an international group of volunteers called All Hands. Due to my years of experience I was offered a position running a chainsaw crew.  As we sawed our way through the communities the people told us about their trees.  Coconut, rambutan, cacao, mango, jackfruit  and many more varieties of fruit and nut trees were sawn up to be repurposed as building materials and firewood.   Everybody was sad to see their "old friends " go.

   Leyte is an agricultural island. These trees that had weathered countless storms before could not withstand the massive winds that took them down.  Millions of important trees had been destroyed.  

In addition to being eager to help  I also arrived with a determination to contribute something long lasting. I didn't want to clean up and go home.  I could see the damage here would last for years to come.   I began spending evenings with a local family.   These were the people who became my partners. Even though they suffered losses from the storm they were eager to contribute to a long term recovery plan for those in need.   After many evenings debating what could be done we dreamt up the Leyte Reforestation Project.  We were offered the use of their families old farm and went to work.

  We cleared the farm and started building our facility.   It was tough to find workers because people didn't take us very seriously.   The progress was very slow for the first two years. I think we were were all dejected but no one wanted to give up. Now we're glad we didn't.   After visiting the farm last year the wheels finally started turning.  We were able to finish our compost facility, a crucial component in producing tree seedlings and organic vegetables.  Next came the hiring of a liscensed horticulturalist.  Under his direction we were able to install irrigation, build a really nice greenhouse and instruct the newly hired farm hands on proper development of tree seedlings and organic gardening.   We now have the capability to produce five thousand fruit trees every month!  These seedlings are destined to invigorate the communities surrounding our farm.  

The Leyte Reforestation Project does not only develop trees. We offer an education program as well. Local farmers and recipients of seedlings can visit our farm. We are operating as a training facility and demonstration farm for a wide variety of farming techniques.   Our processes and technologies are available in a hands on fashion for people who are interested in what we have to offer.   We are a registered nursery and soon to be accredited.   We have support of local government organizations as well as Visayas state college.    Enthusiasm from the local community gives us motivation to move forward  with our goals. 

Reaching sustainability is an important step in moving forward.  Increasing our production of seedlings and organic products allows us to sell enough to cover our costs and have more than enough remaining to distribute throughout the communities.  There is a high demand for what we produce and we have buyers lined up.  

We are asking for donations to increase our production.  Your support is appreciated greatly by myself and all of us involved in the project.  Please donate to our community project.   We have come a long way from the beginning and now our dreams are becoming  a reality!  Thank you Jeff
story_txt: If you know me then it shouldn't surprise you that I started a tree farm in a foreign country.  My first arrival in Leyte was four years ago.  The island was a mess.   I was eager to help in any way that I could.  I joined with an international group of volunteers called All Hands. Due to my years of experience I was offered a position running a chainsaw crew.  As we sawed our way through the communities the people told us about their trees.  Coconut, rambutan, cacao, mango, jackfruit  and many more varieties of fruit and nut trees were sawn up to be repurposed as building materials and firewood.   Everybody was sad to see their "old friends " go.   Leyte is an agricultural island. These trees that had weathered countless storms before could not withstand the massive winds that took them down.  Millions of important trees had been destroyed.  In addition to being eager to help  I also arrived with a determination to contribute something long lasting. story:
On February 19th, 2013, the case between 75-year-old Indiana farmer Vernon H. Bowman and the $13-billion biotech corporation known as Monsanto will open to the Supreme Court.  Monsanto, the multinational producer of pesticide-resistant seeds and known champion of genetically modified organisms (GMOs), has sued Mr. Bowman for $84,000 for purported copyright infringement, that he used their strain of seed without compensation.  Mr. Bowman claims that in seeding his 300 acre soybean farm, he simply purchased second-generation seeds from a nearby grain elevator, property to which Monsanto claims rights.

Monsanto has acknowledged the stakes of this case, which started way back in the 1990s, when their seed sold for about $4.50/bag.  With that price having risen to nearly $18, Mr. Bowman claims that it simply does not make sense for him to have to keep paying such a price for a product that otherwise self-replicates.

Indeed, the implications are huge.  According to Huffington Post, "more than 50 organizations - from environmental groups to intellectual property experts - as well as the U.S. government, have filed legal briefs hoping to sway the high court."  If Monsanto wins, as they did in local court against Bowman back in 2010, they are granted more power in an already one-sided battle against nature, as they continue to monopolize agriculture through largely untested genetic modification.  If Vernon Bowman wins, it is a huge statement, telling this corporation that they can't commoditize our food.  So much is at stake, and Vernon Bowman has taken it all on by himself.

Thankfully, he has help.  The national media has offered coverage of this battle, with articles in the New York Times, NPR, and the Huffington Post.  We're hoping that the more people who learn of this fight, the more will support Mr. Bowman.  Meanwhile, though legal fees have taken a toll on the man -- he's spent over $31,000 in legal fees already -- Mark Walters and his firm, Frommer Lawrence & Haug, have already spent $1,000,000 of their time and $80,000 in hard costs, keeping this case pro bono for the Indiana farmer.  

Please, do what you can to help this brave man.  If it isn't your financial support, please spread the word and shift public opinion in his favor.  Monsanto has steamrolled countless farmers, civilians, and politicians in the past, and will continue to use their power and money to get what benefits them.  We have another shot to shift the balance: let's win one for ourselves!


It's come to my attention that the contribution process is a bit confusing.  If you choose to donate, simply type in the amount in full dollars, without cents included.  For example, if you want to donate $25.00, just type in "$25".  Thanks!

story:
"A world of grass and flowers stretched around me, rising and falling in gentle undulations, as if an enchanter had struck the ocean swell, and it was at rest forever . . ."  - Eliza Steele, Summer Journey in the West (1840) 

Perhaps you've heard of the Appalachian Trail or the Pacific Crest Trail?  They're two examples of long distance trails known as National Scenic Trails.  Imagine a new National Scenic Trail in one of the most stunning and storied places in America - The Great Plains!

Hi!  We're the Great Plains Trail Alliance and our organization is dedicated to establishing a new National Scenic Trail in the Great Plains.  We're a new organization just getting started, and we could use some help getting a particular project going:  We would like to create a 3-5 minute informative and inspiring video so we can share our unique vision in a more powerful way.  As you can see from the video posted, we need some professional help, and would like to take the next step beyond "arm-length productions."  If you agree that a big trail in the Great Plains would be awesome, make a donation (any amount is helpful) to help us spread the word, and turn the Great Plains Trail from an idea into a reality!  And Thanks!

Great Plains Trail Alliance is recognized by the IRS as a 501c3 organization, so anything you contribute can be deducted from your taxes!

story:
This project involves the development of a membership organization dedicated to helping its’ members save money at the gas pump by flexing our collective buying power and negotiating substantial discounts in the price of a gallon of gas at the pump.

This organization has come about because of the helplessness we all feel about the ever increasing price of a gallon of gasoline. As individuals we feel there is nothing we can do about the utter greed of the oil companies. They raise the price of gas very fast on the slightest hint of bad news that “may” have an adverse effect on the oil industry. The media fuels this phenomenon by “preparing” us for the impending rise in gas prices at the pump by “explaining” the reasons behind these events.

Once the alleged “crisis” is over or has subsided, the price of gas is very slow to come back down. More and more of our monthly income is going into our gas tank.

My question is this: How can an oil company report a one billion dollar quarterly profit when supposedly it has been adversely affected by catastrophic events in the Middle East or the effect a hurricane has on its' oil refineries in the gulf of Mexico?

This campaign is important because I believe it represents a very real opportunity to make a difference and to save money at the gas pump. Also, it represents a real chance to “fight back” against rising gas prices and alleviating that feeling of helplessness we all have. If you want to do something about rising gas prices then please contribute to this project.

As a contributor you will help to bring this organization into existence. As a member of  the organization you will be able to take advantage of all of its planned benefits. Such an organization is necessary to provide a vehicle through which we can collectively eradicate that feeling of helplessness and the belief that there is nothing we can do about the rising price of gas.

We require a minimum of $350,000 to

 1.) Conduct a marketing campaign designed to sign up an initial         300,000 members towards our ultimate goal of one million members;

2.) Apply for and receive IRS 501(c)3 non-profit status and;

3.) Develop a membership website.

In exchange for contributing to this project you will receive some exciting perks which include:

  1. Membership in the organization (1 year, 2 year, 3 year, 4 year, 5 year or lifetime depending on the amount contributed)
  2. A certificate for $1000 in grocery coupons (you choose the coupons you want)
  3. A certificate for $1000 in restaurant savings coupons (to popular nationwide restaurants)
  4. 3 night hotel accommodations  to any one of over 30 vacation destinations.

If the amount requested is not raised, we will continue to pursue creation of the organization. Whatever amount is raised will be used to initiate the membership marketing plan, secure IRS 501(c)3 non-profit status and develop a membership website. Thihgs will have to move a little slower, but there will be continued development of the organization. It will take longer to reach the initial goal of 300,000 members, but we will get there. The price of gas is only going to continue to rise which only serves to prove that such an organization is sorely needed.

This organization is designed for and dedicated to helping its members save on the cost of gasoline at the pump by utilizing their collective bargaining power. It will negotiate with one national gas station chain to provide a monthly per gallon discount to members. Members will receive a membership card similar to a credit card which they will use at the gas station to save as much as $2.00 per gallon or more each time they buy gas.

Depending on the amount of gas a member buys each time they fill up, they can realize substantial savings. For instance, if a member averages 30 gallons a week he or she can save $60.00 per week at the $2.00 dollar per gallon savings. That’s an annual savings of $3120. Of course, the more you buy the more you save.

The organization will apply for and receive IRS 501(c)3 non-profit status so that the monthly membership fee paid by members will be tax deductible, thereby providing additional savings to members. Currently, the monthly membership fee is sceduled to be $14.95. Planned future benefits include 1.) providing members with very low fixed rate mortgages (1%) with up to 50 years to repay. 2.) using the collective buying power of members to receive substantial savings and rebates on almost everything members purchase and 3.) helping to reduce the cost of home energy usage.

How many times have you driven up to the gas pump and felt that feeling of helplessness at not being able to do anything about the rising price of gas. Well, now is your chance to do something by being instrumental in helping this organization get off the ground.
 
Even if you can’t make a monetary contribution you can still help. You can help get the word out by contacting your friends, family and associates and getting them involved in this effort. You can also use the Indiegogo share tools to help get the word out.

Thank you in advance for your support.

Picture courtesy of FreeDigitalPhotos.net

story:
Student Artwork + Climate Change + Public Transportation 

Cool Science is a fun, creative project that gets kids involved in communicating important ideas about climate change to large, captive audiences riding public transportation. Every day in Lowell alone, thousands of people use mass transit. That's one state. One city. Think BIG PICTURE here. How can our Cool Science model be used across the country as an informal teaching tool?

What We Do

Cool Science invites K-12 students to create and submit a visual work of art about climate change. The best entries are placed on posters and placards throughout Lowell’s mass transit system to engage the riding public with informal learning opportunities. In our pilot year, we received over 600 student entries from over 30 schools in Massachusetts. 

The Basics: What We Need

More funding = more communities reached, more students involved, more months of artwork on public transportation

With a minimum of $12,000, Cool Science can run the winning entries on public buses in Lowell for 3 months. Any funds donated above our goal will help us extend our campaign length and radius. 

What You Get

If you donate to our project, you will not only be helping give students a voice about climate change, but you’ll also be eligible to receive some of our unique project-based perks.

We’ve kept our perks simple and economical, so the majority of your donation can go to funding our project. We also want to be smart about our shipping costs and resource consumption. After all, that’s what Cool Science is all about!

Why YOU Should Be A Part

"Out of 10 people, I would recommend it to the 10 people"

-G, 5th Grader

Give students like G a voice, a chance to speak out to thousands about their concerns about climate change and the world they are inheriting.

THEIR Voices: What Students and Teachers Are Saying 

The Cool Science Team

David Lustick

A professor of science education by day and a rock star by night, David was once a featured artist on 92.5 The River's program, Homegrown. David's research focuses on the intersection of informal science learning and climate change education. He loves the idea of teaching people on the go, not just in classrooms. His son, Dakota, gets most of the credit for our Cool Science video.

 

 

Jill Lohmeier

Jill is an avid runner, mom, and education professor. Sometimes, she finds time to play soccer. Her research expertise is in quantitative research methods, and she brings a wealth of experience in cognitive psychology to our Cool Science work.

 

Bob Chen

The resident expert on all things ocean related, Bob was recently featured as an outstanding faculty member for his work at UMass Boston. Bob's research focuses not only on the science of climate change and carbon movement, but also on the teaching of that science to learners of all ages. He and his family reside just outside of Boston.

 

 

Thank You For Your Support!

Even if you can’t contribute at this point, spread the word about our work and our project!

  • Like us on Facebook: https://facebook.com/coolsci
  • Follow us on Twitter: https://twitter.com/cool_sci

We’ll be updating regularly!

story:
Help 180 People Sleep

180 men call Sunday Breakfast Rescue Mission home each night.  It is for these men that we need 100 new mattresses in our emergency shelter.

Services Provided at Sunday Breakfast

Hundreds of men and women come to Sunday Breakfast to receive three meals a day on every day of the year.  Many of these individuals also live at the Mission in the men's emergency shelter.  These services are the beginning steps in transforming an individual's life forever.  It is only after immediate needs are met that someone can start moving toward a changed life.

There will be an increase in guests during the September Papal Visit because the Benjamin Franklin Parkway will be cleared of residents.  These new mattresses will make it possible for us to accommodate any displaced men while the Pope is in Philadelphia.

Sponsor a Mattress for Men Like Kevin

Kevin came to the Mission looking for a safe place to sleep and some food.  He spent 20 days in the emergency shelter before he began the Mission’s long-term Overcomer Program.  While in the program he had vocational training in food service and received several certificates. Now he has started a job working for the University of Pennsylvania’s food service program!

Kevin’s life transformation began with a night in the emergency shelter. But the emergency shelter needs your help to continue this service.

Homeless Individuals are Counting on Your Support

  • We need $8,000 to buy 100 mattresses (Each mattress is ONLY $80). 
  • The men in the long-term program, like Kevin, will be writing everyone who gives a gift to say a personal thank you!  The more you give the greater the appreciation.
  • If we don’t reach our goal, your gifts will still be used to buy as many mattresses as possible.

This Mattress will Change a Life

Your gift will help a man come off the street, be welcomed, have a safe and comfortable night of sleep, and begin his life toward a better future.  It only takes one night of shelter, one delicious meal, or one great conversation to open someone’s heart to end their struggle with homelessness.  They need you!

  • Everyone needs to get involved.  Please share with your friends!

Thank you for providing a new mattress for a homeless man in need.

This Mattress will Change a LifeYour gift will help a
man come off the street, be welcomed, have a safe and comfortable night of
sleep, and begin his life toward a better future.  It only takes one night of shelter, one delicious meal, or one great conversation to open someone’s heart to end their
struggle with homelessness.  They need you!


Everyone needs to get involved.  Please share with your friends!

Thank you for
providing a new mattress for a homeless man in need.

story:
Water is sacred. We are made up of water just like parts of the surface of the earth. Water is our first teaching, it sustains life. Can you imagine a place where the water is considered toxic? This is life in Aamjiwnaang. 


It is important to empower ourselves as stewards of the water, as government and industry have downplayed, ignored and actively worked to repress information about water pollution in Chemical Valley. By conducting our own water testing of pollutants in our territories, we build the knowledge, skills, and resources to get answers about long standing questions about the level and nature of contamination in Aamjiwnaang. We also have strong alliances with researchers who have expressed concern about the impacts they have seen, particularly given recent research into the impacts of pollutants on women in Chemical Valley.

The money raised with this fundraiser will help pay for tests for heavy metals, PAH’s, and PCB’s on water/sediment samples of creeks and ponds in Aamjiwnaang’s territories. One-third of chemical valley sits on lands stolen from the Aamjiwnaang people.

ASAP water and sediment testing initiative will consist of collect samples, writing a community report of results. Conducting water testing by sending samples to independent labs for analysis, working with university partners, communicating results back to community (i.e. videos, written reports, social media)

Project Timeline:

· May/June – Community meetings on water/sediments testing
· July/August –Conduct lab testing of water/sediments samples
· September – Host Toxic Tour in Aamjiwnaang/present results from lab testing

This work will be done with the guidance and support from elders and youth from Aamjiwnaang. It is important that we follow our culture’s way of life by having elder and youth work hand in hand for a common goal.

About Aamjiwnaang and Sarnia against Pipelines

ASAP was created in 2012 with the vision to raise awareness about the Enbridge Line 9 pipeline project, which increases the transport of tar sands dilbit in Chemical Valley, and will result in greater pollution for Aamjiwnaang, as well as increase the risk of pipeline spills. Since that time, ASAP has expanded its mandate to look at fracking projects, refineries, and the transport of toxic chemicals in Aamjiwnaang’s territories. ASAP is a community led initiative. 

We work to confront the industries that pollute, steal our lands, and put our community at risk. ASAP asserts Indigenous Rights and Sovereignty, and we use both direct action and education to raise awareness about environmental injustice. We highlight how environmental racism has created a scenario where our community is polluted and cannot receive basic health or environmental testing, while oil companies make billions from their operations in the Valley.

Background

Locally, Aamjiwnaang First Nation, Walpole, Sarnia, and other communities will directly benefit through increased knowledge regarding the contaminant levels in this region. In 2004, community concerns about birth ratio’s lead to the discovery of endocrinal disruption on reserve. In 2008, a community health study documented reproductive, respiratory, and cancer clusters in Aamjinwnaang related to industrial pollution. In 2013, researchers documented high levels of PCB’s, PFC’s, as well as a host of carcinogen’s and mutagens in child-mother pairings on reserve. More knowledge of where these pollutants are in the community can help keep people safe from high exposures, and identify areas for immediate remediation in terms of toxic exposure. 


Chi-Miigwetch (Thank You)

story:
English version under "Mises à jours", on the top of the page.

  • Nous, c'est avant tout une association locale (STADD, 15 membres) en partenariat avec un travailleur social et impliquant une centaine d'hommes, femmes et enfants des couches les plus précarisées de Lomé. L'ambition de ce partenariat est de créer une entreprise de recyclage des déchets plastiques en granulés afin d'apporter une solution à la pollution grandissante du pays.

  • L’absence de collecte organisée entraîne l’apparition de décharges sauvages. Les déchets sont omniprésents dans l’environnement (rues, caniveaux, zones cultivées, rivières) et créent une situation sanitaire propices au développement de maladies comme la malaria ou les troubles gastro-intestinaux. La vermine abonde, les odeurs sont nauséabondes et les caniveaux se bouchent, avec pour conséquence la stagnation de l'eau et donc la prolifération de moustiques. Occasionnellement les déchets sont brûlés, ce qui pollue l'air et libère de fines particules de polyéthylène (chez certains plastiques), particules qui sont cancérigènes. De plus, les plastiques qui jonchent les rues enlaidissent la ville. 

  • L'association «Science et Technologie Africaines pour un Développement Durable» (STADD) est née en 2011 à la suite d'une prise de conscience de Bemah Gado, 23 ans et actuel président, de la nécessité de combiner nos savoir-faire pour favoriser l'émergence de projets environnementaux et sociaux. Originaire du nord (Mango), il est également coach formateur. Pour le volet «Environnement», il est accompagné par Ouro-Yodou Rouféni, 26 ans, également originaire du nord (Aledjo). Ouro est le coordonnateur du projet de récolte des sachets plastiques. Forts de leur expérience dans la récolte des sachets, ils décident de se lancer dans la phase de transformation du plastique. Ils rencontrent Philippe Nelom Agbémégnah, 29 ans et originaire du sud (Agoè Nyévé) et de la Suisse, porteur d'un projet similaire. Ils décident alors de créer un partenariat afin de travailler ensemble, d'où la naissance de STADD&Partners. La première phase de ce grand projet sera de recycler les sachets «Pure water» puis, plus tard, tous types de sachets plastiques.
  • L'étape indiegogo: Forage et construction d'une usine à Tsévié (35km de Lomé).


  • Le projet dans sa totalité coûte $189,600 (99,354,675 FCFA). Cependant, nous allons avancer étape par étape, d'abord avec le forage puis la construction de l'usine. Le total pour ces deux étapes est de $96,514 (grâce à vous: $86,000; notre part:$10,514).

  • Ayant déjà payé le terrain à Tsévié en juin, nous payerons les études d'impact pour obtenir un certificat de conformité de la part du ministère de l'environnement, puis nous démarrerons les travaux de forage et de construction. L'achat des machines et les autres frais viendrons dès la fin de l'étape susmentionnée.
  • Au cas où la totalité des fonds ne serait pas perçue, nous commencerons le forage et ferons le mur de clôture. En parallèle à cette recherche de fonds, nous allons débuter des sollicitations auprès de fondations, gouvernements et autres institutions, et probablement nous orienter vers un prêt bancaire.

  • Chaque geste en faveur de notre planète est en réalité un geste solidaire. En commençant par recycler des tonnes de sachets «Pure water» par mois, l'entreprise Stadd&Partners projette de contribuer à l'assainissement de la zone maritime et désire améliorer sensiblement la qualité de vie de la population. En nous unissant pour cette cause commune, nous investissons tous en faveur de notre propre bien être. 

  • Générer des déchets implique une responsabilité, voilà pourquoi nous ne devons pas attendre que quelqu'un d'autre le fasse pour nous.
  • Les étapes du recyclage: les sachets sont achetés à la population par kilo et stockés dans des containers. Une fois le container suffisamment plein, ils seront vendus à Stadd&Partners qui les fera broyer, laver puis passer dans une machine appelée extrudeuse, qui à son tour fera fondre le plastique en pâte. La pâte ressortira de l'extrudeuse sous forme de fil refroidi puis coupé en petits morceaux de quelques millimètres, appelés granulat de plastique. Ce granulé est la matière première pour la fabrication de multiples objets en plastique, comme les poubelles par exemple.

  • Nous sommes un groupe de jeunes d'horizons différents. Sensibles à l'environnement et à la qualité de vie, nous nous aguerrissons au fur et à mesure que nous avançons, car actuellement personne dans le groupe n'est expert dans le domaine du recyclage et de la manipulation des machines, en particulier de l'extrudeuse. Pour cette raison, nous comptons sur notre réseau (ministère de l'environnement, consultant en machineries, professeur et consultant en gestion...) et une mini-formation en entreprise plasturgique.

N'hésitez pas à jeter un coup d’œil à nos contreparties et à parler du projet aux amis et à tous ceux qui s'engagent pour le présent. Les façons de s'engager sont multiples (conseils, dons, publicité...) et sont toutes utiles. N'hésitez pas non plus à visiter notre galerie d'images et les réseaux sociaux nous concernant. 

Actuellement, STADD dispose de cinq containers répartis dans la ville de Lomé. Les habitants, généralement les plus défavorisé, peuvent venir y vendre les sachets qui leur sont achetés au kilo. Voici le témoignage de trois d'entre eux sur cette activité:

Nous sommes un groupe de jeunes d'horizons différents. story:
It has now been over 3 months, since we closed our doors due to the Covid-19 pandemic. This has now started to take it's toll. As a small wildlife park, which receives no government funding, we rely on entrance fees, school tours and our education workshops as our main sources of income. 

We have raised almost €9,000 on our Go Fund Me Campaign which we are so grateful for! We have decided to launch a crowdfunding campaign to encourage you to avail of perks e.g. A family pass at a much cheaper price, a certificate for your child to keep etc instead of you just donating as we thought this would be nice to do as a thank you.  But if you just want to donate and receive no perk please go here 

We have managed to continue to give our animals the best possible care up to this point through online pre-ticket sales and animal sponsorship's. Unfortunately this is no longer enough and we are asking for your help. 

Having tested our Go Fund me campaign and seeing the reaction, we decided to reach out globally to more people with perks to reward your generosity.

Over the past 14 years Secret Valley Wildlife Park has endeavored to educate our visitors and followers into plight of wild animals and the efforts we can make to conserve the environment and protect animals in the wild. 

We also work with an exotic animal rescue organisation based in Europe to provide a permanent home for exploited and neglected exotic animals.

We currently have four species of rescued primates, including capuchin monkeys and cotton-top tamarins which were rescued from the pet trade. Our most recent additions are four Rhesus Macaques which were saved from a Dutch Laboratory. Having endured horrible suffering while being used for neurological research, Bassie, Adriaan, Puyi and Tchang, can now live out the rest of their lives in peace at Secret Valley Wildlife Park. 

Please help us to continue providing a home for these special animals.
