story:
Imagine a world where a farmer who once subsisted on an income of less than $2 per day is now on the path to self-sufficiency.

Imagine a world where families earn enough income to no longer be at risk of losing farmland that has nurtured shade-grown coffee for over 30 years.

Consider the joy a farmer feels when he is able to send his daughter to school so she can pursue her dreams.

At Project Alianza, this is not only our vision.  It's our business plan. 

We are asking for your support in launching Project Alianza, a program that offers agricultural education and access to fair markets for coffee farming families in underserved communities, beginning in Jinotega, Nicaragua. 

Enrique is pictured standing on his family-run farm situated in Nicaragua’s most desirable coffee-growing region, referred to as ‘the coffee triangle.’ He has the potential to produce specialty-grade coffee and nearly double his coffee production. Like many farmers, he has not received formal agricultural training and sells his coffee through middlemen who offer only the lowest wholesale prices. As a result, Enrique  is not able to invest in his farm to improve his productivity.

Enrique is eager to learn how to improve his coffee farm and begin growing other fruits to diversify his income. With increased sales, he would pay school fees so his three daughters can attend school.


What will we create?

We want every coffee farmer like Enrique to have access to the knowledge and the resources to maximize the productivity of their land, and the opportunity to partner with ethical buyers so they can turn their efforts into income. We want them to reach their own goals: to maintain ownership of their land, educate their children, and control their own futures. To make this possible we will use the $8500 from this campaign to build partnerships with farmers and implement the Project Alianza pilot in Jinotega, Nicaragua.

Here is our plan:

  • Develop a mobile education program for up to 25 farmers, with a team of agricultural technicians that will visit each individual farm, teaching better ways to plant, tend, and market their coffee.
  • Improve access to farming technologies and promote bio-construction techniques with structures such as rainwater catchment and compost bins. 
  • Establish a sourcing plan with ecologically and socially conscious coffee companies. We have established a partnership with Ethical Coffee Chain, to connect farmers to international markets that bring our coffee to you, the consumer.
  • Gather information and disseminate best practices through networking and round-table discussions with industry leaders, cooperatives and experienced farmers, about topics such as new technology, diversification techniques, and strategies for improving quality control.
  • Continuously measure and evaluate our impact on farming families and communities, and systematically assess our successes and challenges as we move forward.
  • Document stories of farmers through photo essays and short videos.


Jesus invited us to his home in northwest Nicaragua, where he candidly shared his story of starting his career as a coffee picker, before eventually improving his own coffee farm enough to earn a livable wage from his own land. In 2012, his crop was devastated by a preventable coffee fungus, and as a result, he lost access to credible buyers and returned to life as a coffee picker.


Why invest in Project Alianza?


We change lives:

Alianza will build a community safety net to create access to agricultural knowledge and resources so farmers like Jesus are less vulnerable to environmental threats.

We go further:

While small farmer cooperatives and FairTrade certifications have made good progress in improving access to markets, we recognize the limitations of these programs: they can require expensive investments to join, they may be poorly regulated, and they are difficult to access for many of the smallest farmers. In addition, these efforts generally stop short of providing the knowledge and resources necessary to address the long-term challenges of farming families. That's where Alianza comes in: we partner directly with farmers who are in under-served areas and are the most vulnerable to threats such as pest or weather-related productivity loss, or corrupt microlending practices.

We're innovative:

We build stronger communities by promoting partnerships among small farmers and larger more established farms, who often already have the certifications to appeal to conscientious consumers and the distribution channels to reach them. As small farmers develop the resources and know-how to produce coffee at the highest standards of quality, they are also able to gain access to these preferred markets.

We believe in an evidenced-based approach:

Our program is based on research of what techniques are most likely to succeed within the local contexts of the communities we serve. We don't simply provide a higher price or teach a single skill, like better planting techniques. We provide a multi-faceted approach that improves living standards through education, farming resources and access to better markets.

We recognize the challenges ahead:

Like any new initiative, there can be unpredictable challenges along the way. We will work hard and our farming partners will have to take a leap a faith, putting in more hours and investing a proportion of their incomes to increase their long-term yields. Building local collaborations and listening to the concerns of our partners will be critical to ensuring program engagement.


Kristin, Project Alianza's Cofounder, is pictured above visiting Jesus's coffee and fruit farm in Northern Nicaragua.

Kristin was so inspired by the potential of this project to improve the lives of farming families, she applied for and received a Fulbright Fellowship to support her efforts. She recently left her job at a global policy research institute in Boston, MA to build Alianza from the ground up in Jinotega, Nicaragua.

Project Alianza has sustained our work through the generosity and efforts of a small but passionate army of volunteers, and now we are turning to Indiegogo to take Alianza to the next level.


San Benito flashes a heartwarming smile after a day harvesting coffee. 


Your funds put into action.


Your dollar is an investment in education and sustainability efforts facilitated by our on-the-ground partners. 100% of our earnings go directly to our farming partners. The portion of our funds we don’t raise on indiegogo will have to be raised by other means to support critical programming to change the lives of these farmers.

  • $25 supports a plot of five coffee plants for up to five years. The coffee plant produces an average of 2 lbs of coffee for up to 30 years!
  • $100 provides a loan in the form of seed and fertilizer to a family who lacks access to the financing needed to support a small-scale farm.
  • $950 supports a year of tuition for a coffee farming family to participate in an agricultural education program. Farmers learn about sustainability and experiment with growing techniques which allow them to become rooted in their community.

________________________________________________________________

Please feel free to contact us at info@projectalianza.org.

Project Alianza is a pending 501(c)(3). All donations are tax deductible. 

Thank you for your support.

     plant, tend, and market their coffee.

Improve access to
     farming technologies and promote bio-construction techniques with structures such as rainwater catchment and compost bins. 

Establish a sourcing plan with ecologically and socially conscious coffee companies. We have established a partnership with Ethical Coffee Chain, to connect farmers to international markets that bring our coffee to you, the consumer. 

Gather information and disseminate best practices through networking and round-table discussions with industry leaders, cooperatives and experienced farmers, about topics such as new technology, diversification techniques, and strategies for improving quality control.

Continuously measure and evaluate our impact on farming families and communities, and systematically assess our successes and challenges as we move forward.

Document stories of farmers through photo essays and short videos.

Jesus invited us to his home in northwest Nicaragua, where he candidly
shared his story of starting his career as a coffee picker, before eventually improving his own coffee farm enough to earn a livable wage from his own land. In 2012, his crop was devastated by a preventable coffee fungus, and as a result, he lost access to credible buyers and returned to life as a coffee picker.
Why invest in Project Alianza?
We change lives:
Alianza will build a community safety net to create access to agricultural knowledge and resources so farmers like Jesus are less
vulnerable to environmental threats.
We go further:
While small farmer cooperatives and FairTrade certifications have made good progress in improving access to markets, we recognize the limitations of these programs: they can require expensive investments to join, they may be poorly regulated, and they are difficult to access for many of the smallest farmers. In addition, these efforts generally stop short of providing the knowledge and resources necessary to address the long-term challenges of farming families. That's where Alianza comes in: we partner directly with farmers who are in under-served areas and are the most vulnerable to threats such as pest or weather-related productivity loss, or corrupt microlending practices.
We're innovative:
We build stronger communities by promoting partnerships among small farmers and larger more established farms, who often already have the certifications to appeal to conscientious consumers and the distribution channels to reach them. As small farmers develop the resources and know-how to produce coffee at the highest standards of quality, they are also able to gain access to these preferred markets.
We believe in an evidenced-based approach:
Our program is based on research of what techniques are most likely to succeed within the local contexts of the communities we serve. We don't simply provide a higher price or teach a single skill, like better planting techniques. We provide a multi-faceted approach that improves living standards through education, farming resources and access to better markets.
We recognize the challenges ahead:
Like any new initiative, there can be unpredictable challenges along the way. We will work hard and our farming partners will have to take a leap a faith, putting in more hours and investing a proportion of their incomes to increase their long-term yields. Building local collaborations and listening to the concerns of our partners will be critical to ensuring program engagement.

Kristin, Project Alianza's Cofounder, is pictured above visiting Jesus's coffee and fruit farm in Northern Nicaragua. 

Kristin was so inspired by the potential of this project to improve the lives of farming families, she applied for and received a Fulbright Fellowship to support her efforts. She recently left her job at a global policy research institute in Boston, MA to build Alianza from the ground up in Jinotega, Nicaragua.
Project Alianza has sustained our work through the generosity and efforts of a small but passionate army of volunteers, and now we are turning to Indiegogo to take Alianza to the next level.San Benito flashes a heartwarming smile after a day harvesting coffee. 
Your funds put into action.
Your dollar is an investment in education and sustainability efforts facilitated by our on-the-ground partners. 100% of our earnings go directly to our farming partners. The portion of our funds we don’t raise on indiegogo will have to be raised by other means to support critical programming to change the lives of these farmers.
$25 supports a plot of five coffee plants for up to five years. The coffee plant produces an average of 2 lbs of coffee for up to 30 years!
$100 provides a loan in the form of seed and fertilizer to a family who lacks access to the financing needed to support a small-scale farm.
$950 supports a year of tuition for a coffee farming family to participate in an agricultural education program. Farmers learn about sustainability and experiment with growing techniques which allow them to become rooted in their community.

________________________________________________________________Please feel free to contact us at info@projectalianza.org.Project Alianza is a pending 501(c)(3). All donations are tax deductible. Thank you for your support.

story:
Growing in a farm, I’ve always loved working outside. My love for nature flourished in high school when I joined the outdoor club. I got to hiked several mountains in central Java.

After high school, I went to Northern Arizona to study biology. Flagstaff and its surrounding were a perfect fit for me. Knowing little about America, I chose NAU mainly because of its proximity to the Grand . Here I got to explore not only the Grand Canyon, but also San Francisco Peaks, Sedona, and the southwest desert.; and I picked up rock climbing. I used the same criterion when it came to choose the place to continue my study at Colorado State University in Fort Collins.

My outdoor passion follows me wherever I go. I discovered the joy of sharing knowledge when I had the privilege to teach climbing at an indoor gym in Seattle. For six years I introduced people of all ages to rock climbing; and for six summers I had the honor to take these friends for their first outdoor climbing experience.

My outdoor activity went off-shore in Seattle. I learned sailing from the great people at the Center for Wooden Boats in Seattle. The gracious folks of this wonderful institution let me help out and shared their knowledge with me. I eventually was able to raise money to buy a 42-yo sailboat. For my last two years in the States, I had a blast sharing this classic plastic with friends.

This combination of love for nature and sharing it with others has led me to this endeavor: to build an ecolodge where people of all ages and cultures can enjoy an experiential learning in nature conservation.

Upon my return from living in the States for more than 20 years, I met the family of Mr. Sudarli who owns a plot of land on the coast. Mr. Sudarli is a tireless conservationist. Born and raised in the village of Purwodadi, Gunung Kidul Regency, he has been working since the 1980s not only to restore the environment that had been destroyed  since 1960s. His efforts have also empowered the villagers. The culture for nature conservation that he instilled in the area has brought sustainable improvements to the village. People have been able to farm on these karst hills and harvest the timber with minimal impact to their environment.

The village of Purwodadi, Gunung Kidul Regency, is two hours away from Yogyakarta, a college town and one of the main tourism destinations in the country. The land consists of one acre of arable valley, flanked by relatively steep hills. The overall area is four acres. The valley and some parts of the hills have been farmed for the past four decades. We want to return this land into a productive forest by planting fruit trees on the valley and lumber trees on the hill sides. Once this forest matures, we hope to have the old spring return to the area. In this forest, we want to build an ecolodge in the hopes of bringing in an additional economic injection to the area.

There are popular beaches in and around the village. But most visitors only stay for no more than several hours. This pattern of behavior only benefits mainly the businesses near those beaches. By having an ecolodge, guests will stay longer and spend more currency to more businesses.

I hope to attract local and foreign tourists to stay longer in this area by providing lodging and experiential learning opportunities about nature conservation in the area. For the local visitors, I will offer an English camp/retreat to learn and practice their English with a heavy emphasis on nature.

The lodge will also provide a place to stay for people who want to explore the numerous caves in the area and climb at a nearby popular climbing spot, Siung Beach. This area has other places where there are undeveloped limestone cliffs boulders within 30 minute walking distance from the lodge.

This fund will be used to build an ecolodge facility that will be the first of its kind in the area. It is the natural next step on the process of empowering the locals. We hope to use the ecolodge to provide a new model for a small scale/family run business.

We do not plan to build a mega resort. We have put an upper limit of a 20-guest capacity for our facility. We will scrutinize every possible impact, record every step and share what we learn to the guests directly and general public on our website.  We will also share our knowledge to the villagers or anyone to start their own ecolodges if there is indeed a demand for such a venture in the area. Mr. Sudarli is also an instructor at the local community college (Universitas Gunung Kidul – UGK) teaching conservation. We hope to develop an academic cooperation with UGK and may eventually start a curriculum on ecotourism using what we learn from our ecolodge.

We need US$8050 to build the commons, five cabins, one kitchen, two shower stalls, two composting toilets, water supply and rainwater catchment systems, solar power system, fruit tree saplings, and marketing materials.

The following prices of items include the cost of materials, labor, transport and indiegogo fee.

We will build one Commons building , 3 by 6 m2, which costs $750. We plan to spend $400 to build a kitchen and furnish it with smokeless biomass stoves and storage cabinets.The cabins will cost $300 each and we want to build five of them. The kitchen and cabins are 3x3 m2. All buildings are made of bamboo and thatched roofs. Wash sinks are available in all buildings.

There will be two shower stalls ($100 each)  and two composting toilets ($125 each).

To supply the place with water, initially we will connect to an existing pipeline that supplies water to the valley below from a spring, two kilometers away. We are required to obtain a 5-HP water pump that costs $500, build a storage house for it that will cost an additional $250, and get additional pipes for $150 to complete this project. This pump will deliver the water to one 1200 L tank on our property that will be placed higher than the buildings for gravity-fed plumbing system.

We do not plan to solely rely on the above system. We will also place one 1200 L tank to collect rainwater from each cabin and the kitchen and one 5500 L water tank for the commons. In total, we will need seven 1200 L tanks ($150/tank) and one 5500 L tank ($750) for rainwater catchment.

The farm is off the grid, so we want to install a solar-power system. We want to start with a 100-watt system to fill the need for lighting and charging. But eventually we want to add more power for refrigeration, water pumping, other electrical equipments that we may need. A 100-W system will be a good start for a modular expansion. This initial need will cost us $1500.

To start the planting, we will get saplings from reputable nurseries in and around Gunung Kidul Regency. In the first year, we will concentrate on planting fruit trees on the upper half of the valley. For every fruit tree, we will plant five supporting trees and ground covers. These supporting trees are nitrogen-fixing trees. We hope to plant the whole valley with fruit trees by the end of second year. Ground covers will also be planted to reduce water evaporation, increase fertility and provide a source for vegetables. We expect to spend $300 on planting.

To market the ecolodge, we will need $500 to start. We will use print and electronic media, and visit to institutions to promote our ecolodge and educational programs.

For a complete list of items and costs, please check Indiegogo Fundraising Round Two on our website, http://lenggokofarm.wordpress.com/

We accept any amount of donations. We will immortalize your donations by naming our plants and facilities after you.

For $10-25, we will put your name on an herb; for $50 dollars, we will name a fruit tree after you; with a $100 donation, we will name a hardy tree for you;  and for $500, we will designate a hut or a plot of garden with your name.

Each donation will be a part of our facilities and last for as long as our facilities exist. We will send you a picture of your plant or garden, and update you with its progress.

The main infrastructure that has to be present is the water supply system.  We will build this first. Having a reliable water source in our property will allow us to live on the land and start the project full time.

Water is also a necessity to start building the structures. The first building that we need is the Commons. We can use the building not only as the classroom, but also lodging for our instructional programs. There are two huts already available in the farm that can be used as the kitchen and storage.

One shower stall and one composting toilet will be the additional structures to have the to kickstart our venture.

Our overarching goals are nature conservancy and education. This ecolodge will provide a place to develop a sustainable business model for this area specifically and contribute to ecotourism in general. This ecolodge will offer a more responsible alternative to the conventional tourism for those who love to travel.

We have a living Business Plan, which contains the details of our plans, on our website. To continually improve our business practices, we will update this plan when necessary. We will also welcome and respond accordingly to all criticisms and suggestions.

While direct financial contributions are highly appreciated, we also hope that you help us to spread the word. This networking assistance is also indispensible.

Again, our current website is http://lenggokofarm.wordpress.com/

Thank you so very much for your kind attention.

story:
Summary

My name is Bob O'Hara, and I have been a solar technician in New Orleans, Louisiana for nearly 5 years.  Upon returning to New Orleans in 2008, I began working in the solar industry on various renewable energy projects throughout Louisiana.  

In the summer of 2009, I noticed that there was an uninstalled Solar Hot Water system sitting in the warehouse which houses the Lower 9th Ward Village Center, a community organization which works to bring back homeowners to the 9th Ward and assist in the rebuilding of the neighborhood, which was devasted by Hurricane Katrina.  

I took it upon myself to attempt to get this system installed for the organization, as they had limited funds to pay for the extra equipment and labor required to make the system operational, and the original contractor was unable to install the system due to a debilitating illness.

In 2011, several solar companies came together to install half of the Solar Hot Water system, pictured above.  

Today, this same group, GSREIA (Gulf States Renewable Energy Industries Assocation (www.gsreia.org) is poised to finish the installation in June.  This event will coincide with Solar Day 2013, which will be June 29, 2013, but we need funds in order to pay for the extra materials we need to complete the project.

 

What We Need & What You Get

We need:

  • $750+ for copper tubing, fittings, valves
  • $500+ for racking to mount the 3 remaining solar collectors
  • $400-500 for possible replacement of drainback solar water tank
  • $500-750 for plumbing and commissioning of system 

For your support of $25 or more, you get a solar site assessment of your home in Louisiana from Joule Solar Energy, personally done by Bob O'Hara.  I'll provide you with the information you need to put solar electric and/or solar hot water on your home!

The Benefits and Impact:

  • Solar Hot Water is available to the 9th Ward Village/Lil Wayne Skate Park, allowing the organization to save money on its energy bills each month.
  • The Lower 9th Ward Village can continue to benefit the Lower 9th Ward in its operations and assist in the rebuilding of the neighborhood.
  • All funds generated will be going towards finishing this solar installation, providing the 9th Ward Village/Lil Wayne Skate Park with greater financial, environmental, and social benefits.
  • This organization has a solar electric system installed on its grounds, and with the addition of a solar hot water system, the facility will be able to operate more independently, lowering the financial burden to the organization and decreasing its carbon footprint.
  • Within the last month, Bob O'Hara and another Joule solar technician taught a solar installation class in Vermont, in which 12 inexperienced students completed a fully operational solar electric system for a client in 5 days.  This solar hot water project can be completed and working in a short period of time with your help.
  • GSREIA also has a track record of positive community involvement, advancing the cause of renewable energy in communities throughout the Gulf South, and in its home, New Orleans, Louisiana.
  • This installation will provide an example to the community, showing that renewable energy is within the reach of everyone.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Go to GSREIA.org and find out more about renewable energy in your area.
  • Spread the word through social media about our campaign!  
  • Show your support for Solar Day 2013--More news on this event to come!

story:
The video here is the promotional video from ISV which includes other projects such as community development and children's programs as well as wildlife conservation and environmental management.

Our Story

 Hi everybody! My name is Stephanie Arcusa, I am a junior student from the University of Massachusetts Amherst. I have two passions in life. The first one is to travel, and that I have covered extensively within Europe but this will be my first time in South America. I am so excited! I bet it's wonderful :) My second passion, and the one which is driving me forward, is the environment. I am currently studying Geosciences which is a mix of geography and geology for those who don't know :) It's incredibly challenging and exciting because the Earth cannot speak, it cannot tell us where she hurts or how she feels. In recent times we've all heard too many environmental disasters happening around the world. Some in distant lands, others much closer to home. It is time to take action I say, before the Earth has had ENOUGH!

This May 2012, I am therefore volunteering in Ecuador with a non-profit, U.S. based organisation called International Student Volunteers (ISV). I will take part in an exciting and educational four week environmental conservation program where I will participate with several other students, in hands-on world saving! I will replant native trees where deforestation has occurred, I will teach children about caring for the environment, I will help set up recycling programs as well as encouraging the local people to farm sustainably and organically. I will work towards making Ecuador a sustainable economy where natives and the environment alike can live in harmony and prosper. 

The Impact

As of July 2011, Ecuador has a population of over 15 million people. Local people rely heavily on the land to survive as well as to export. As a result deforestation and pollution are widespread which in turn is affecting the population. ISV volunteers talk to local people about sustainable organic farming in an attempt to conserve Ecuador's natural resources. iSV volunteers also set up recycling programs to make sure the environment is not degraded and to cut down on waste. Also important, ISV volunteers help Ecuador become an eco-tourism world destination providing a sustainable future to its population.


Ecuador is the home of a part of the Amazon rain forest, a forest full of rare and exotic plant and animal species. Many of which are used by Northern countries to make pharmaceutical drugs such as Quinine from the cinchona tree which is used to treat malaria. Apparently, less than 5% of the species have been analysed for their chemical compounds and medicinal value. Deforestation is destroying our chance to find a cure for cancer! By supporting this cause you will give chemists more time to discover the wonders of the Ecuadorian rainforest. You will also make sure species such as the Golden Mantled Tamarin and the White Bellied Spider monkey keep their home. In the past year ISV volunteers have planted over 3000 native trees.


Something you might not have thought of: the rainforest is a key area in terms of climate, it helps regulating it by absorbing CO2. Deforestation not only removes carbon sinks but also releases more CO2 into the atmosphere as machines work through the forest. By supporting this cause you will make sure the situation with climate change will not become worse than it already is.


Ecuador is also home to mangrove forests which have despairingly been cut down to almost 10%. Mangroves are really useful to the local population as well as for the world's oceans. Mangroves provide erosion control as well as the nutrients necessary for the oceanic food chain. They are also home to hundreds of animal species many of which are sustenance to local fisheries. Mangroves also have the ability to purify water by replenishing it in oxygen. By supporting this cause you will ensure that deforested areas will be replanted thus sustaining local populations as well as the global food chain. In the past year, ISV volunteers have planted 10,700 seeds.


By supporting this cause you will help ensure Ecuador's people have a sustainable future, that the world's oceans keep receiving a plentiful supply of nutrients, that the rainforest remains intact for its beauty and for the species living in it and finally that every attempt is made to keep climate change under control.

What We Need & What You Get

Well folks, here's the deal. This volunteering trip will cost approximately $6000 dollars. This includes accommodation, meals, project material and support, ground transportation and tour guidance. I am aiming to raise $1000 or more through this website as I have other fundraising activities going on elsewhere. For example, donations from friends and family, donations from the very generous local businesses and a soon to happen raffle.


What you get from this is, first of all, the sense that you are making a difference in the world because you know that this organisation DOES make a difference. Second, you become a philanthropist, the most generous and self-less type of human being on Earth. Third, you get a reward :D


Other Ways You Can Help

Here are other ways you can help.


1. Check out my Facebook page and LIKE IT!
    http://www.facebook.com/pages/Ecuador-Volunteer...


2. Share this page in anyway way you can, Facebook, Twitter anything!


3. If you have a business (or you know one who are looking to donate), let me know! Any donations made by businesses paying taxes in the U.S. are tax-deductible because ISV is a non-profit organisation. I would be more than happy to send you a tax-deduction form!
story_txt:
The video here is the promotional video from ISV which includes other 
projects such as community development and children's programs as well 
as wildlife conservation and environmental management.
Our Story
 Hi everybody! My name is Stephanie Arcusa, I am a junior student from the University of Massachusetts Amherst. I have two passions in life. The first one is to travel, and that I have covered extensively within Europe but this will be my first time in South America. I am so excited! I bet it's wonderful :) My second passion, and the one which is driving me forward, is the environment. I am currently studying Geosciences which is a mix of geography and geology for those who don't know :) It's incredibly challenging and exciting because the Earth cannot speak, it cannot tell us where she hurts or how she feels. In recent times we've all heard too many environmental disasters happening around the world. Some in distant lands, others much closer to home. It is time to take action I say, before the Earth has had ENOUGH! This May 2012, I am therefore volunteering in Ecuador with a non-profit, U.S. based organisation called International Student Volunteers (ISV). I will take part in an exciting and educational four week environmental conservation program where I will participate with several other students, in hands-on world saving! I will replant native trees where deforestation has occurred, I will teach children about caring for the environment, I will help set up recycling programs as well as encouraging the local people to farm sustainably and organically. I will work towards making Ecuador a sustainable economy where natives and the environment alike can live in harmony and prosper. 

The Impact
As of July 2011, Ecuador has a population of over 15 million people. 
Local people rely heavily on the land to survive as well as to export. 
As a result deforestation and pollution are widespread which in turn is 
affecting the population. ISV volunteers talk to local people about 
sustainable organic farming in an attempt to conserve Ecuador's natural 
resources. iSV volunteers also set up recycling programs to make sure 
the environment is not degraded and to cut down on waste. Also 
important, ISV volunteers help Ecuador become an eco-tourism world 
destination providing a sustainable future to its population.

Ecuador is the home of a part of the Amazon rain forest, a forest full of rare and exotic plant and animal species. Many of which are used by Northern countries to make pharmaceutical drugs such as Quinine from the cinchona tree which is used to treat malaria. Apparently, less than 5% of the species have been analysed for their chemical compounds and medicinal value. Deforestation is destroying our chance to find a cure for cancer! By supporting this cause you will give chemists more time to discover the wonders of the Ecuadorian rainforest. You will also make sure species such as the Golden Mantled Tamarin and the White Bellied Spider monkey keep their home. In the past year ISV volunteers have planted over 3000 native trees.

Something you might not have thought of: the rainforest is a key area in terms of climate, it helps regulating it by absorbing CO2. Deforestation not only removes carbon sinks but also releases more CO2 into the atmosphere as machines work through the forest. By supporting this cause you will make sure the situation with climate change will not become worse than it already is.

Ecuador is also home to mangrove forests which have despairingly been cut down to almost 10%. Mangroves are really useful to the local population as well as for the world's oceans. Mangroves provide erosion control as well as the nutrients necessary for the oceanic food chain. They are also home to hundreds of animal species many of which are sustenance to local fisheries. Mangroves also have the ability to purify water by replenishing it in oxygen. By supporting this cause you will ensure that deforested areas will be replanted thus sustaining local populations as well as the global food chain. In the past year, ISV volunteers have planted 10,700 seeds. 

By supporting this cause you will help ensure Ecuador's people have a sustainable future, that the world's oceans keep receiving a plentiful supply of nutrients, that the rainforest remains intact for its beauty and for the species living in it and finally that every attempt is made to keep climate change under control.

What We Need & What You Get
Well folks, here's the deal. This volunteering trip will cost approximately $6000 dollars. This includes accommodation, meals, project material and support, ground transportation and tour guidance. I am aiming to raise $1000 or more through this website as I have other fundraising activities going on elsewhere. For example, donations from friends and family, donations from the very generous local businesses and a soon to happen raffle. 

What you get from this is, first of all, the sense that you are making a difference in the world because you know that this organisation DOES make a difference. Second, you become a philanthropist, the most generous and self-less type of human being on Earth. Third, you get a reward :D


Other Ways You Can Help
Here are other ways you can help.

1. Check out my Facebook page and LIKE IT!     http://www.facebook.com/pages/Ecuador-Volunteer...

2. Share this page in anyway way you can, Facebook, Twitter anything!

3. If you have a business (or you know one who are looking to donate), let me know! Any donations made by businesses paying taxes in the U.S. are tax-deductible because ISV is a non-profit organisation. I would be more than happy to send you a tax-deduction form!

story:
We met our goal!  Any money raised above $5,000 will support 30th anniversary organizing.

---

NEW and IMPROVED Bhopal.net

We are the International Campaign for Justice in Bhopal - North America, the North American branch of an international solidarity network of students, professionals, and activists that was set up to address the grave injustices suffered by half a million Bhopalis. We are all volunteers dedicated to supporting the struggle of Bhopalis 30 years after the Union-Carbide pesticide factory leaked toxic gas and killed more than 20,000 people that evening and over the years.

Sadly, 30 years later Bhopal is still seeking justice and corporations continue to make decisions that put their profits ahead of the well-being of people and the planet. There is a cost to this human suffering and no community should have to pay for careless industrialization.

What do we do?
Using education, grassroots organizing, and non-violent direct action, ICJB-NA works to hold Dow Chemical & the Indian Government accountable for the ongoing disaster in Bhopal. Demands include acceptance of liability, monetary compensation, health care for the victims, and remediation of the abandoned factory site.

What do we believe?
ICJB is at the epicenter of the global movement towards corporate accountability. If we do not remember, condemn, and demand justice in Bhopal, then there is nothing stopping government and corporations from prioritizing profit over human & environmental health again and again. A global precedent must be set, and Bhopal must be that precedent!


THE PROJECT: BHOPAL.NET

Bhopal.net is the primary resource on the web about the campaign for justice in Bhopal, the story of the movement, and it provides ways for people to take action around the world.  Our Tech Team has a vision of one comprehensive and up-to-date website for the campaign. But with 15 years of content across multiple websites, this is a huge project!  There are 2,500 posts/pages to organize!

What We Need
Our Tech Team is amazing, but functions on a volunteer basis only, and thus doesn't have time to complete this project by the end of the summer

We have years of web content. It's a detailed history of the campaign and we want to keep this as a resource to future organizers, and as a historical record of the movement for justice in Bhopal. We want to hire someone (we know you're out there!) who has the mind of a librarian with the Wordpress skills.


We believe it will take someone three months of working full-time to organize all and categorize all the content, consolidate it, migrate it to the new site, write content for the new site, and work with the tech team to complete the site by the end of the summer.

If there is any additional time left, the contractor will help us promote the new site launch.

10 weeks  -  Web Content Consultant ($500/week); $5,000

If we don't raise the entire goal, we will still proceed with the project and hire someone with as much money as we raise.  The project may not be completed until a later date if the goal isn't reached.

If we exceed our goal, any additional money will support 30th anniversary organizing in Bhopal.

Perks
We have some awesome perks! 


Other Ways You Can Help

Please spread the word about this campaign. $5,000 is a lot of money for our small campaign to raise but the website is a resource that has international impact. We must continue to remind the world of what happened in 1984. The gas disaster illustrates how real lives are devastated by companies that put their profits ahead of the health of people and the environment.

  1. Please share the link to this campaign on your Facebook page.
  2. Send an email to people you know encouraging them to give.
  3. Volunteer your time with the campaign. We are always looking for more people to join our Community Relations, Media, Education, and Admin/Finance committees.
Thank you for making this possible!

NOTE: All donations are tax deductible to the fullest extent allowed by law through our fiscal sponsor, the Pesticide Action Network.

story:
We need a truck!

Free I.T. Athens is an all-volunteer 501c3 non-profit institution founded in 2005. Our mission is to reduce e-waste, promote technology re-use, help close the digital divide, offer technology education, and advocate for free software and open alternatives.


Since its founding in 2005, Free I.T. Athens has diverted more than 100 tons of unusable equipment from landfills.  Subsequently, we have been able to distribute over 2,500 refurbished computers to individuals, community groups, churches, and non-profits in Cameroon, El Salvador, Peru, and the United States.

Since January of 2015, we have distributed over 300 recycled computers to individuals and families in need. In the same time period, we have distributed over 60 computers to community groups and nonprofit organizations in Athens (and as far as the Russian Federation), working in the impact areas of domestic violence, mental health, homelessness, education, mediation, public health and HIV/AIDs.



Free I.T. Athens
  • accepts and collects unwanted computer-related materials.
  • sorts, refurbishes, or responsibly recycles unwanted equipment.
  • manages a volunteer base of support, training them in GNU/Linux, hardware refurbishing, customer service, and basic management. (Volunteers are rewarded with a refurbished computer after 30 hours of service.)
  • teaches public training classes in GNU/Linux, freely licensed software, Creative Commons, etc.
  • fulfills equipment grant requests for non-profits and start-ups.
  • offers donation-based tech support to the community at-large.
  • sells refurbished computers and parts.


Now, as we celebrate our 10th anniversary, we are confronted with a larger donation base than our founders could have imagined or anticipated.


We are asking for $5000 so that we can
  • purchase a used vehicle.
  • pay the necessary insurance.
  • create a fuel fund.
  • create a parts fund in case of repairs. (We have the labor covered!)


In order to meet the growing needs of Free I.T. Athens' donors and clients, we need a pick-up truck. Volunteers making multiple trips to pick up donations in their cars is becoming less and less sustainable and unnecessarily increases our carbon footprint.
 



Please help by making whatever tax-deductible donation is comfortable for you. The perks are so amazing that you'll probably want to tell your friends. Please do because....we need a truck!



See more about Free I.T. Athens history and our mission in this video.

Visit FreeITAthens.org

Like Free I.T. Athens on Facebook

Thank you.

p.s. Just in case we are lucky enough to receive a donated, used truck, we will continue this campaign and allocate the funds for fuel, repairs, and insurance.

story:
Climate-related natural risks, such as flooding, hurricanes, drought, wildfire and extreme heat, occur frequently and cause huge economic loss each year. As climate risks are getting more and more common, there is no doubt that many aspects of people’s lives are being threatened.

Among all the major climate risks above, let's take a look at flooding and see how it may affect us in the near future.

Climate change is no longer a remote and irrelevant issue. It has become more extreme and severe. Ultimately, no matter where you live, it is possible that your community and property will be impacted by one or more types of extreme climate events. Being able to assess them and plan ahead is a critical precaution step that everyone should consider taking.

Climate.IQ® is our new and exciting web application designed to gauge the current and future climate risk level and projected financial loss for all properties in the US. Climate.IQ® is searchable by zip code or mailing address. Simply click on a property or pencil around the area, then you will receive information such as risk score, historical flooding depth and future projection, hurricane frequency and intensity, and  potential building replacement value. 

In the 2016 MIT Climate CoLab Competition, Climate.IQ® won the Popular Choice Prize “for high novelty and innovation”. To know more about Climate.IQ®, please check us out at https://climate-iq.com/ 

Without doubt, Climate.IQ® is based on complex science. However, on the user side, we have made Climate.IQ® easy to understand and use. Now let's walk you through Climate.IQ® with its analysis for New York JFK Airport area. You can get a comprehensive understanding of this area by following 3 simple steps!

*Please note all snapshots shown below are for demonstration only and illustrative.

Step 1:  Choose a climate hazard category from the click down menu

Choose a hazard category that you are concerned about. In this specific example, click on coastal flooding and sea level rise.

Step 2:  Select a different property or infrastructure layer

To examine different assets of the area, you can click on the left menu to see different infrastructure layers, such as residential or commercial buildings, sewage infrastructure, street drainage, hospitals, fire stations and more.

Step 3:  Click on an individual property

To access more advanced information, simply click on an individual property, you can find out an historical risk score and a forecasted financial loss, based on climate change scenarios.

Generally speaking, Climate.IQ®’s analysis selects the most useful information to help you understand what climate change impact has been in the past and may be in the future for properties, and all information is displayed in an intuitive and easy-to-understand way.

We are dedicated to supplying the analysis in an easy to-use application, available to all. Climate.IQ® provides the data and modeling at the level of one property at a time across the US for users to obtain a risk score for a prediction from now, year 1 to year 100 showing increased risk in 10 year increments. We think that this can be seriously important information for all our user groups, including home owners, realtors, city planners, governments and many more!

We offer Climate.IQ® Beta reports as perks for your kind contributions. The reports can be for a sample property or your own property depending on the perk you claim. All reports will include flooding and hurricane risk analysis. For each disaster, we will provide risk score, score interpretation, risk forecasting, historical event analysis along with other additional information. 

*Carbon Credits: We are also dedicated to deceasing greenhouse gas (GHG) emitted into our atmosphere, and we hope you can join us in this effort. On average, an individual living in the US generates about 33,000 grams of CO2 per day, which equals to 1 ton per month and 12 tons per year. 

We work with Carbon Credit Capital, a company specializing in reducing people’s and companies' carbon footprints with carbon offset credits to help build a healthier environment. By purchasing carbon credits, you can offset the GHG you generate by supporting GHG reduction projects that take equivalent amounts of GHGs out of the atmosphere. Carbon Credit Capital will retire the exact amount of carbon credits you pay for, and you will receive confirmation of your contribution to a more stable environment each calendar quarter. Let's lead a carbon free life!

Know more about Carbon Credit Capital’s GHG reduction projects at: https://www.carboncreditcapital.com/index.php/our-projects/

Visit the About section of this page to know more about our team members!

Through this Indiegogo funding campaign, we would like to raise $200K to further refine our climate risk modeling, data sources and complete the computer programming. 

This funding campaign will last for only 10 further days! We hope you will join us to complete this phase of our work. You will receive Climate.IQ property scores for any location in the US as a perk to show our gratitude for your kind support!

Empowering people with accurate climate intelligence has always been our mission, let’s make it happen together!

Q: What is Climate.IQ®'s coverage?

A: So far Climate.IQ® can assess flooding and hurricane risk in all 50 states of the US. In the future, we plan to expand coverage to all major climate disasters including flooding, hurricane, drought, extreme heat, extreme cold and wildfire at property scale.

Q: How accurate are your risk reports?

A: We are using the most authoritative public data sources available. However, inevitable statistical errors may still exist. To best address that issue, we will provide uncertainty levels in all reports, and we will constantly update our data and analytics to improve the reliability of our information.

Q: How do I reach out to Climate.IQ® team?

A: You can reach us simply by posting a question in the public comments section, or by sending us an email at info@cincs.com.

Q: How will I receive perks?

A: Perks will be delivered through email. For custom report purchasers, we will reach out by email requesting information we need to generate the custom reports after the campaign ends. 

 

OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP

1 - Spread our campaign on social media!  We need everyone concerned with climate risk to share our campaign with as many people as possible. Thank you!

2- Support our social media! Like us on Facebook, or follow us on Twitter.

3- Sign up for our newsletter on www.climate-iq.com to keep updated with the latest climate news and Climate.IQ® development.

4 - Give us your feedback by sending an email to our support team at info@cincs.com!

Once again we appreciate your interest in Climate.IQ®! Let us make climate risks better known to all of us!

story:
Imagine an Edible Neighborhood.  One where fruit grows along the sidewalks for everyone to enjoy.  Growing Community

An Edible Neighborhood is a community where the neighbors plant perennial fruit in their front yards and along the sidewalks for their neighbors to enjoy.

It’s about generosity and connection among neighbors.  It’s about growing in appreciation of the power and delight of nature, cultivated. It’s about being an oasis in a food desert and resilience.  It’s about growing food and community in all the space available.

Community gardens are such a great impact on community.  Edible Neighborhood extends that to the sidewalk, and focuses on perennial plants, especially trees that will produce for 20 or 30 years.  Also perennial herbs and perennial edible flowers.  

This program will complete our pilot project in the Chosewood Park neighborhood, a
community hit hard by the housing bust.  Phase 1 started a year ago with the planting of a couple dozen fruit trees, a few dozen perennial herbs, and hundreds and hundreds of edible flowers. Those plantings are doing well.  And with the additional plantings here we will be able to offer fruit trees and berries to lower income neighbors for free. 

Administered by the Chosewood Park Community Development Corporation, your donation is tax deductible.  This program is guided by Clay Preston and Greg Ramsey, architects and planners who each have 15 years of experience designing sustainable communities that incorporate organic farms in every project.  Their assistance is donated.

A fig tree 8 months after planting

What We Need & What You Get

With the $2800 requested we will multiply the plantings that are already done, and provide fresh fruit to all the neighbors in this ethnically and income diverse neighborhood. 

Your contribution pays for a healthy plant to be planted by volunteers.  But it also provides a very small amount to pay an under-employed neighbor to keep the plants watered through hot, dry July and August.  We will also bring in an orchard expert to conduct free workshops on care and pruning of the varieties planted.  5% of the funds will be used to spread the concept and to initiate the next Edible Neighborhood.

If we raise less than the target goal:  all of the funds will be used to plant all the fruit we can.  If we fall far short of the goal, then the Orchard expert will not get an honorarium for our workshops.  Underfunding will reduce our reach in spreading the concept of Edible Neighborhood and of course, Indiegogo takes a larger share (6% instead of 3%) for the service.

The Impact



This is a map of the actual plantings to date.  Your plant will be mapped, and your name included in the metadata on the map marker.  View Chosewood NOW Plantings in a larger map


Bonds of friendship are harvested when gathering together to pick apples, plums, figs, and other fruit; connection to the Earth and her seasons; delight for the senses and connection across generations.

And literally across generations.  Fruit trees planted this year will be bearing fruit until 2040 and beyond. This is growing resilience for a community.

But beyond this neighborhood, Edible Neighborhood will be established as recognized, reproducible program that can be taken to neighborhoods everywhere.  5% of the funds we collect will be used to promote the concept of Edible Neighborhood to community gardens, neighborhood associations, and community development organizations through social media and providing how-to guides for free.

Other Ways You Can Help

Is Edible Neighborhood a good concept?  If you believe it is, then please share this program with your community of friends.  Like and Share the Facebook page.  If you are so moved, then we would be very glad to have your donation of a tree, bush, or herb.  But in any case, please do share the idea.

What happens if we encourage, “invision”, communities to make edible landscapes a part of what draws them together and brings them delight?

The concept of the Edible Neighborhood focuses on cultivating edible perennials that are located so neighbors have easy access to the plants. This is a community development project that is very effective financially.  A small investment will provide returns of food and community for decades.

community in all the space available.

story:
Butterfly Town USA Takes a stand for Monarchs and Bees by distributing thousands of artist created Save Our Pollinators Action kits. These Kits include a postcard addressed to the Committee on Agriculture which is currently considering HR 2692, " The Save America's Pollinators Act 2013 and a Native Pollinator Seed Mix specific to the Central Coast of California. 

SHORT SUMMARY

Hi. My name is Michelle Magdalena Maddox and I am a photographer and activist who lives in Pacific Grove California, known as Butterfly Town USA. Our Monarch Sanctuary hosts thousands of Monarchs when they migrate here from as far as 2,000 miles away. Monarchs are beautiful and intrepid but they are also in trouble, losing the habitat that sustains them and being poisoned by unregulated pesticides at alarming rates. 

I’m working with poet and designer Meredith Stricker to create and distribute thousands of Save Our Pollinators Action kits. It is up to all of us to join together and help protect Monarchs along with other threatened pollinators!

THE MAGNITUDE OF THIS PROJECT + WHERE THE FUNDING IS GOING 

Our goal is to take immediate and practical action to protect butterflies and bees, which in turn sustain our food sources, gardens and life on earth.   

Your contribution will help us:

1. Create and distribute thousands of simple, effective and colorful artist-designed postcard kits with information, Action and seeds to protect and sustain butterflies and bees:

Each kit comes with easy-to-understand and comprehensive information about what you can do right now to sustain pollinators;  a packet of seed mix specially formulated for the pollinators in regions specific to their migratory path and a take-action postcard to send Congress to support HR 2692, “The Save Our American Pollinators Act of 2013” which will place a moratorium on the harmful neonic pesticides already banned in the EU but still widely used in the US, killing butterflies and bees at unprecedented levels. 

2. Have an immediate public, local impact with a booth at the Pacific Grove “Good Old Days Festival” where you will help sponsor activities with children, inform the public at large and distribute hundreds of our SAVE OUR POLLINATORS ACTION KITS right in Butterfly Town, USA reaching out to local residents and the many travelers who visit our region. 

3. Work with Central Valley Farmers and other bio-regions to help expand habitat that sustains and protects the bees and butterflies crucial to orchards and farm-fresh foods. Your contribution will help us reach thousands of people with direct action to help pollinators in our gardens and habitats while reaching out to farmers, growers to help them with what they need to protect pollinators and joining all of us in taking direct political action to make democracy work to sustain bees and pollinators.

WHAT YOUR CONTRIBUTIONS WILL PAY FOR 

You will help us pay for a comprehensive and effective campaign to help pollinators across the country. Your donations will cover printing costs for 1000s of color post-card kits with beautiful artwork and clear information; 1000s of seed kits in envelopes we’ll pack by hand; a campaign to save pollinators with postcards targeted for Congress; a campaign launch and booth in Butterfly Town USA for the "Good Old Days Festival" April 5 and 6; coordinating with farmers and growers working together to sustain bee and butterfly habitat as well as shipping costs. 

Even if we are unable to meet our full funding goal, your contributions will still be effective in local outreach, printing and distributing Save Our Pollinators Kits and reaching out to farmers, just at a reduced level. Everything you donate will go directly toward this campaign. We are a local and artist-run group; 

we create to take direct action without bureaucratic waste.

story:
Hi,

My name is Geoff Brown

And I present Clean Water in a bucket.

The statistics surrounding people without clean water are dire:

Half the world’s hospital beds are filled with people suffering from water related diseases.

Water-related illnesses, mostly diarrhoea, cause the deaths of more than 1 million children each year in the developing world.

768 million people one in ten of the world's population, do not have access to safe water. 

These people would not be around without water.

What they need to do is to clean the water they have.

My proposition is therefore - Clean Water in a Bucket.

Shopping List

Take a ‘standard’ 20 litre paint bucket, recycled will do.

Add:

a circular photovoltaic lid, a condensing cone, a collector, a filter, a drain, an immersion heater

and 10 litres of dirty water.

Process

Pour the dirty water in. 

Point the photovoltaic lid at the sun.

Wait.

Collect the clean water.

Now the tekky bit:

The sun provides energy to generate electricity in the photovoltaic cell.

This is connected electrically to the immersion heater.

The water is heated by the immersion heater.

As soon as the water is heated above the temperature of the air above the water it starts to evaporate. The dirt stays behind.

The water condenses on the cone and runs down to the collector.

Here it is filtered to remove bacteria.

Collect the clean water.

There are a couple of similar devices:

One for salt water

And one for clear water

Clean water in a bucket produces clean water from any water.

Clean water in a bucket:

Locally constructed from tried and tested components to provide personal clean water

I am currently looking for funding for the prototype buckets and to create a professional video to promote the bucket. My ultimate aim is to produce buckets where needed for 20$ each.

Visit us at www.cwiab.eu.pn

Thank you

story:
PAVAP - Volunteering Program for Protected Areas

This is a program lead by the Environmental Engineering Students from the National University of Asuncion. The program focuses on countrywide biodiversity conservation processes through volunteering and is a healthy activity to exchange knowledge and experiences.


It offers an opportunity to work for the care of the natural protected areas. It´s a program where the volunteers support the work of the forest rangers by doing simple tasks such as environmental education, waste classification, maintenance and reparation of trails, tour guiding, first aid care of tourists and so on. With this program we look for volunteers to participate, share and grow from their experiences.

This Activity was born in Paraguay with the name of PAVANP around 1990 and was developed for another organization for almost 7 years. Today, after nearly 14 years of culmination we want to thank and give back to the work of former volunteers and environmental engineer students in the National University of Asunción.

We have finished a first successful cycle between January and February of 2013 in the Ybycui National Park (La Rosada). There were six weeks of hard work with unique experiences and direct contact with nature. Nearly 100 volunteers participated, they were taught in several fields of study, such as: First aid, Protected Natural Areas, Bird Watching, Flora and Fauna Monitoring, and Solid Waste Management.

We firmly believe that the PAVAP is a necessary and effective tool for Natural Protected Areas, that are in danger today, mainly from visitor impacts. Park visitors are simply not aware of the importance of these conservation areas, which poses an opportunity for education.  We see great opportunity to utilize the university students in assisting in Protected Area Management strategies.

This year we want to continue working in Paraguayan Natural Protected Areas and we need your help by contributing to this cause, you will be directly helping to maintain our important natural heritage.


When you come visit the Ybicuy National Park, we´ll be waiting you with open arms, and you will see the beauty that 5000 hectares of forests holds.

So, join us in this process of change! Today is up to us to protect these extraordinary ecosystems for generations to come. 

PAVAP - Programa de Apoyo de Voluntarios en Áreas Protegidas

El programa de apoyo para voluntarios en las Áreas Protegidas (AP), es un programa participativo para la conservación de la naturaleza, es un proceso de conservación de la biodiversidad del país a través del voluntariado, pretende ser una actividad sana donde intercambiar conocimientos y experiencias. 

Ofrece la oportunidad de trabajar por el cuidado de las áreas protegidas de nuestro país. El programa tiene como objetivos brindar a los voluntarios capacitaciones mediante clases teórico-prácticas sobre temas relacionados a las Áreas protegidas, el manejo y la situación actual en rasgos generales a modo de dar a conocer a los voluntarios la realidad nacional sobre las mismas. La educación ambiental como base para la interacción de los voluntarios con los visitantes. 

La clasificación y aprovechamiento de residuos sólidos generados por los visitantes, reparación de senderos y carteles de señalización dentro del Parque ofreciendo informaciones útiles a los visitantes y a la vez instando a colaborar con las labores de mantenimiento. El eco turismo una modalidad de turismo que busca generar el mínimo impacto de los visitantes a las áreas naturales. Por último servicio de primeros auxilios para la atención en caso de accidentes los cuales son inevitables dentro de las áreas. 

El PAVAP fue llevado a cabo en el Parque Nacional de Ybycui (PNY) a mediados del mes de enero y finalizó al término del mes de febrero del 2013. Con esta primera experiencia se lograron cumplir con los objetivos propuestos: capacitación a más de setenta voluntarios quienes fueron a apoyar las labores de los guarda parques, principalmente en la limpieza de las zonas visitadas y de proveer información a más de 5.000 (cinco mil) visitantes según el reglamento de uso público dentro de las Áreas Silvestres Protegidas proporcionado por la Secretaria del Ambiente. 

En las seis semanas de trabajo dentro del PNY se evidenció la necesidad de apoyo institucional para promover y extender esta iniciativa a las áreas de mayor afluencia de visitantes y continuar con el programa de forma permanente para asegurar el disfrute de los servicios ambientales que ofrece el Parque a las generaciones futuras.

story:
Hello Everyone! 


My name is Harshita Pilla, and I'm the team lead for the Tibetan Village Project at Berkeley. I'm currently a second year, Civil and Environmental Engineering undergraduate at the University of California, Berkeley. I'm personally very interested in the importance of sustainable design in our future, which is why I've chosen to take this project on. Thank you for visiting this page, and if you have any questions, feel free to personally email me at harshita.pilla@berkeley.edu. 

Who's the Tibetan Village at Berkeley?
We're a group of students who have been working this past year to attempt to combat the waste management issues in rural Tibet. We comprise of many different academic interests, including biology, civil engineering, bioengineering, architecture, and sustainable design, and are hoping that our integrative approach will offer a novel solution to this critical problem. 

What's the problem?
Waste management is a critical issue in Tibet. There is no real waste collection system as political barriers with China and physical terrain deter any sort of transportation of trash out of the country. In addition, we found out that a majority of the trash that is polluting the river source are made of plastic and glass, both recyclable. 

So... what are we actually going to do about it? 
We've been working on a design to build a greenhouse constructed completely out of the waste that is currently contaminating the water source in the rural village of Yoloshi in western Tibet. This greenhouse will not only serve as a community center where villagers can exchange goods, but also will stand as a visual reminder of the things you can do with "trash." We plan to build the greenhouse side by side with villagers, so they can understand and reproduce our design after we leave. Apart from that, we also plan on providing educational materials to students and families giving them a guide to smart recycling and sustainability. We'll have the opportunity to travel to Tibet on May 18th and actually implement our work, and we need all the support we can get before then! 
What have we done so far? 
We've hosted a benefit dinner, displayed our efforts and gained support at the annual Cal Day at Berkeley, built part of a prototype of the model, and raised about $4000 in funding. Attached are some photos from the various events we've hosted or displayed our work in! 

Above (without the flyers) is a sample of the type of wall we want to build for our greenhouse.

Why we need your help: 
The Tibetan Village Project is the non profit organization that we've been working closely with over the past year, and we're hoping to bring attention to the fantastic work that they've been doing for the past 13 years. Other than the materials cost that we need to make our own design come to life, we want to raise as much awareness and funds as possible to ensure that the community will have enough funds to keeping improving and creating new ways to combat the waste management problem. 

How can you help? 
Share this page and spread the message as far as you can!

Donate to help ensure the sustainability of our project for years to come. The primary methods of funding is coming from our pockets, which makes it hard as college students. Any small donation will be extremely appreciated!

For more information, please feel free to contact us or visit our website below: 
http://tvpberkeley.wix.com/tvp2014

Thanks and Go Bears, 

Harshita Pilla
TVP Berkeley Team Lead

The primary methods of funding is coming from our pockets, which makes it hard as college students. Any small donation will be extremely appreciated!For more information, please feel free to contact us or visit our website below: http://tvpberkeley.wix.com/tvp2014Thanks and Go Bears, 

Harshita Pilla
TVP Berkeley Team Lead

story:
Students from a graduate school in California will be traveling to Colombia to assist Misión Gaia, a non- profit organization dedicated to the development of sustainable tourism in the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta, Colombia to develop a long-term business plan. This business plan will help Misión Gaia ensure that tourism in the region doesn't create more ecological problems and social disparities, but instead trains and empowers the local community to manage their own businesses and protect the environment. 

One of the ways that they are doing this is through a birdwatching program that allows tourists to experience the unique biodiversity of the region. The animal and plant life in the area is worth more to this community if it is intact--unlike  other ecologically devastating economic activities that are common in the region, like logging or mining. This also offers the community a long term source of income that will allow them to invest in schools, medical centers and more businesses that generate wealth and protect their irreplaceable natural resources. The tour guides are trained and the business is ready to go-- they just need a little bit of help. 

They don't have the money for the binoculars. They aren't asking for any cash or long-term investments, they are asking for help buying the binoculars that they need so that they can begin their exciting journey as entrepreneurs. 

Returns on the investment will have a much greater impact than you could ever imagine: you'll be part of a movement that lifts local communities out of poverty, protects unique and threatened species and allows tourists from all over the world to learn about Colombia's flora and fauna!

Binoculars Needed for Community Based Ecotourism in Minca, Colombia:

As a part of our efforts to build capacity and develop new strategies for ecotourism, we are utilizing participatory planning to steer our burgeoning tourism market towards ecotourism that benefits the local community, local economy and protects our unique natural environment.  

As Minca's tourism has increased by 33% in the last two years, we feel it is now more important than ever to be prepared for this change by providing nature tourism technical training programs to community members.  With generous support from Eco turs and the PROAVES Foundation we have been able to deliver the first theoretical and practical training for youth bird watching, a training consisting of 60 field hours.  We work in an area with more than 600 species of birds (including 20 endemic species) that is also a UNESCO Biosphere Reserve.  We still do not have binoculars, which would allow the group to apply its newly acquired knowledge.  

What We Need & What You Get

In order to purchase high quality birding binoculars for our bird watching graduates, we are aiming to raise $6,000.  Each pair of high quality binoculars (Eagle Optics, Ranger 10x42) costs $309.99.  We are aiming to raise enough money to purchase 20 pairs.  15 of these pairs will support graduates of the recent bird watching guiding training, while the remaining five pairs will be reserved for the next round of community training.  If we do not meet our overall funding goal, all money raised will go directly towards the purchasing of the number of binoculars the funds will support.

The Impact

Your contribution supports the Minca community members who have participated in the bird watching technical theoretical and field training program by providing the tools they need to take their training to the next level.  Misión Gaia will continue to support these individuals to further develop their guiding techniques and enterprises.  Your contribution directly supports the development of sustainable livelihoods in Minca, Colombia to improve local living standards and safeguard natural resources in the face of rapidly increasing tourism in the region.

Background/Information:

THE NEED:

•Young people in Minca have limited job options due to a lack of training.

•There are no trained guides on which tour operators can rely.

•The existing training opportunities in Ecotourism are of low-quality, and access is restricted.

•There is a limited availability of equipment to strengthen training programs and allow newly acquired knowledge to be applied.

HOW WE ARE RESPONDING:

•We have aid from Eco turs and the PROAVES Foundation for the theoretical and practical training of youths in nature tourism, specifically in bird watching.

•We are looking for new partners to create and strengthen training programs.

•A group of 15 young people from four communities in the Minca area have participated in the training focused on bird watching.

•With the support of SerCO natural and Eco Turs, we have developed the first course in bird watching for ecotourism guides in the Minca area, and we are looking for support in order to continue the training process. 

•We are in the process of establishing partnerships with various national and local groups, such as SENA, the University of Magdalena and the Elemento Outdoor Adventure company to support these training opportunities.

•We still do not have binoculars, which would allow the group to apply its newly acquired knowledge.

Misión Gaia, Background

OUR ORGANIZATION

Misión Gaia was founded in 2011 by a team of professionals from diverse backgrounds, all of whom have a passion for conservation and for promoting sustainability in the region of Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta, Colombia. The organization aims to encourage the responsible use of diverse natural resources so that they may be secured for future generations.

OUR MISSION

Utilizing participatory planning in local communities, we seek to increase educational opportunities to improve local living conditions and standards through sustainable development, ensuring the availability and diversity of resources over time.

OUR VISION

We envision united communities that protect diversity, develop low-impact environmental processes, promote conservation awareness and encourage respect for nature.

OUR GOALS

·  To increase environmental awareness; to develop effective actions; to promote the sustainable use of resources; and to help improve the quality of life for local communities. 

·  Lead and support participatory environmental and educational projects to generate responses to local problems. 

·  Develop training programs to produce environmental leaders who raise awareness about environmental issues and the sustainable use of natural resources. 

·  Promote socio-cultural exchange by involving local and international volunteers cooperating in projects within a framework of solidarity tourism.

WHERE WE WORK

[img border="0" width="320" height="240" src="file:///C:\Users\Whitney\AppData\Local\Temp\msohtmlclip1\01\clip_image001.jpg" alt="http://www.misiongaia.org/_/rsrc/1346273480224/about-us-1/MG_Picos.JPG?height=240&width=320" v:shapes="Picture_x0020_2">

We work with rural communities in the Colombian Caribbean and the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta, the highest coastal mountain range in the world, which reaches 5,700 m and has a complex network of ecosystems. The area is home to more than 600 bird species - of which nearly 20 are endemic. This unique environment is sacred to the indigenous communities and must be preserved and protected.

Find out more about la Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta:        

http://www.sacredland.org/sierra-nevada-de-santa-marta/ 

http://tairona.myzen.co.uk/index.php/history/the_kogi_in_the_20th_century/ 

http://blog.coloradocollege.edu/IndigenousTraditions/sacred-lands/sierra-nevada-de-santa-marta/

OUR PARTNERS

Misión Gaia´s international partners are Association Voyage & Sens, Association Tourisme Sans Frontières, Omprakash Network and Digital Hope. Our national partners are public institutions such as Secretaria de Salud Distrital and Secretaria de Educación Distrital Santa Marta, Junta de Acción Comunal de Minca some NGOs including Fundación Calipso, SercoNatural and Proaves; as well as private local businesses: El Eden la Tagua, Literarte Taganga, Elemento Outdoor Adventure and Poseidon Dive Center. 

What We Need & What You Get

In order to purchase high quality birding binoculars for our bird watching graduates, we are aiming to raise $6,000.  Each pair of high quality binoculars (Eagle Optics, Ranger 10x42) costs $309.99.  We are aiming to raise enough money to purchase 20 pairs.  15 of these pairs will support graduates of the recent bird watching guiding training, while the remaining five pairs will be reserved for the next round of community training.  If we do not meet our overall funding goal, all money raised will go directly towards the purchasing of the number of binoculars the funds will support.

The Impact

Your contribution supports the Minca community members who have participated in the bird watching technical theoretical and field training program by providing the tools they need to take their training to the next level.  Misión Gaia will continue to support these individuals to further develop their guiding techniques and enterprises.  Your contribution directly supports the development of sustainable livelihoods in Minca, Colombia to improve local living standards and safeguard natural resources in the face of rapidly increasing tourism in the region.

Please see our website for the myriad of projects we have initiated in less than three years!

Other Ways You Can Help

You can also help us to spread the word concerning our campaign and organization in general.  We have a partnership with Omprakash to financially support volunteers who wish to help us in achieving our mission. Please see: http://www.omprakash.org/ for more information!
